Disappointment of the year?
I am a fan of Metal gear solid series, i loved previous games, those were one of the best games i have ever played. I had high hopes for MGSV, i have waited so long and thought this will be the culmination, this will be the best MGS game. But it turned out to be the opposite.

The gameplay is really good and fun. You can approach the mission as you like. Going pure stealth no kills or killing everyone or just rambo style. It works all ways. The gameplay is basically the same as in paid demo - Ground zeroes. It's really an amazing feeling when you accomplish the mission not alerting anyone. Or you going onto rampage killing everyone. You can choose t what day time to do the missions. Day or night. At day enemies see you from a longer distance, at night they can't see you from 20 meters. But it changes if you always play at night. Enemies then start using night vision goggles.

The buddy system is really nice. You have a D-Horse which helps you travel longer distances fast. And you can give a command to poop. Nice huh? Then you have a D-Dog. He can spot enemies form quite a long distance, so he‚Äòs pretty useful. He can equip a knife and kill enemies. And of course you have Quiet. A sexy half naked girl with the ability to turn invisible. She‚Äòs a sniper and she can take out all the camp alone. You then run through the camp collecting resources and fultoning people to your base to build up your army. And the last one is D-Walker. It‚Äòs really useful if you want destroy everything and kill everyone. You can have some fun using it.

Graphics are average. The game has pretty good lighting so sometimes it looks really good, but when you play for some time you notice that graphics are not very good. At least the game runs on 60fps almost all the time.

MGS always had amazing story and characters. In  MGSV  story is almost non existent and the characters are bland and uninteresting. The game is about completing missions in the same locations over and over again. The opening scene was awesome, it was so MGS, but after that the game gone downhill and the longer you play the worse it gets. Konami just wanted to make this game lengthy and took the easy and stupid path. There are 157 side ops which are boring and repetitive. The main game consists of 50 missions. Half of them are interesting and other half is just a content filler. Like it‚Äòs not enough you‚Äòre forced to replay some missions on harder difficulty in chapter 2. Why? Because the game must be longer. The story is unfinished. Some users found out hidden chapter in game files. So we can expect a DLC. The open world is empty and useless. The lack of cut scenes makes the game even worse. After the prologue don‚Äòt expect much cut scenes.

Another annoying thing is FOB. You are forced to play online in a single player game. People can invade other peoples FOBs and steal resources and staff. So if you grind for hours for resourses and staff, someone can just steal it from you. There‚Äòre microtransactions. You can buy an insurance so that other people couldn‚Äòt invade you and steal your resources. The insurance is not permanent of course if you want to be safe you must pay more. Also you can buy more FOBs for real money. This is ridiculous and sad at the same time. Great job Konami, you just took the crown from Ubisoft. I hope Konami will disappear from gaming world forever. No one will miss them. At least you can disconnect from online and play the game how it‚Äòs supposed to be played.

Is it worth buying? At the current price no. Another no because it‚Äòs Konami. They ruined the game. And just look at the newest PES. People shouldn‚Äòt support them. Buy it when it‚Äòs on sale for 10‚Ç¨ or so. You still can have some fun with the game. As a non MGS game it would be a really decent game, but there‚Äòs not much left from MGS and as an MGS game it‚Äòs the worst in the series.

Cons:

Repetitive missions
Content filler missions
The most ridiculous microtransactions

reviewText:
Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain is the final game in the Metal Gear Solid franchise produced by series creator Hideo Kojima. It is a continuation of the story of Ground Zeroes and a chronological sequel to the Metal Gear Solid 3, Portable Ops and Peace Walker. In a lot of ways Metal Gear Solid 5 is closer to what Kojima desired the original Metal Gear on the MSX to be. A game with a focus on modern military combat set in a style of 80's cheese.

There's a lot to say about the Phantom Pain. What it does well, and why fans walked out on the game feeling bitter and disappointed. In many ways the title reflects the mental state of the protagonist and the fanbase alike. There is a feeling of longing, for something that was there and is no longer.

We find ourselves in the shoes of Snake set 10 years prior to the events of Metal Gear. After a 9 year coma he awakes, and sets out for revenge and to rebuild his army. The storytelling in TPP is easily some of the worst in the series. The villains are unmemorable, the story is half baked, there are no interesting codec calls to shed exposition and provide a nice pacing break to the story. It feels very unlike a traditional Metal Gear Solid game in this regard. Snake feels like a silent protagonist, and you can swap him out with a member of your military just fine and feel very little difference. Revolver Ocelot is completely underused and miscast. The only character who feels like he's giving an actual performance is Robin Atkin Downes as Kazuhira Miller. Without David Hayter as Snake, TPP feels more like a modern military shooter and lacks the humor and self awareness the series was well known for.

But all that aside, the gameplay in TPP is easily the best in the series. The game feels much more akin to what a lot of other stealth action games have attempted but never quite grasped. Snake's movement is very tight and responsive, gunplay is good and quick, enemy AI responds to the player's actions convincingly, and stealth is always the most viable option. Ontop of this the game has sim-like elements related to kidnapping enemy soldiers and conscripting them to join your ranks. These sim elements brilliantly lead to you using stealth not just because the game is designed around it, but because you want to get better upgrades much quicker. It's an extremely comfy game and it feels very at home with other open world games like Red Dead Redemption and Far Cry 3. It also runs surprisingly well on PC.

The Phantom Pain might appeal to newcomers to the Metal Gear franchise much more for these reasons. And as a result it's very hard for me to recommend the game to longtime fans unless you're aware of what you're going into. It doesn't feel like Metal Gear went out with a bang but with a whimper.

And in a lot of ways it is poetic justice. For long periods of time Metal Gear Solid was criticized for having fairly awkward gameplay, long cutscenes and unnecessary philosophical drama. What TPP does instead is give people what a more general audience wanted, but it sacrifices something for it. And long after the game is over, it leaves you with a feeling of pain in your fingertips where your arm once was.

reviewText:
This review does not contain spoilers and any information revealed can be found in trailers prior to the game's release. Metal Gear has been under a lot of hype and I will explain the reasons why this game isn't at all what it's made up to be.

Unlike the older Metal Gear games which can be completed in a few hours and generally feel satisfying, The Phantom Pain has an incredible amount of pointless filler. Of the 207 missions in the game, only 15 advance the story - that's just over 7% of the game for the story. What's even more frustrating is that towards the end of the game, the older missions are simply repeated with a slightly harder requirement such as no equipment or forced stealth. In fact, in the second chapter of the game, only one mission progresses the story and the player must play those repeat missions to progress. This is artificial lengthening of the game of the laziest order.

There is no character development in the whole game bar one character. Of all the characters in the game, only one has an arc involving development. Everyone else is the same at the end of the game as they are in the beginning. One character that had potential to be interesting was the Man on Fire. I originally thought he was some manifestation for war and conflict, following those that kill or live in war. As a metaphor he is very fitting - he cannot be destroyed and any damage people try to inflict is immediately repelled. It would have made an interesting game mechanic for players that go around killing instead of being non-lethal, much like the encounter with The Sorrow in Metal Gear Solid 3. However when his real identity and purpose is revealed, it's so poorly written that I was almost tempted to bang my head on my desk despite how clich√© that phrase is.

When the Metal Gear mech is revealed, the design is almost identical to a Metal Gear from another game, which is rather disappointing and seems like the artists couldn't be bothered to come up with something fresh and unique.

The AI is very bland and predictable. Seeing as 99% of engagements with the enemy are on flat open outdoor terrain, it simply comes down to learning the distances at which enemies will see you. The game devolves into shooting the enemies in the legs with tranquilisers, because as the game progresses the enemies wear helmets and body armour which resist darts. This leads nicely on to the next point.

The Phantom Pain takes place in Afghanistan and Africa. The gaming media made wild bravado of how open world the game is and how there's so much to do. This is complete nonsense. Afghanistan consists purely of roads with unclimbable cliffs on either side and a checkpoint every few hundred metres. Africa is the same except the cliffs have sometimes been replaced with grassland. There is nothing to do and the vast expanses are completely empty except for visual purposes. It is purely empty ground to traverse with no secrets or reasons to explore.

As for the story, it's truly horrendous and you'll find better written plots in a middle school creative writing class. The characters are one-dimensional, wooden and pretty much every single character in the game is motivated by revenge. I know the plots in the other Metal Gear games are rather silly, but this one enters a whole new frontier. As the game progresses, the plot becomes laughably bad and simply reveals that Kojima can't write stories or characters full stop. The supposed explanation for Quiet's lack of clothing is beyond stupid, serving as a blatant and flawed excuse for her body. I would respect it more if they just said Here's a naked girl" rather than trying to come up with a plot reason why she has to be naked.

Gameplay-wise
date: you spend all of your time picking flowers
recommended: kidnapping men if their stats are high enough and completing pointless objectives like rescuing a man in a desert ten times

Short Review of MGS V TPP :

‚ô¶ Rating - 8/10
‚ô¶ Should you buy and play this game at full price? - Yes absolutely :)

Pros:
‚ô¶ Amazing Gameplay
‚ô¶ Amazing Weapon Customization
‚ô¶ Amazing Main Characters/Protagonist (its Big Boss duh! :P)
‚ô¶ Epic Soundtrack
‚ô¶ Best Prologue in a Game i have seen in the last few years
‚ô¶ Different Ways of doing One Mission/Objective
‚ô¶ Epic Dialogues
‚ô¶ Achieving S ranks are addicting: D

Cons:
‚ô¶ Bad and Unfinished Story (Chapter 2 is unfinished and Chapter 3 is missing)
‚ô¶ Legendary Secondary characters who played important role in MGS history are complete blunt and has no major role in this game
‚ô¶ Chapter 1 has too many repetitive missions
‚ô¶ Some actual Story related important missions are thrown in side missions which would have been better if was placed in chapter 2 main missions
‚ô¶ It is not the missing link that Kojima promised
‚ô¶ Not enough Boss Battles like previous MGS Games (Main bosses mostly killed in custscenes)
‚ô¶ Most of the Story is in cassette taped
‚ô¶ No codec conversations (it is kind of a big deal to me since imo that is a big part of MGS)
‚ô¶ No Long MGS Cutscenes
‚ô¶ Sudden Ending out of nowhere

As you can see most of the negatives in this review of mine are not some big game breaking negatives but instead mgs saga's story related problems, Kojima promised an epic ending which will be the missing link to the franchise but due to konami and kojima's cold war we didn't get that and the game was instead sold in its unfinished form. The game has lots of repetitive missions but you will never get bored of playing this game just because of its amazing gameplay and weapons and because of the different ways of doing a single objective you can do a mission 2-5 times like me just to see how many ways something can be achieved.
its definitely worth buying and playing, even if you are a non mgs fan and even if you hated previous mgs for bad controls, too long cutscenes etc you will love this game :) and if you are a mgs fan like me then i am sure you have already bought it, played it, wrote your own fan fiction about the ending of mgs saga story and linked the dots which Kojima and Konami didn't lol :P


Anyway i hope this review helps anyone who wants to buy this game :) it is my first review so if i did something wrong be sure to tell me :)

reviewText:
Metal Gear Solid V : The Phantom Story

Hear me out when I say the gameplay in this game is probably the best in the series so far. You'll most likely have hours of fun playing the game. But why on earth would I give this game a negative review?

The simple reason comes down to the story. My first major issue is that the story just abrutly ends. Imagine if in Metal Gear Solid, the credits rolled after the torture scene with ocelot. That's what it is like here. The game sets up a bunch of different plot points and then leaves them unresolved when the game ends. Konami even had the final battle and ending cut from the game to push the game out, you can even find the alpha footage on youtube.

My second issue comes from Kojima. Don't get me wrong, Kojima is the man. But in Phantom Pain he has forgotten many crucial plot details from MG1, 2 and MGS4. The end result is that he has retconned a great deal of the plot and actually has ruined some of Solid Snake's backstory aswell.

And one last thing. There's too much god damn exposition throughout the story. Many key moments in the Phantom Pain are just explained through long winded dialogue instead of being shown. Of course the series has always been guilty of this to some extent, but in this game it's almost the entire plot that is conveyed in this way. Code Talker is the worst when it comes to this problem.

They also ruined all the mystery and wonder of The End by explaining his abilities with... Well you'll find out. But it's kind of like Star Wars: The Phantom Menace which ruined the sense of wonder of The Force with Midi-chlorians. It's very ironic that they share a similar name.

I enjoyed the game but not the story. It's probably done more damage to the franchise than Konami's pachinko machines ever could. While the story has its share of twists and suprises, it ultimately doesn't live up to the rest of the series. It's like a jigsaw piece that doesn't fit, so you have to force it to fit by hammering at it until it does. You ultimately end up with a broken picture.

If you don't care about the story, you'll probably enjoy the gameplay. But if you're a real fan of the Metal gear franchise you'll understand exactly why I take issue with the game. My best guess to the source of the problem is Konami making cutbacks to their video game sector and Kojima simply being forgetful when it comes to his plotlines. Amazing game, terrible story.

reviewText:
This game is great, I had MANY hours of fun.

While I like the game, I DON'T like to play clash of clans.
How does this fit with MGSV you ask?

There's a little thing called FOBs (Forward Operating Base) these little data streams are initially seen as a wonderful asset to your game, because you get more room, more resources, and access to better upgrades!

But these perks come with a drawback. You now need to develop a new security team to defend your FOB from invasions. This is where my Clash of Clans comment draws in. PLAYERS are the only force to invade your FOBs and if they succeed they get to take some of your men.

This affects your SINGLE PLAYER game. These losses can affect ALL of your teams, you WILL lose levels on your teams, you CANNOT disable FOBs. you get to choose where to place your men, your guns, and your drones, but that doesn't affect anything when a player can LITERALLY kill everyone and take 40 men.

Personally, I like the game. I do not like forced PVP. I cannot recommend a game like this.

Tl;DR: Gud game, bad forced PVP.

Thank you for reading

reviewText:
More Metal Gear Solid!

If you liked the previous MGS games, have been interested in checking them out or if you like open world games like say Red Dead Redemption, get on steam or get to the store and pick this game up right now.

Gameplay is improved, controls are improved and for me atleast so far it is already more enjoyable than MGS4 was. You get the usual interesting characters that Kojima is known for and of course an overly long tutorial/intro that could have been shorter, but in general the story, characters and dialogue are not as good as in past games.

The way the story and cutscenes are done is different from previous Metal Gear Solid games, less cutscenes and more storytelling that is IN GAME( Such as cassette tapes,etc..). Definatly a different approach to that aspect when compared to past games, but I am liking it so far mainly for the gameplay.

Gorgeous graphics, the game runs very well and it is alot of fun to play. No idea how the online will be come Jan, but I wasn't to huge on MGS4's online. The singleplayer campaign is worth it alone imo, like The Witcher 3, side missions are a good deal mroe fun than alot of other open world games.

I have had no crashes, no performance issues and no gamebreaking bugs so far after 7 hours, it is very well optimized, especially for how good the game looks. If you ran the Prequel fine, you will have no issue playing MGS5.

Some of these microtransactions for the online I have been reading about sounds like it was not needed which makes me think maybe this was one issue Kojima had with Konami while this game was being made.

The audio is very well done also, as is the voice work, this game really is a joy to play in nearly every aspect. Kojima has always reminded me somewhat of one of my favorite foreign movie directors, Takashi Miiike. Both are almost always brilliant, different and unique in alot of ways. Sure they both can take it a little far sometimes with there own style and flare but the good far outweigh the bad most the time and MGS5 is no different. Sure there is the odd time when I feel like Kojima and Takashi Miike both could use a better editor or tone some things down but would we honestly want that in the end? For me personally I don't think either would be nearly the fantastic creators they are if they just kept everything to the script and did things like everyone else. Imagine them playing it by the book?

Stacked to the brim with things to do, addicting gameplay and the usual Kojima flare and brilliance that we have come to love, an overly long intro/tutorial and some microtransactions can't bring down what is one of the best Metal Gear Solid games yet and just behind Witcher 3 and Pillars of Eternity as my favorite games of 2015 so far.

Where does this game stack up in the MGS series? For me it is hands down better than MGS4 (which was the weakest of the bunch for me personally) and up there with MGS 1-3 qualitywise. The controls and gameplay are quite improved from the early games which is nice. Weither you are brand new to the series or a long time vet like myself, I think you will enjoy this game. All stealth fans, MGS fans and open world fans need to check out this game ASAP!

The last issue I have is with the motherbase, this could have been done so much better. It is a very cool idea but with a bit more depth man... this could have been a HUGE positive for the game but as it is, it just feels very empty and after awhile somewhat useless. Far from perfect but still very enjoyable for its gameplay!

reviewText:
This is a tricky game to review. From the perspective of MGS 1 and 2 this game is missing the old gameplay and ambience. I really have to look hard to see a MGS game in this.

As for the gameplay it feels almost like a mix bewteen Tomb Raider and Sniper Elite, but then with modern gadgets and tools. As in Tomb Raider you have to gather plants and wildlife (and diamonds) just as in this game. Which is a bit weird as you have a large base with personel. Apparently you have the supplies to build a gigantic offshore plaform, but you do still have to gather plants for supplies. And the sneaking/killing/tagging/overwatching is fairly the same as in Sniper Elite, but then in a modern day setting.

So far (30 hours of gameplay) the game conststs of doing uninspired missions such as 'free a prisoner' or 'steal a blueprint' or 'kill an officer'. Luckily those missions take place on a good designed open world(ish) map where you have decent amount of freedom to complete the missions. The fun part of the gameplay is that you can choose your own way of finishing the objective and clearing out hostile area's while using all the neat gadgets and weapons you have available. With the things you 'earn' from those missions you can expand, upgrade and develop your base further.

The graphics are really nice in this game and all the assets/objects/characters on the map are all well modeled and textured (vegetation could have been better though). And on top of that the game runs very well on maxed settings. There could have been some more graphics options (specially AA options. jaggies on maxed settings), but it is all decent enough.

From nostalgia perspective and remembering the old gameplay of the first 2 games in the series you might get a bit dissapointed, but if you forget that this a MGS game then this game is a good game with solid gameplay and game mechanics thats well worth the price tag on the store page.

There is also an online part in the game that lets you compete against other players, but I haven't touched that yet.

85/100

Update after 100 hours:

The gameplay overall is stilll pretty cool. However, the story missions gameplay gets interupted by totally lame missions where you are up gainst 'super villians'. It is just horribly designed and totally brakes the normal gameplay of the game. It's so bad that I just stopped doing the story missions and completed 100+ side-ops missions instead. I litterally had to exploit and brake missions to continue the story missions as in a 'normal' gameplay way it's frustrating and simply not fun to do the story missions that contains 'super villians'.

For this it gets a:

75/100

reviewText:
I'm a long time Metal Gear Solid fan, I've played all the games and I built my computer in March of 2015 picking parts that I knew would max out the game.

I don't completely dislike this game, I do NOT recommend it to prior fans who want more Metal Gear, those who are new to the franchise and have only played all the games before the announcement of this game won't feel the pain most hardcore fans will feel.

I don't like this Metal Gear game, it felt the least bit Metal Gear. I don't hate it and feel that this is a great game on it's own, but it's not the same Metal Gear I love, I'm not being nostalgic, I think that this game is lacking in the level design, item uses, multiple issues in the game. The mechanics are superb and I do love the refinements that they have made over Ground Zeroes and it's not the new ''mature'' story that turned me off, in fact, I was really expecting and WELCOMING this grimdark game that would of shown us the downfall of Big Boss.

GAME MAP; HALF FULL OR HALF EMPTY?
This game's world feels dead to me, the first minute I booted the game up, I was in love with it, the intro was something I didn't expect and I liked, the Phantom Limbs mission had me hyped since I was finally playing the mission I was shown atleast 2 years ago at E3 2013 and now I was finally playing it!

This mission and a select few others are the only interesting ones as they have something important that is required for the plot to progress. The game's maps suck. Both of them, Afghan is more interesting to me but I felt like they completely missed the mark with it, there's only about 4-5 areas in each map that's fun to infiltrate, the rest are no fun, are open and have nothing interesting about them, literally copy pasted about the map.

PORTRAYAL OF CONFLICT AMONGST SOLDIER FORCES
In MGS4 (‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you I loved it), there were two sides to the conflict in the area, the Militia and the PMC, this idea was only shown in Act 1 and 2 but it was amazing, siding with the Militia would make it easier to go through areas after you wait for them to clear it out and then you're free to walk about them and it will not trigger an alert, siding with the PMC does nothing cause you're still their enemy.

The two sides of conflict made it either easier or harder to progress and I loved that idea, you could slip by enemies that are focused on the other side of their conflict, or you could side with the underdog, watch them win (even assist if you wish) and then not bother slipping by but rather walk about.

In MGSV, we constantly hear about the Mujahideen and whatnot, but where are they? I didn't see a single Mujahideen in the map fighting the enemy, I didn't even see conflict! I only saw a few Mujahideen PRISONERS. Total downgrade from MGS4 in this department, that and the fact we cannot use disguises or anything at all since camouflage isn't as easily changable as in the past but rather a choice you make at the start, or a choice you make later, pay for then wait for, meaning temporary disguises would be painful to use as you would have go through all that effort, etc.

I noted in Africa, there were multiple Private Forces companies but noone ever fought one another, they weren't even in the radius of one another, it was only static soldiers that wouldn't react to the outside ecosystem but only react to you. As if there's nothing else important in their lives that only you are their worry.

STORY; KOJIMA WENT PANTS ON HEAD STUPID
I'm sure at this stage, anyone that's played the game is familiar with the trailers, the trailers were beautiful, every single one of them had a song that would perfectly capture the tone and went well with the shots we were shown.

This will delve into spoilers, so anything I have blacked out, I am talking about spoilers, so please, if you haven't beaten the game (I mean Chapter 2) and look at the spoilers, don't moan to me, this is a warning.

Metal Gear Solid V didn't have the grimdark story I expected, I expected a story about how Kaz and Big Boss became demons, how information can kill people from the qoute 'Words can Kill' but instead we get this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing story about ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing PARASITES of all things killing people when they speak a specific language.

Skullface was a very interesting villain, but underused, I didn't see him as often as Volgin but he did intrigue me a fair bit, he was pretty cool in Ground Zeroes, he had that proper villian aura, but instead we get this idiot that was technically Big Boss' phantom during MGS3 (this is why he qoutes Volgin with ''Remember the Alamo'' since he knew that is proof of him being there during the Virtuous Mission since anyone else that would have heard it is dead bar Sokolov at this point)

Big Boss never becomes the villain, in this game he's the nice dude that saves kids, and mercy kills his men since they're infected. Then you think, how is Big Boss a demon, you even collect Heroism Points.  So I finally beat the game, the plot twist? We were the medic in GZ, Big Boss ran off making Outer Heaven in Zanzibar land and your character becomes the Big Boss that dies in MG1, meaning the only loop it closes is to explain why Big Boss is alive in MG2.

What was the point of it all? We do hear about Sniper Wolf and other Sons of Big Boss members encountering Big Boss, why couldn't they put that into the game?

I really liked Ground Zeroes, it was an amazing prologue. Camp Omega was beautifully designed and felt like a living, breathing Guantanamo Bay style area, and the whole situation with Chico and Paz felt like MGSV was gonna include more taboos but instead we get nothing too taboo at all.

TL;DR Spoilers: The game makes no important additions into the Metal Gear Franchise.


MUSIC; 80s HITS AND ORIGINALS MISSES
The track list in this game is quite good, with a few hits, but there's not too many tracks from that era and I'd prefer if they even tracks like ''Gimme Shelter'', ''All Along The Watchtower'' or even something as obscure as ''Holiday in Cambodia'', instead we get ''Friday I'm in Love'' (from 1992), but nothing that captures the 70s/80s war vibe.

Tracks from Ground Zeroes do not return. The game's OST sucks ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• compared to past games since Ludvig Forssell isn't half as good as Harry Gregson-Williams (who got pushed to producer rather than composer) and the only memorable tracks in this are 'V has come to', 'Disarmament' and that one song that plays in the Quarantine Mission.

I would type more about how FOBs suck, how MGO3 doesn't look half as good as MGO2, how annoyed I am at unique characters like Glaz and Palitz aren't playable (‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, a proper Big Boss character with no horn and no scars and both arms would have been a nice alt costume for Venom) and how disappointed I am in this game but I already had to cut a portion of this review out like Kojima did to the game.

I'm still going to 100% this game then I can finally write it off as a waste of three years waiting, ‚Ç¨1600 euros wasted and personally, a never ending feeling of disappointment knowing this game isn't the Missing Link.

There is no 'predator-esq' jungles. Most disapointingly is the lack of stronghold, or anything concrete really, the buildings are small and easily cleared/forgotten. reviewText:
One of my all-time favorite games and simply polished to perfect, but the plot...

After the events of Chaos Theory, Sam Fisher awakes from a nine year nightmare of double-crossing, convictions and black lists to find that he's been in a coma the entire time. While recovering in Cyprus, he's set upon by a mysterious assassin whose only motive is to fail spectacularly at killing a helpless man who can't lift his limbs. Sam is saved only by the timely intervention of Reznov, a black ops agent who has been watching over you for your nine year sleep and you can tell he's not real because imagine a ten year medical bill by someone faking it.

After an hour-long intro that serves no real purpose but to teach Sam the ropes of tactical stealth once more (and show hundreds of people being slowly butchered against your screen because Kojima has a thing for trying to impress Americans), Psycho Mantis appears and is completely retconned into a magical nine year old that can shoot down helicopters with giant fiery whales but can't seem to catch a 40lb limp noodle of a man who hasn't used his muscles in ten years. An excellent way to ruin one of the franchises' most treasured characters, but at least you went out with a bang Hideo!

John Marston (Revolver Ocelot(Revolver Ocelot) finds you in the woods with Reznov mysteriously missing, only to reveal that he is a texas cowboy russian who cannot speak russian, leading to some very awkward first missions and future games where he actually betrays his allies to try and bring back glorious russia even though he was apparently fighting russia during the cold war. He tried to eject the first round by hand, but an ocelot never lets his prey escape. You're pretty good.

After that, the entire plot takes a standard Ubisoft turn and goes to complete and utter junk unworthy of being mentioned or parodied, but Sam did keep us waiting, eh?

reviewText:
Finally started playing this game and I'm really thrilled with it. I've been a fan of Metal Gear Solid and Hideo Kojima for many years now having played MGS3 Snake Eater endlessly, so this game and its concepts were nothing new to me. If it were totally new, I would describe it as a strategic game mixed with action.

If you enjoy games that involve the use of powerful weapons that turn you into a Rambo killing everything as quickly as possible in a fantasy land, then you will probably not like this game. MGS Phantom Pain is a game that allows the player to act more realistically. Mission objectives focus on avoidance of detection, destruction of communications, the use of nonlethal force, and the extraction of enemies and hostages with the intent to gain information and new recruits.

To kill an enemy actually eliminates the possibility of an elite mission, which is considered to be more successful with tactical takedowns, interrogations, and extractions of useful and high ranking recruits who can then switch sides and help us at our base of operations. It's a much more cerebral game than most, and it also is an open world environment with many possibilities that are totally open to the choices of the person playing. Kojima's games really consider the use of intelligence over brute force and much of Sun Tzu's philosophy comes to mind while playing.

‚ÄúThe supreme art of war is to subdue the enemy without fighting‚Äù
‚ÄúThe greatest victory is that which requires no battle‚Äù

Such an incredible amount of intelligence went into this game and its production, but humor and emotions can also shine through and be felt. It's a great game, but its also an amazing work of art by a master.

reviewText:
I have officially got 100% in this game now, with 157 hours under my belt. This is also coming from a huge fan of the franchise who's played every Metal Gear game many times to completionist values.

I was so excited for this game, hyped beyond belief and following ever since the original Phantom Pain tease that was a fake project. This game lived up and went beyond all that hype, for the entire first half of the game.

The world building though empty is impressive. Afghanistan and Africa feel like military zones, where the small towns, bases and checkpoints have soliders patrolling, watching out for intruders (which, I admit is only yourself - so it feels a little off when you think about it).

The missions are fun, challenging, stealth is of course always what you should go for, but it's not neccesary - pick up an assault rifle or grenade launcher and blast through. But, you'll be missing out on a lot.

Mother Base building up, fultoning soldiers back to build up your own personal military force, and going to visit the place you've put hours into building up in the Seychelles.

The exitement all ended in the second half, the missions feel repetetive sometimes, or rather lackluster. The story falls apart, to the point where infamously there is a missing mission with a huge unanswered storyline left out - and potentially an entire third act that was cut.

There are issues with this game, the story is the weakest out of any Metal Gear game, there are no classic boss fights like FoxHound. Dead Cell or The Cobra Unit. There are no codec moments. There is no big ending.

But, it's one of the best open world games I've ever played. Capturing soldiers never gets old, and sneaking through a base crowded with soldiers who have donned riot suits or helmets because of your tactics on the battlefield feels tense and gives a challenge. The buddy system is pretty cool, I enjoyed all of them greatly. Research and Development of new items was always something I loved in Peace Walker and it's even better now. Creating new platforms on Mother Base (which you control unlike Peace Walker) is also brilliant, and getting a FOB to build a second one for greater resources and higher ranks of your different units. I hate the MB coin microtransaction system that I never used, the FOB's should have been gradually unlocked through the game, or cost huge amounts of GMP (in game resources).

I wholeheartedly recommend this game. It has flaws, but it is still oh so fantastic.

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/7l1bFSwu1bw
Game: Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain
Genre: Third-person Open-world Stealth
Developer: Kojima Productions
Publisher: Konami Digital Entertainment
Copy supplied by Steam

Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain is an open world third-person stealth game developed by Kojima Productions and published by Konami Digital Entertainment. I grew up playing Metal Gear games, and this is easily my most anticipated game of all time. Thank you Hideo Kojima for all the great game that you made.

STORYNine years after the events of Ground Zeroes, Big Boss wakes up from his coma. After being helped escape from the hospital by Ocelot, he goes to Afghanistan to rescue Kaz Miller, rebuild Mother Base and take revenge on Cipher and Skull Face. Saying more would be a spoiler, and all I can say is that I found the story very interesting and full of plot twists (both believable and not).
Unlike the other games, the cutscenes are shorter and more accessible then before, and the Codec calls have been replaced by cassette tapes that can be played while exploring the battlefield. This way, the gameplay is never broken and you can enjoy a better look at what happens. If you are new to the franchise, you won't understand jack, however the story isn't shoved down your throat like in Guns of the Patriots, and you can just as easily skip the cutscenes if you don't care.

GRAPHICSThe Fox Engine really is sublime: even at the lowest settings every facial animation, every little detail in the open world is beautiful, and everything runs at sweet 60fps at high resolutions. Even though it is open world, the world is still full of details and secrets to discover, as well as varied locations: you will infiltrate power plants, villages, highly-guarded camps and bridges. The game is gorgeous and you don't even need a great PC to enjoy it.

GAMEPLAYFirst of all, the combat. You have tons of possibilities to handle each situation: go in guns-a-blazing with rifles and rocket launches, snipe from afar, call air support, hold-up everyone at gunpoint... The choice is yours. And you are not punished for going on a killing spree, but even more so if you don't kill anyone and avoid detection.
You can also call in four buddies to help you out: D-Horse to move fast and undetected, D-Dog to distract enemies and detect plants and wildlife, Quiet to scout environments and snipe, D-Walker to attack outposts when violence is needed. Each one of them is important, and simply changing buddy changes how you play a mission or Side Op.
Each mission is unique and has relevant bits of story that unlock at the end, and the Side Ops are varied and seemingly unlimited: extract prisoners, destroy heavy infantry, find blueprints, capture animals... Every mission feels relevant, and not put in just to fill a void, something that most open world games do.
You can also develop Mother Base, where the soldiers that you extract go, to develop new weapons, items and outfits. You can also deploy combat units to complete some missions to get more currency and items. You can also explore Mother Base to increase morale, take a shower, find emblem parts and diamonds and complete target practice. You can also customize weapons in every single part (after finding the legendary gunsmith), your buddies, your helicopter and your vehicles.
I just love the amount of detail and depth that is put in the gameplay, making this the most accessible and complete gameplay in a Metal Gear ever.

CHALLENGEThe more you play the game, the smarter the enemies become: you like headshots? They will start using helmets to protect themselves. You enjoy lurking in the night? They will use night vision goggles. The fact that the enemy adapts to your strategy makes every encounter challenging and fresh, and even though your health regenerates, you can't stand behind cover because they will throw grenades or send shielded enemies to kill you. However, you have enough firepower and possibilities to defeat this enemies and escape when everything goes south, making everything more enjoyable rather than frustrating.

SOUNDThe voice acting is superb: like him or not, Kiefer Sutherland is very good as Big Boss (even though he mostly talks in the cassette tapes), and Robin Atkin Downes, Troy Baker and another voice actors do a fantastic job as always. The sound effects are also brilliant, with each gun and footstep never feeling out of place.
And the soundtrack. I LOVE this soundtrack. Listening to Take On Me while infiltrating a camp, having The Final Countdown while you are riding your horse with bullets flying all around you are just some of the great memories that the music in the game helps enhance. You can also add your own music, which is always a nice touch.

REPLAYABILITYTons of missions, 42 achievements, the upcoming multiplayer and the FOBs make this a game that you will play for at least 100 hours.

Overall, this is one of the most enjoyable open world games I've ever played. If you love the Metal Gear games, you will have a ton of fun with the excellent gameplay and multiple possibilities to complete missions. Even though the story isn't as strong as the other games, it still is very much interesting and it ties many loose ends. If you like open world games, third-person shooters, stealth games and Metal Gear, this is a must-buy.
Thank you Kojima for changing mine, and many other gamers' lives.

The first 2 hours of MGSV are incredible and possibly the best 2 hours of game that I have played in the last few years but that is where my love for the game ended. What followed were repetitive mission in an ‚Äúopen world‚Äù in and around a dusty mid 80s Afghanistan. Where are all the awesome cinematic pieces and incredible boss moments? Sure the character of Quiet is fun but there are literally only a handful of actual cut scenes in the game. Now I understand why this game has been praised so well by critics and fans and that is because of the breath of content there is available and  there is a big world to get lost in.

But personally I am cut from a different cloth and prefer more narrative in my games. I like a thrill ride that I can settle into enjoy every moment and at the end of 10 hours sit back and think about what I just experienced.

It also has to do with time, I am married with kids have a day job as a teacher and a night job as a games reviewer. I simply do not have time to devote many hours any more into one game.

So don‚Äôt get me wrong I can see how both games are good but I personally felt the repetitive and tedious nature of the majority of the missions in both games has soured me to the future of anything open world. I want story lines that have been carefully crafted not ones where I have to fill in the blanks.

SPOILERS ARE HIDDEN

Sadly, the game has been getting a lot of negative reviews (some ridicolous and childish just for the sake of complaining) even from people who have spent more hours than I have, but the truth is: gamers are generally mad over a missing ending (totally understandable) and a FEW cut content. But what about the rest? It's awesome.

The Phantom Pain is a new entry in the Metal Gear Solid series that tries something new, instead of being the same linear, cinema-like experience. It introduces open-world gameplay, base management seen in Peace Walker and interesting new mechanics. Plot-wise, it plays like a TV show, meaning that the narration is not involved in just one plot throughout the entire game.
The storyline is, once again, about the legendary soldier Big Boss, waking up after a nine-year coma. The story and other sub-plots are awesome in my opinion, but admittedly not necessary to the entire Metal Gear Solid saga.

reviewText:
TL;DR:
Gameplay: 9.5/10
Story: unfinished/10

Overall, I'm very satisfied with the game despite some its flaws and I recommend it for fans both of stealth games and third-person shooters. Even though it is said that people who have never played MGS before may play The Phantom Pain, I would strongly recommend getting acquainted with MGS 3, Portable Ops, and Peace Walker first.

The gameplay is where The Phantom Pain really shines. There are many games where you can either use stealth or annihilate everything, but the beauty of MGS V is the number of possible ways to do that. However, sometimes the game may feel kinda easy, especially when ignoring stealth and using a wide range of destructing weaponry and high tech gadgets.

The amount of content is amazing. It took me about 100 hours to beat the game, including a lot of side ops and some online play (FOB missions). Side ops are fun, but honestly they get a bit tedious after a while. Metal Gear Online 3 (the proper multiplayer component) isn't out yet, and with it, The Phantom Pain would be even better.

Many say the story is unfinished. Unfortunately, I must agree. Don't get me wrong: the existing story is great, but it's obviously lacking essential parts (mainly at the end). Still, it‚Äôs an early game in terms of overall chronology, so if you‚Äôve played the previous MGS games, then you already know what is going to happen.

reviewText:
To start with I am a very big fan of Metal Gear series as you can tell (At the time writing this review my username is Big Boss). I have played MG1, MG2, MGS1, MGS2, MG3 (my favourite), MGS Peace Walker, MGSV: Ground Zeroes and this one. I loved all of them and I was really looking forward playing this game.

It took me ~160hrs to finish this game, mostly because I was taking my sweet sweet time with it and I loved every second of it. The story (without spoilers) isn't what I expected, but after some time I will appreciate it more than I did at the first playthrough. Gameplay is amazing, I would say that it is the best gameplay I have ever seen in a game with third person perspective, they really did a wonderful job with that! This is an open world game and by that people would expect a living world with things happening in it. Well, not in this game. If you're not doing mission stuff, just exploring an open world, you will find a big, empty world with nothing to do.

If it comes down to story missions, you can replay them as much as you want, which is great, as some missions may be too difficult at the first time or maybe you want these S ranks in all the main missions. There's ton of weapons, gear and other gadgets. I still haven't got them all. Plus Konami is making FOB events where you can get pretty cool items or uniforms and colours by completing them which makes players keep playing the game.

Metal Gear Online 3, a online component of the game came out four months later on PC than it did on consoles. It came out on 13th Jan 2016 if a form of beta to be more specific. A week later it officially came out. I am really enjoying MGO3 and some people may be saying otherwise. It is a great FREE addition which make the game even more fun.

Please, do yourself a favour and buy this game if you love stealth games!

reviewText:
Nostalgia, stupidity, and hypocrisy are killing the top reviews of this game.

If the game is like its predecessors, people have a problem and go like 'OmG there's nothing new gonna kill maself'

If the game has something new, and is introducing elements with a breath of fresh air, people have a problem with that too and say 'OMG nothing lyk da old Matale GearSSS, wow pls gimme sum pills' I mean not exactly so but words to this extent.

Now, I see these people with hours and hours, even hundreds of hours of gameplay and then giving this game a negative review. I agree, yes, you are entitled to your opinion and have every right to rate this game how you wish, the publishers and developers will probably value it more than you value the game. But just because you have a whim, don't give it a NEGATIVE review, in my opinion, a negative review is a big thing, if a game lets me down but I still enjoy it enough to play it even a little, I just don't write a review at all. The only game I have given a negative review to is CoD Ghosts and we all know what a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•up that was.

Here we have a game which is so beautifully optimised, it runs smooth as a hot knife through butter. The gameplay is engaging, and to people who are saying that missions are repetitive probably don't see the little changes, the subtle nuances here and there as the game progresses and the behaviour of the enemies change, their armour and behaviour alter with your style of gameplay, which, as far as I am concerned is phenomenal. The little details here and there have won my heart, such as making your horse poopypie and being able to hear the enemy radio chatter and beong able to understand it only after you have extracted an interpreter.


Tldr? This is a real gem, or shall I say DIAMOND of a game...hehe..anyway yes, get it, don't go for the misleading reviews, the people who have given it a negative review despite having good reasons themselves cannot get enough of this game.

A Hideo Kojima game, but won't say ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you konami. Because I did give them my money to play this game, if you hate them so much then don't use their product, don't enter into a transaction between them, direct or indirect.. respect your own hate enough to hate truly.


Final edit- After completing the game and spending a lot of time on it and finishing it, I can finally say, I understand why it got the hate, I will honestly disclose that I am not a long standing MGS fan but..I can feel their pain...

Adding insult to injury was thqt there was no promise at all whether we will get a finished product eventually or not.

The ending is messed up, repeated missions on higher difficulty, cut content, a story which we get in bits and pieces, it has been rushed...but I will still not take away my recommendation, I had so much fun with the game and yes I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Is it really the end of Kojima's time with MGS? All signs point to yes, and there's a somberness with that realization.

The journey of Metal Gear reaches its magnum opus in terms of a fully realized stealth action open world game which, by far, manages these elements with incredible results. Open-world is a saturated phrase. Games employ it but often fill it up with mindless side activities and content which gets dull over time. Here though, the tactics you employ for every area and approach are always refreshing. You are rewarded for thinking carefully and planning ahead. The enemy adapts, forcing you to change. The seamless transition of stealth to action makes playing an absolute blast.

However, MGSV is a hodgepodge. To say it's a 10/10 is a misnomer. There are specific parts of this game which are outstanding. Gameplay, sound design, soundtrack, cinematics, character design, managing Mother Base, it's all quite incredible. There's SO MUCH CONTENT in this game, it's insanity. I finished Chapter 1, the first sequence of the game, after about 47 hours.

However, shortcomings do exist in smaller ways. Depending on who you are, you might find the story lighter. Kojima is going against the MGS formula, which has been routed in tradition for a long time. Thus, lengthy exposition and long cutscenes aren't as prevelant. The loss of end game content (in terms of side character plots) is unfortunate, but something which happens these days with massive titles. There's also a true ending point which may strike fans or players differently.

So, the major impairments are some plot weaknesses. However, this was a major undertaking for Kojima's team and really his first crack at the format. Despite what controversies come from plot and a few errors, the game will be remembered for years. If nothing else, it's absolutely the BEST stealth action game today. It makes many other stealth games feel painfully inferior.

reviewText:
Where to start?

My opinion on MGSV is pretty bipolar as on one hand I love this game but on the other I hate this game. As a long time MGS fan, I can't say this is the game I was expecting. I didn't read anything about MGSV before playing, and when I saw it was like Peace Walker, I was almost already disappointed. It grew on me over time but this feeling of just doing the same thing felt like a pointless grind. The MGS brand is legendary for what it did, and for this to be Kojima's final hooray for the series IS NOTHING BUT DISAPPOINTING. I have respect for Kojima in everything he has done in this game however, the story when shown is excellent (though REALLY rushed), the gameplay truly shines at times.

As you can see from my play count (if I played it after, I finish the game in 55 hours) this is not a short game at all. This can actually feel like a very repetitive game, side ops are repetitive, heli is repetitive, some main missions are repetitive and the waiting for something to develop is repetitive. I sometimes felt like I was forcing myself to play the game, hoping it can deliver but it just never does. Story is actually left unfinished in some areas, half of me believes this is Konami's fault. The game sets itself up for WAY MORE development but it just never happens.

I guess I have talked about the disappointing areas of the game, I guess I should mention what I liked about the game. The gameplay is excellent, really fun and surprising addicting to build your base to be as strong as possible. Before you go out on missions you can create your loadout of weapons and buddies. With the best buddy being D-Dog, I never felt an attactment with Quiet like most people, I actually don't know why people felt attacted to her, she doesn't do anything really. You're free to do whatever in MGSV, with the game being open world. It's exactly like Far Cry 2 in fact, if you haven't played that game, here is the best way to sum it up. You clear a guard post, you go away from the area and come back and all the guards are back. Every time you play, this is really frustating and what made me HATE playing Far Cry 2. So you could probably understand my frustation playing MGSV for 55 hours. When out in the field, you can extract soldiers for your own personally army. You can also extract wild animals, such as bears and sheep, this is pretty funny to see a few times, after a while you'll stop extracting these animals and just stick with people.

The story structure is in episode format, meaning it should opening and ending credits, this goes as far to literally spoil what is going to happen in the episode. For example: if you see Skull Face's name in the opening, you already know what is going to happen in the episode pretty much. I pretty much made it a requirement to look away during these moments at the start because I hated being spoiled in this way.

Too sum up:

Pros:
Gameplay is good
Base building is addicting
Side story stuff is better than main story but main story is the focus.
D-Dog
Acting is amazing
The game runs like a dream, one of the most optimised open world games I've ever played

Cons:
Episode structure is bad as it literally spoils what is going to happen in the mission
Story is disappointing
Under-developed second half
Hardly any bosses
Side ops are repetitive
Game feels too long because so much down time

Overall: This game is not the best MGS game ever made, in fact, I think this is the worse out of the whole series. However that isn't a bad thing, I still had fun during my time with the game, despite how it may look. I made some of the fun with repetitive side ops by doing them in different ways. See how fast I could do them as all of them are simliar in some ways.

Will I play this game again? No I won't, I think the whole it's like MGS2

reviewText:
So MGS V...

There are certainly a lot of things to complain about MGS V, particularly on PC, but how much each of the gripes matters depends a lot on where you're coming from. If you enjoyed 1-4 and are expecting the same sort of narrative and gameplay, you'll probably be disappointed; same for people expecting an FPS or min-maxing folks who are expecting a huge challenge even when using the best equipment and companions. That said, if you played Peace Walker and thought, man, I really wish this had been on a console / PC instead of PSP it would have been great, this game fills that niche (minus the solid narrative of PW).

I could write a lot more, but I'm still kinda dazed from playing the game for 40 hours over the span of two days. I think that sort of says it all for me at least. This game isn't for everyone or whatever everyone expected, but it certainly is for me.

Its right out unfinished, you can literally feel the content that is not there like a phantom pain. Such a lust for irony.

From the storytelling of prologue and chapter one you can feel that they story should have contain at least 5 chapters, and I believe it was what planned for at first. Because we are promised to see how Big Boss turned evil from the legendary soldier of Outer Heaven  to merciless tyranny of Zanzibar Land, we were promised a story that will tie lose ends. None that happens in the game.

My theory is that Konami pull Kojima off from the game after first chapter and finished the second chapter without him thus explains why the second chapter was such a mass and unfinished, and today we found out that a whole 3th chapter is missing including the unfinished 2nd chapter. As a conclusion Konami just wanted to release the game and get the hell out of AAA game industry.

We have no idea what exactly went down during development between Konami and Kojima Productions and the fallout that ensured. For all we know the game wasn't complete and needed more time, but Konami rushed for a September 1st release. On the other hand, Hideo Kojima had 5 years and 80 million dollars to make this game, and he failed to deliver a complete product. But again, we don't know what happened during the development of this game.

reviewText:
No Spoilers!This game is a mixed bag for me.

I applaud the game in many ways. The open world design and integration of either stealth or going loud worked out in the end. You have freedom of choice to tackle any situation in the game such as dropping a supply drop on an enemy's head, which knocks them out, to approaching a base/outpost with a tank and completely overthrowing soldiers. The gameplay is miles ahead of the previous games. The soundtrack is also very good. Compared to the previous games soundtrack, it's not the best, but it is still quite good. Voice acting in the game is also another plus. While some will disagree with me, and while I am overly familiar to David Hayter voicing the main character, Kiefer Sutherland did a very good job. I will say in some parts he sounds drunk but I don't expect you to exit the game because of that.

Now for the negatives. I both loved and hated this game, but in the end I left disgusted. I, and many others, will repeat on how this game is potentially one of the worst Metal Gear Solid games. So much of the dialogue from certain characters seem so forced and unnecessary. The game is not finished. This game is incomplete and it ends with you having more questions than answers(in a bad way). The last few missions are repeats, and are just on harder" difficulties. The side ops and story feel repetitive and you begin to feel like you've been playing the same mission over and over and over again. I could have looked past the incomplete game if the story was anywhere near the previous games. Again

Well everybody probably has already played this game so a review at this point it‚Äôs not much of a use but I still need to write it mainly for two reasons:
-One, because I can‚Äôt stand fanboys and game review sites giving it 10/10 reviews with 0,1 hours of gameplay and calling it a ‚Äúmasterpiece‚Äù. If this game is a masterpiece then what the bloody hell where MGS1 and MGS3? I‚Äôm a big fan of the series, I‚Äôve played every game except PW but I can‚Äôt just shut down my brain in order to satisfy the little man inside me or satisfy my pockets‚Ä¶
-Second, if they ever going to release a MGS game again I don‚Äôt want it to be anything like MGS5. This, in my honest opinion, should be made clear to the developer, the publisher and especially to Kojima himself by true fans of the series.
So let me get this straight first. This is not a bad game, it can actually be quite fun at times but it is not an MGS game and it‚Äôs not a complete game. More analytically:
Graphics Graphics in this game are OK, nothing exceptional but not bad either. Also the game engine seems well optimized. I have an old GTX660ti and it runs smoothly on ‚ÄúExtra High‚Äù setting (the only one I set to high was the shadows).
Sound In the music department I am probably a little biased since I dislike almost everything from the 80s and all cassette tapes from the game where 80s tracks. Also the game doesn‚Äôt have a single memorable track/theme. The only good thing was that I could put, as a helicopter sound, the theme from Snake Eater and remember how freaking awesome that game was.
Story/Characters Voice acting in the game is not bad on its own but the way they portray the characters is so much divorced from the story of the previous games that made the characters entirely foreign to me.
-Snake in the previous games was a very talkative guy who would make funny remarks here and there. He was a combination of Snake Plissken and Indiana Jones. In MGS5 he barely talks and when he does talk he sounds like he suffers from some kind of depression. It‚Äôs unbelievable. Even in MGS4 which was way more emotionally charged game compared to the previous ones, Snake still retains a cheerful attitude. Did Sutherland got paid in a dollars per word type of contract or something like that? Also his voice was so distant to Hayters voice that only amplified the fact that MGS5 Snake* is not the character that we grew up with and loved. (*Don‚Äôt give me that crap that he is a different character because we already have the same situation with Liquid Ocelot in MGS4)
-With Ocelot it‚Äôs even worse. How on earth did the narcissistic, sadistic, smartass, over the top character of the previous games became the voice of reason in this game?
-And Quiet. Well what can one say about Quiet. Who needs character development when you have boobs? Seriously I‚Äôm starting to take the side of those half-crazed ‚Äúfeminist‚Äù people here.
Scene -> Mist incoming
Me -> All worked up for a fight
Scene -> Female skull snipers that look badass incoming
Me -> ‚ÄúOh boy oh boy this is gonna be tough‚Äù
Scene -> Gros plan on female skull sniper‚Äôs ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•
Me -> ‚ÄúWhat the‚Ä¶‚ÄùThis game puts a new low for female videogame characters. I enjoy seeing female breasts as much as the next guy but this is ridiculous. You can have sexual characters but put them into context (like EVA from MGS3 for example) don‚Äôt just throw breasts and asses here and there.
I just can‚Äôt understand it. It would be logical if they hired someone else and not Kojima to make the game and make these characters not resembling in the least their former selves but this is a Kojima game‚Äù. In fact it does say so in the beginning and end of EVERY MISSION! Seriously this has to be the most pretentious thing I have ever seen from a creator. Imagine if Tarantino or Scorsese instead of putting credits in the beginning and end of a film started putting credits after each scene.
‚ÄúYeap that‚Äôs mine‚Ä¶yes that one too‚Ä¶oh this one also‚Ä¶‚Äù
Ridiculous‚Ä¶
Kojima pull yourself together man.
Gameplay This game offers a dumbed down version of MGS mechanics. This is both good and bad.
-It‚Äôs bad because the game doesn‚Äôt offer a challenge at all. I S ranked the missions in my 2-3 retries at most. On the other hand Extreme difficulties in the previous games where hard to finish even for veterans of MGS series and stealth games.
-The good about it is that due to the strange decision to make it an ‚Äúopen world‚Äù game it would have been a very unpleasant game to play otherwise and this is another point I want to emphasize. Why oh why did you make it an ‚Äúopen world‚Äù game. It‚Äôs not even a real open world game. It‚Äôs just open terrain with hardly any interiors (again strange for an MGS game) filled with enemies here and there and hardy anything worthwhile to do. Someone would expect interaction with villagers
date: Afghan and African little cities where you could help liberate from enemies and things like that. Calling this game open world is false-advertisement. The only in-game reason for this pseudo open world concept to exist seems to be in order to make the game needlessly long. Why do I have to watch a helicopter ride every time I start a mission

reviewText:
Just as a standalone game, this is pretty good, although it has some faults.

The stealth and combat is the best it's been in the series, although it falls short on things like level design and mission variety.

However, as an MGS game, this is probably the biggest dissappointment I've had in years. Really crappy story. It has some nice concepts but none of them are fleshed out like they should be. Cutscenes are few and far between. Instead you get TONS of cassette tapes which are honestly pretty boring to listen to. Cut content. The entire last chapter was cut from the game. The game ends out of the blue, leaving tons of loose strings you want to see played out.

Ground zeroes is a more satisfying MGS title than the Phantom Pain, as sad as that sounds. Metal Gear Solid is my favorite game series, and the MGS fan in me has to downvote this entry.

reviewText:
MGSV is, hands down, the best of the franchise gameplay wise, and a contender for best game all around as well.

TPP takes a departure from previous titles (bar Peace Walker) in the sense that is no longer a linear, cutscene-plagued game. Cutscenes are less prominent than in previous games (except for the prologue, but it's expected for the introduction to ANY game to have plenty of cutscenes anyway), and missions are split. This means, no longer games where a single score was given to the whole playthrough. Each mission has it's individual score, and they can be redone if you're not sastified with the result, albeit with a reward reduction (half the GMP [money] reward).

Main missions have the mandatory objectives to fulfill, and then hidden ones which are optional to complete but add up (either by score, or with personeel/gear). The game grants you total freedom on how to complete them. If the mission says Eliminate x target"

reviewText:
This game had moments where it shined...and a LOT of moments where it fell completely flat.  I'll just make a list without trying to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out over how I really feel about this game

Pros:
-Story starts off Solid...
-Open world is interesting at first
-Graphics are great
-Animations are superb, maybe the best out there right now
-Guns feel good, really great aiming with M+K

Cons:
-Story starts off Solid, but quickly turns into Liquid ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•
-Stealth is extremely simplistic and the game is very easy unless you gimp yourself (Even then it's still easy).  Durability on supressors does nothing at all except become an annoyance as the player could easily call in a supply drop for a new one/hold up enemies/use CQC.  AI is also ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and doesn't become better until Mission 30ish for some odd reason.
-Open World adds NOTHING to this game, can't explore beyond certain areas during missions.  Could have just broken up the open world into levels and made the game a linear experience and you'd get the same result.
-Buddies are OP as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.  As much as I love D-Dog, he marks every enemy for me which I don't like.  As for Quiet, as much as I don't mind fanservice, that's the only reason she's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing in game.  She's one of the cringiest characters I have ever seen.
-Kiefer Sutherland is woefully underused.  He has some amazing moments in this game and I think hardcore Hayter fans can even admire his work, but Kojima decided it would be a good idea to make an already established character a self-insert protagonist meaning he doesn't talk much, just listens.
-Twist is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing obvious, Kojima dropped the hint way too many times to the point where the player could figure it out before beating the PROLOGUE.

I'm hoping I'll dump 10 more hours into this game, but even after using Cheat Engine to experience the various different weapons and gadgets, the game just isn't fun.  I bought into the hype and thought this game looked excellent from the trailers, but I'm just going to say this now.

Whatever trailers you watched of MGSV, they do NOT REPRESENT THE FINAL GAME AT ALL.

About MGO: Played maybe an hour of Bounty Hunter, felt cheap and a complete unnecessary addition to the game.  Imagine the resources that could have gone to making the Singleplayer actually good if the MP didn't exist.

The phantom pain refers to the lingering pain felt due to the lack or loss of a limb; this is much like the pain felt due to lack of a cohesive plot. Kojima next leveled us once again.

I enjoyed the game for the first 5 or so hours. The open world infitration was a cool idea and I really liked how I could approach the enemy base from multiple angles. However I soon realized that there really isn't very much variety in the missions. The enemy bases just felt generic and so similar to each other. Maybe this is a problem with the open world design. The world is basically a bunch of outposts and bases connected with roads and empy land in between. While the older games were linear, they had better level design and areas actually felt different and unique. Practically every mission follows the same format. Kaz will recieve a job from some random employer and assign you to go to this location and elimate/extract the target, the choice is yours. After you complete a mission Kaz will talk to you over the radio about what he learned about that mission; this is where the plot" advances. It seemed like most of the early missions are just random jobs that just so happen to vaguely relate to cipher/skull face. The early missions advance the plot extremely slowly and the later missions just throw all of it at you.

Chapter 1 ends and you're greeted with an unfinshed second half. The majority of the chapter 2 missions are just repeats of chapter 1 missions but with harder difficulty modifiers. Other than that

reviewText:
I do not recommend this game unless you are fan of the series like me, then go ahead and grab it (not at full price).

The story line is pretty poor compared to the other Metal Gear titles despite it talks about key events.

SPOILERs :

- Mainly the first meeting between Big Boss and one of his sons.
- There are only few bosses which you can't defeat in a regular fight unfortunately.. the story dispose of them and you can only watch a cutscene (this was really disappointing).
- There is a group of minibosses which you may not fight as well. In most of the cases you can simply avoid or decide to not fight them.. and the story still goes on.
- There are key characters in game which unfortunately you will never see in action, all rotates around you busy in a lonely journey to collect stuff from the maps (there are only 2 maps).
- There are 50 missions of which around 39 as true missions for the story, the others are some of the previous lifted to a higher level of difficulty.

< Lastly Mission 51 doesn't exist : the game has been ripped apart from its true final.. thankfully you still have a boss to fight at the end (guess what? a Metal Gear) but the fight between Big Boss and his son has been reduced to a mind war..>

END.



Its an open world game hence is very repetitive (like 3-4 tipe of missions that you repeat indefinitely) with some cutscenes here and there to remember you are actually following a story.
Your main goal, aside for completing the game, is to create a base for yourself and expand it as good as you can, this too indefinitely.

WARNING: FOB system: after a while you will have the possibility to create a FOB (another base far away) with the difference that this one may be attacked by other players (human players). Yes, you may attack theirs as they can with yours.
If this happen the player which succeeds in a FOB infiltration may steal part of your -resources -equipments and (or kill) -personnel that you have collected in game to craft your bases.
FOBs are not needed to complete the game so if you don't like this side stay away from it.
Little tip: seems you don't get attacked if you don't attack (sort of defensive mechanics for this system).

reviewText:
Okay, I'm writting this at the 40% mark of the game, having put over 50 hours in. I still have yet to complete the main story... and when I thought I did, the game slapped me Chapter 2.

THE PROS
-Fantastic visuals that run well on sub-par machines.
-The enviroments are massive and widely varient.
-You can FEEL the 80 million dollars poured into the game's development.
-The controls are slicker than ever before, polished from Ground Zeroes.
-Forget all about how short Ground Zeroes is. There's well over 60 hours of pure gameplay waiting in Phantom Pain. Not even counting multiplayer.
-The game has multiplayer. Two types even. One is up and running now and the second type will be up and running later in the year.
-There's an overwhelming amount of weapons and gadgets that are useful and fun.
-Realtime weather with day and night cycles not only look amazing but also keeps you on your toes as it changes your gaming experience.
-This is the smartest stealth related AI I've ever had the pleasure of being frustraited by.
-You get your own bases to develope, color, staff, deffend, and slap a custom made logo on.
-This time, Snake isn't always alone. You have several support characters that bring new fun to infiltration and fire fights.
-Feel like breaking from stealth for some serious gun play? That's fun too!

THE CONS
-It's Hideo Kojima's Last Metal Gear game. For realz this time. Man, that makes me sad.
-Microtransactions. Need I say more? It's skummy to put an extra pay system on stuff that's already in the game or to speed up constructing materials. Granted, it's not invasive and stays in the menus. You can also go quite a ways as I have while not feeling punished for not spending extra money.
-Credits, credits, credits! Spoilers in opening credits too! There's 40+ main missions and every one plays opening a closing credits. I think it's likely Kojima's middle finger to Konami for trying to scrub his name so much.
-The checkpoints are often unforgiving. There are times when you can loose 30-45 minutes because you made one bad move. If you were carefully infiltrating a base and messed up once... guess what? You get to start all over.
-As smart as the AI is, there are still some bugs. Prepare to wait for your helicopter. A lot.
-Konami. If they continue to crap on their big gaming industry in favor of cellphone games and pachinko machines, I see MGSV as the last game to purchase from them.

THE CONCLUSION
Buy this game. It's fantastic and is worth every cent. 'Cept the microtransactions. Don't buy into that. Maybe buy actual DLC, but not microtransactions. Seriously.

**POST BEATING THE GAME CONCLUSION (NO SPOILERS)**

THE NEW PROS
-MGO is up and is fun.
-New items have been added.

THE NEW CONS
-The ending has holes, showing that Konami rushed the game.
-If you choose to play the game offline so you don't have to deal with other players, the game now taxes your GMP (in game points) and heavily caps your storage limits. So imagine if Call of Duty decided to take away your bullets in single player for not playing the multi-palyer.
-Now there's expensive FOB insurance that costs REAL MONEY. That's right, you spend real money to place insurance on your fake video game base.
-DLC horse armor is back.
-Snake's signature tux that has been included in every single MGS game is now in this one... as DLC because Konami wants all that fan money.

It's getting VERY HARD to not take away my thumb up right now.
