reviewText:
no spoilers.

I really love this game, and I think it's probably one of my favorite games of the 2015 year. That being said, it is also pretty flawed, mostly because it just doesn't feel complete. Most likely because it wasn't completed.

A lot of people say there's virtually no story in this game, and I just don't think that's true. Chapter 1 feels like an entire Metal Gear Solid story that's much easier to understand. There is a lot of missions in between that don't exactly make the story flow, but I would really hope you'd like the Metal Gear gameplay in general because this game offers you a lot of it. I actually even told myself and my girlfriend that we should just consider Chapter 1 the end of the game and not expect anything else, cuz we would have been fine and happy with that.

But then, as you keep playing Chapter 2, you get sucked into the story. It seems like more things are going to happen and that things are going to get solved or change a little. Even though I knew it probably wouldn't go anywhere, I still fell into it, and its just a shame. The story builds you up to all sorts of things, but then just is over out of nowhere. Like it was just really very incomplete and very unfullfilling. I almost wonder why they didn't just cut the entire chapter 2 out, but I suppose that would be a decent amount of content wasted. This is a pretty big flaw and I really don't blame anyone for disliking the game because of this, but I find myself able to look past it since I enjoyed the gameplay and Chapter 1 so much.

To add on to the gameplay, the open world is actually really cool. I do realize that everything between guardposts and things like that is kind of dead ground, but it makes the world feel a lot bigger and part of something. My only complaint is it's just not fun to travel around. Most open world games give you a fun way to travel from place to place. Take Saints Row or GTA, you can drive around quickly and run people over or just narrowly avoid traffic while trying to get from mission to mission as quick as you can. In this game, you can't really do that. If you try to drive through an outpost, you'll almost certainly be spotted and lose a tiny bit of heroism for it, which isn't much of a problem. But then, they tell EVERY outpost and guard to be on the lookout for an intruder, so every base is now on alert.

Traveling around just feels like a chore and you aren't rewarded well for doing it. All those complaints aside, I still really appreciate the open world aspect of the game and love that I have a big open Metal Gear world to do whatever weird Metal Gear things I want to do.

I really recommend this game to fans of the series, or at least people who love the gameplay of it. The second chapter story is clearly not finished and I don't think it will be, but chapter 1 is great. There's only maybe 3 bosses in the game too, which is a bit of a flaw depending on how you feel about Metal Gear bosses. I'd say it's worth full price, but it'll for sure be going on sale to 40 bucks and below more often and on different sites, so maybe look out for that.

Very  very fun game, but also very flawed. Tons of content, but at the same time, it's unfinished.

I really, really, really love this game. But it is not without flaw.
The gameplay is smooth, unique, and breaths new life into the series in in it's final bow. It makes for a complex, yet easy-to-learn experience that transitions into open world very well. I absolutely cannot wait for Metal Gear Online.
I like how it's also clearly a Metal Gear Game, and indeed keeps the same tones of large scale, atmospheric, eerie enviorments with a link to actual history and technology that, while way too advanced is still somehow fitting.

The gameplay, atmosphere, and the music are all great. Definitely enough to make this one of my top games of the year.

FOB needs to be fixed. I really don't care how, just...fix the cheaters and improve the system. Make it something people WANT to do, not something they feel they HAVE to. It should be fun...not an inconvenient pain.

reviewText:
The games was supposed to consist of 3 acts.
The only interesting of those is act 1. Act 2 is pretty much a joke and act 3 was simply cut from the game. People who haven't played the game may wonder, how act 2 (according to me and a lot of other reviews) can possibly be that bad. The thing is, it's not really an act at all. It conists of 19 missions, where as only ~7 of those are actually new missions, the other 12 are straight up copy/paste from Act 1, with an extra restriction added to make the mission harder. They didn't even bother to change the cutscenes/talking for those missions, so it doesn't fit in the story line at all.
Act 1 however, was in my opinion really amazing. The amount of content is incredible, and it just keeps growing the further you get into the act. New weapons, new functions, new teamstations, a new map and i could continue, i think you get the point.
I simply can't imagine how good this game would've been if act 2 and 3 had been as good as the first, an easy 10/10.

Another thing people complain about, is the game being repetitive. The game contains 150 sideops, 50 main missions and an infiltration system called FOB. This is a lot of content, and repition may seem impossible to avoid in the long run. I would like to say however, that the game offers variation, it just doesn't force it. You can try out all the hundreds of items in the game, or you can play with the same setup all the way, that's up to you. This is not the only thing people find repetitive in the game, but changing your setup once in a while certainly helps. I'm like 120 hours into the game and still entertained, i'd say thats $50 well spend.

TL;DR:
Act 1 is amazing
Act 2 is a joke
Act 3 was cut from the game
The game offers variation but doesn't force it
Game can last for VERY long if you're entertained by it
If you're a big MGS fan and care a lot about the story, you'll probably be disappointed. If you just want to have fun and play around, i can surely recommend this.

Please ask if you have any further questions :)

reviewText:
What can I say although this is the longest I have spent with any of the MGS games it is the one I would recommend the least. This being that I have no drive to complete this game. I am 80odd hours in and have grown bored of the gameplay. Bored with the repetition, When I say repetition let me clairify how bad it is, the game consists of two Chapters. The first chapter consists of 25 or so missions loosely tied together with a weak, easily the weakest MGS storyline to date, The second chapter consists of around  25 or so missions, around 7 of which are continuations of the rather weak story while the rest are just repeats of Chapter ones missions only with new game plus style, make it a bit more difficult for the player parameters.

You can tie in some other boring features, the game tries to be gritty, child soldiers, now that's a touchy subject, oh but you can't kill any of them or it's instant mission failure, a few tortures scenes that make little sense in their context, a story that is just boring at best, I actually muted a long winded speech being done by one of the main characters so I could watch the Matrix Reloaded, that's how bad it can get.

What else, well the FOB online aspect is clearly an integral part to developing late game items but the actual missions are tedious, repetious and either sit in the walk through without ever seeing an enemy or encounter fully speak super aware enemies at every corner and it very obvious that the pay to progress mecahnic is tied in to this aspect of the game, either that or be ready to grind, the same 40 or so sub, non story missions. Yes it does sound like you get a lot of missions but really they get repetitive quickly and if you stuck purely to story missions you could blast through this game in 10 hours easy.

So what else, The AI is weird, some times it is abusively stupid, other times you can fire a silenced sniper rifle from a unseen vangte point and the enemy will ping your location in an instant. Watching guard patrols, like in the old MGS is pointless since all missions turn in to tranq enemy and fulton him away so he won't be a pain later. The weapon choice is large and varied on the surface but most weapons just end up being unused since the tactics for infiltration all end up using the same two or three weapons.

This game has the most content, the longest potential play time and the most weapons of any MGS along with the online aspects but it is easily the weakest game of the series, The story is poor, the equipment is varied in apperance  but usually pretty pointless when used and the enemy AI is either comically stupid or frustratingly difficult the game doesn;t even have any really decent boss fights either and worst of all it is clear that the game is unfinished, that aspects of it (the entire second chpater) where padded out and rushed to get the game out before Konami decided to pull up it's gaming roots and give up on gaming.

A tragic end to what was once a great franchise, ending on an unfinished unloved whimper rather than going out in an all singing all exploding song and dance.... but at least you can pay Konami for the privelage of having them insure your fake FOB resource!!!

reviewText:
37 hours into the game and I'm only 27% complete. This game is honestly one of the best I've played in a long time.

I haven't paid attention to the metal gear story as this is one of the first I've played since I was about 13. I'll be honest, the story is hard to follow for me. Maybe it's because I'm just stupid and not understanding some of it, but it is a bit janky compaired to others stories. Right from the start it grabs you though. It peaks your interest and shows you how beautiful this game is graphically. You're quickly coming to your senses as to whats happening around you. The voice acting pulls you in. The facial motions make you feel like its real.

Occasionally some of the story missions feel like filler ones, like you go here and get one guy then you're done. Maybe I'm just misunderstanding the story again though. However when there are cutscenes it is intense. The story really progresses. Something that is known as a side quest, like getting a new buddy (follower) feels like its part of the main mission. Your buddys will be in cut scenes with you.

This game is challenging. It is honestly one of the hardest games I've ever played. I'm not talking about mechanics. Gameplay is straight foward and unique at the same time. Play stealthfull or charge in there calling in heli support while firing your light machine gun or hiding behind your riot shield. What I'm talking about is your focus. You activly need to listen to things or your mission could go sideways. Without spoiling anything, deep into chapter 1 something happens that you need to control or else your crew could start dying. It is not a mission. There are no hints. It is up to you to find out what is causing this to happen. If you don't, bad things could happen, but you could still go on without solving this. Little things like that make this game intense. They make you express your mental skill in acomplishing things. It's not just mindlessly pressing buttons on your keyboard or controller like many adults may think.

In January of 2016 there is suppose to be a multiplayer component coming (Not FOB missions, I mean like team death match and all that). I played metal gear solid 4 and the online component for that was absolutely amazing. I had never played anything like it. I expect it to be great.

If you're on the fence about this game, buy it. It is one of the few games on this market that is worth the money you pay for it. And please buy it from a source that will help benefit this company. Kojima really deserves the support.

TL;DR: One of the best games this generation. Buy it.

Edit: I've finished it. Took about 55 hours total. Not 100% complete but beat the story. No Spoilers, but it was disappointing. Very generic and left you feeling a Phantom Pain". Not very happy with this in that respect.

That being said

reviewText:
I didn't want to do this.
I avoided reviewing this game.

But in out of respect to my favorite franchise of all time,who firstly introduced me that sometimes even the video games can be more then just video games... More then a simple entertainment so you can kill the time in the day off.
They can be ever more then that,they can become a piece of art.
That classical art of perfection is called Metal Gear Solid for me.

So where to begin with this one?
I imagine that seeing that big red THUMBS DOWN you immediatly clicked disagree on my review,haven't you?
That's cool,i respect that... because everyone have their own opinion but all i asked is to read my review to the end.

First of all... I LOVE METAL GEAR SOLID FRANCHISE. (i even love this one despise it's flaws)
I am a mgs junkie for years... and will be for years to come.

My first introduction to this series was way back on my ps1 era.
In that 1998... a golden age of playstation.
Back then i coudn't even comprehended the severe complexity of this game.
,,Stealth?,, .... WTF is stealth?
I need to stealth in order to get pass those guards?
The first game storyline and advance gameplay for its age grapled like a leech on me.
After beating it i coudnt get my minds of it for years and after seeing first gameplay of MGS2 i think i even wet my pants a little bit.
Those graphics,the sound,the SOLID SNAKE,stealth and complexity n mixture of the storyline that back then i barely knew.
I played and beaten every single game in this franchise.
Kojima made me joy,cry.... being tense at times and then cry some more.
Characters i coud never forgot.
Sniper Wolf,Ocelot,The Boss,Entire Cobra Unit,Twin Snakes and finnaly the man we're playing right now... BIG BOSS.
MGS was made out of cheese dialogues,overly complex storyline that woud make your head explode and beautifuly cinematic made cutscenes that woud never end.... but HEY!
That was exactly what attached me to this franchise over all these years.
That was the main symbol of MGS franchise!
That was true MGS to its core.
Character with a name cheese as SNAKE woud never gotten his title of ,,one of the greatest video game characters of all time,, if it werent for Kojima's corny writting and action/like hero portrayel of him.
For me the real biggest flaw of this franchise was that it was always a playstation exclusive.
So it atracted only a specific kind of a community.
Another flaw is that after first and second metal gear solid game it continued to favorite it's fanbase over wider audience.
You really needed to know WTF is going on in the sequals if you wanted to achieve that big effect on suprise and emotional roller coaster Kojima was driving us fans along all these years.
This kind of game used to appeal only to a certain audience of players.
Those who hated it's long-overly dragged out cutscenes with overly-complexed storyline haven't sticked along to the very end.
But i cannot explain how rewarding it was to never get out of that roller coaster drive.
If you immerse yourself in it,and wait till the very end i cannot explain how rewarding it will be.
I can honestly admit that there is no game out there that made me cry like a little sissy as MGS did. :)
I litteraly took few pills after the ending of MGS4. (no joke :P)

Which finaly brings us back to THE PHANTOM PAIN.
An final installment for this franchise.... a final chapter for our unanswered questions.
I watched the dev for this game over the years now... bitting my nails every new year to come.
I simply coudn't wait for it any longer!
With every new update and progress it started to looked more and more unrealistic for me.
It simply looked way to good to be true. Part of it was even the fault on my way abow the sky expectations of it!
I expected the greatest game yet ever to be released.
Watching YONGYEA's videos 24/7 for new updates about it.
The gameplay demos along with the rest of presentation looked absolutily stunning!

Finaly septembar first came! Aaaaaaand.... ?!
Has it been everything i hoped for?
Is this the new best gem of this generation?

Frankly,for me as a deep (wont use word ,,hardcore,, it seems kinda dumb) fan it was kind a huge letdown.
Is it a bad game because of that.

FAR FROM IT !
It is still an amazing game!
You heard me, i'm thumbing it down and still saying it is an amazing game!
So what's the problem?

Yes,the V is an outstanding game on its own... it's just not an oustanding METAL GEAR SOLID game.
For what was promised and what delivered after it's release.... i cannot say it is worth the full price of it.

The good:

Superb graphics for this gen and amazingly well execuded gameplay.
You coud inflirtate the enemy compounds in any way you like,it rly deppends on your own imagination which is cool.
The soundtrack is also great... it kinda makes you dig that 80s vibe again.

reviewText: I feel very conflicted about this game. Like other metal gear fans I was really eager to play this. The game started out great. The first 90 minutes were absolutely incredible. I rarely felt scared about the consequences of getting caught in the first scene than I have in any other game. It felt like there was so much on the line and the emenies were merciless. The first 90 minutes crescendos and by the time the opening is finished I was exausted. I was ready to take a step back. After the opening my imagination was going wild thinking about all of the other experiences that I would experience like the first 90 minutes of gameplay. This feeling kept me going for about 10-15 hours when I finally realized there would be nothing resembling that opening again. Once I realized this I could not get myself to extract another enemy from a base or gain some special intel. So this is the problem I have with this game. For players like me, there is very little reward for finishing a mission.  In past Metal Gear Solid games I felt rewarded after a difficult mission with a captivated cutscene sequence. The cutscenes in past games would suck me into the MGS universe. It made me feel like This is happening." This game does not do that for me.  A mission just ends and then you get a cassette tape to listen to. That's really it. Then you get briefed again. Go on mission. Repeat 50 times.\n\nThe game does feel really good though. The controls are tight and responsive. The game looks great. The gameplay is really good at first but wears me down after a while becuase there is little variety once you develop your own playstyle. reviewText: This is a tough review for me, as I've been a fan of the Metal Gear series since the first Metal Gear was released on the Nintendo Entertainment System. Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain is a prequel to the original Metal Gear and the 11th in the overall series, according to wikipedia. With that being said, the character of Snake is not voiced by David Hayter as has been the case with previous Metal Gear games, due to injuries suffered prior to the immediate events of The Phantom Pain. Snake, also known as Big Boss, is voiced by Kiefer Sutherland, and does not speak a lot during the game.\n\nSeveral support characters familiar to those who follow the series such as; Ocelot Revolver, Kazuhira Miller, and Eli, to name a few, are also back, along with new characters. The gameplay is more modernized, and open world than previous installments, but this change also makes the game feel differently from others in the franchise. The Storyline is interesting, and keeps your attention, but honestly I miss the feel of previous Metal Gear Games in the series, so my review may be a little biased. As a stand-alone game without any introduction to previous titles in the series it stands on it's own two feet. If you are new to the series, you will find the gameplay to be pretty straightforward, to those who enjoyed the series, you will find aspects of the game to be similar, but notice a difference when you play. Overall it's not a bad game at all. The graphics are beautiful. I hope you enjoy the game.

Metal Gear Solid V - The Phantom Pain		* 8/10
It's very difficult to rate this game. I Loved it, I hated it, and then I loved it again at the point that I sadistically completed it at 100%. Nonetheless I can't help but disagree with those Reviewers that rate it 10/10 or even 9/10. Don't misunderstand me, I really wish I could rate it 10/10 but I must honestly say 8 is a more balanced rate because this chapter is not a mediocre product but it's not flawless, nor it can compare the previous chapters (which can all be rated 9 or above...).

reviewText:
My negative review of the shameless Konami cash grab that is Ground Zeroes was easily my worst received review ever. But I can happily say that The Phantom Pain is a huge improvement over it, so maybe this one will be more popular.

For those that tire of my typically long-winded reviews, I'll get this out of the way up front in just a couple of sentences: I would definitely recommend anybody that's a fan of open world or stealth games purchase this. It's a phenomenally fun, addictive experience. BUT! It does have some pretty severe flaws, some returning from Ground Zeroes, and some that have always been present in Kojima's work.

Now, onto the fun part! Ramble time!

The graphics are really solid, once again. I'm coming off spending about 150 hours in Witcher 3, and though this game doesn't quite compete with that one on a graphical level (nothing does, honestly), it still looks really freaking good. The Fox engine's lighting and particle effects are stunning. And it runs amazingly on PC. I'm holding 60fps solid at 1440p. No complaints here.

The best part about this game, though, is how addictive the open world progression is. That's something that always seems to draw me in. As a minimap completionist games like this, the Assassin's Creed series, and Witcher 3 are absolutely my bread and butter. I hated how limited Ground Zeroes was. The entire game felt like continuous retreading of common ground. It bored me. This game is a step completely in the opposite direction. The base building, the weapon and equipment progression, the buddy system... It all tickles my fancy. These's so much to do here, and it's hard to put down. It's an experience that will melt away the hours of your day.

I do have some notable criticisms of the game. Some will fall on deaf ears, as Kojima fans love his trademark weirdness, but some are just run-of-the-mill dated Japanese game design issues that I'm seeing more and more frequently these days as the Japanese development scene falls further behind the modern Western scene.

I dove heavily on the dated control scheme in my Ground Zeroes review, so I won't say it all again here. Instead I'll summarize and just say the control scheme is dated and unintuitive. That's an especially bad thing for a stealth game, because you need to be able to react without thinking if you turn a corner and run into a guard. Too many times early in the game I'd have to actually think about what button did what, and a few times I even had to look up the controls to find out what I needed to know: Example: How the hell do you sprint on horseback? Oh

reviewText:
People need to stop judging this game based on how much time they sank into the game. I played this game for nearly 50 hours and while I enjoyed it for a while, I realized how much of a chore the game actually is and how there isn't actually as much content as there seems to be. This game is Far Cry with a dumb anime plot (emphasis on the dumb part).

First off the open world, while it controls very well and looks very pretty, is very empty and uninspired. The game is set in Afghanistan and Africa, both which are apparently war torn though I never saw any battles between the Soviets or Mujahadeen or between the African PMCs and natives. That's because in each map, you only encounter the Soviets or the African PMCs and nobody else save for the occasional POW. Compare this to a game like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. where there are roughly 5 big factions that roam the world and interact with each other as well as the player, and that game came out 8 years ago. In fact the open world actually detracts from the story by making it feel so disjointed. Maybe if each story mission felt like it had closure like a tv episode (which is what it was supposed to be mimicking I guess), it wouldn't be so bad.

Next the amount of side quests and missions, while there are plenty of each, are all rinse and repeat and the side quests are completely forgettable. This is what they call filler and it's nowhere near as good as the kind they put in twinkies. The story missions themselves mostly consist of assassinating targets and extracting prisoners. But the assassinations almost always turn into extractions as well because the targets are so much better than the usual cannon fodder for your mother base. The actual story missions are usually these kinds of missions as well but instead of being able to fulton out the target, you'll have to carry them to the chopper (what a tweest). What's most disappointing is the lack of boss fights. There are maybe 3 legitimate boss fights in the entire game and they aren't nearly as good as the ones in previous games. Remember fighting Psycho Mantis or The End or The Sorrow? Remember how unique and memorable those boss fights were? You're not going to get anything like that from MGSV.

Now let's talk about the other important part of this game, the story. If you don't want to be spoiled, here's the tl; dr. It sucks and it fails to close the gap between Peace Walker and Metal Gear (MSX). You know, the very thing this game was supposed to do? The reason this plot is dumb is because of some big twists and lazy explanations so if you don't want the story spoiled, look back at my tl; dr. So the biggest problem I have with this game is that (spoiler alert), you're not playing as Big Boss. Venom Snake is actually you, the player who happens to be the medic on the chopper in Ground Zeroes. I get what it's trying to say, anyone can be Big Boss but that plot was already done before in MGS2 and it was much better executed. Here, not only is it dumb in the game's universe, but it makes everything you've accomplished in the game feel like a complete lie. Maybe it's supposed to be our phantom pain (lol) but that's just a horrible idea and it better not be the intention.

Another annoyance is how Skullface's plan and motivation are dumb and unclear respectively. He comes off as a mustache twirling cartoon rather than an actual interesting villain that all of the trailers made him out to be. But the worst part about him is that (more spoilers) apparently he was helping Big Boss and cleaning up for him since MGS3, making all of Big Boss' accomplishments nullified. If that were the case, then why is Big Boss considered such a legend that they would have to clone him three times? Why would they go through all that trouble when not only can you just brainwash someone else to be able to be like him (Venom Medic), but he didn't even do anything all that special himself? Now MGSV has not only ruined itself, but the entire series. Sure you can go on about how Kojima explains everything with parasites instead of nanomachines now or bringing back certain characters for fanservice and leaving more relevant ones out for no good reason but those pale in comparison to the big dumb twists that this game introduces.

This game not only disappoints long time Metal Gear fans like myself but also alienates any new fans with it's confusing and lame story. I wouldn't recommend this game to anybody. It turned Metal Gear into a Far Cry clone. Not to knock on Far Cry or anything but Metal Gear used to be it's own unique franchise and it's sad to see it end like this. If you want to play a good Metal Gear Solid game, play one of the first three.

reviewText:
An excellent game, although perhaps not the best Metal Gear.

Pros
+Varied way to approach missions, stealth, loud, clean with no kills etc.
+Doesn't punish you with insta-fail situations if you are detected.
+Huge arsenal of weapons, tools and gadgets to research and use.
+Good visuals.
+Great sound.
+Fair story (although lacking compared to other MGS games)
+Changing world - keep getting headshots they equip helmets, constantly using gas the enemy uses gas masks.
+MGS moments, like defeating Quiet by calling supplies down on her to knock her out :P

Cons
-Story missions and story content can be few and far between.
-Difficulty sometimes inconsistent.
-Story largely delivered by audio tape (background would be ok, but not the main story)
-The 3 main voice actors all sounda kinda the same. All are using a raspy voice so it's difficult to understand if it's Kaz, Snake or Ocelot talking.

Conclusion: A great game. Not the best MGS game, but a GREAT game.
What's next? You rate up because you like MGS and this game or you rate down because you don't like the game or you have been seriously offended by this game and how dare it call itself a MGS game when it lacks the same depth of story.

reviewText:
This game is like a Rough Diamond, there are gleams of the potential under the unfinished surface but it was just not quite there yet. And this is obvious from its game play to its narrative and even how the story is paced. The further you progress into the game, the more glaring those unpolished flaws drown out the gem underneath it all.

The gameplay is what draws you in, free roam stealth with a base building mechanic that makes it feel like you are building up to something much bigger than just a super stealth master is addicting. But then you quickly realize that none of the things you are building up towards really goes anywhere.

I never used another weapon other than the M4, and the silenced pistol as my default set up. Anything unsilenced is a waste in this game because stealth is supposed to be everything and there are only a handful of stock suppressed weapons and they are all inferior to what you start with.

The choice of weapons simply was not interesting enough and its very puzzling how it shows that there are eight grades of weapon upgrades but even though I have not seen a weapon upgrade past grade 6. But this is just one of the first issues that this game has.

I was super exited for the base building mechanic and sending out my soldiers to do missions. But, it is shallow and very uninteresting. But the base building is just a throw away feature and offers nothing towards the overall experience towards the game. Every mission happens off screen, the levels mean nothing but simply make up fake requirements for new weapons until level 40.

And the base raiding is just broken, if a player defends, just leave. Because they can keep respawning if you kill them and make it simply not worth your time trying to attack the moment they show up. But really, the rewards for attacking only help with building up a base that simply... offers nothing to the bigger picture of the game.

I was hoping that the FOB raiding would be like some kind of end game content where building up your base actually meant something. But its just tedious and a waste of time, the resources put into this useless mini game could have been put into far more important things... like the story.

Because the story is a mess, the narrative is easily the most dry and uninteresting thing I have been subjected to. Especially after playing a game like The Witcher that makes this look someone‚Äôs overblown fanfiction. And the more I think about it like that... the more I feel like it is the truth. Let‚Äôs break down the characters for you!

Big Boss, Dude, I got a massive metal shard in my brain, talking is hard... this is why I don‚Äôt say ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• for 90% of the dialogue.

Miller, growl growl, Phantom Pain, growl growl, revenge.

Ocelot, its the bosses choice, But I will ALWAYS contradict Miller, always.

Emmerich, I am just trying to help, everything is everyone else‚Äôs fault.

Eli, I am the most abrasive child in the world that needs to get the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• spanked out of me, why am I not in a cell?

Child Soldiers, Why are we following the white boy around?

Skull Face, My name is stupid, my reason for revenge is stupid, my way of deploying of the parasites is stupid.

Code Talker, THE PARASITES DO EVERYTHING, THEY EVEN TALK TO ME, WHY? BECAUSE NANOMACHINES ARE OVERUSED!

Mantis, I am responsible for ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing EVERYTHING that happens, but I will only be the first boss for Solid Snake.

Man on Fire, AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!

Quiet, I cannot speak because I am eye candy, even the camera knows this. My ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• must always be out because apparently I am a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing plant.

D-Dog, I am the most useful companion ever, the tactical advantage I give the player is so damn broken you are stupid to use anyone else.

D-Walker, Boss didn‚Äôt even research a single part of me.

D-Horse, who let that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing dog join? I GOT ONE MISSION BEFORE I BECAME USELESS!

Battle Gear, Was I supposed to be important?

Sahelanthropus, How the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• did I exist before Metal Gear Rex?!

The characters are all just so dammed boring. Their motivations and goals just serve no interest for me at all, it‚Äôs all just noise between the missions. The dialogue is so dammed bad that the bulk of it is shuffled off into cassette tapes for ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s sakes!

---Spoiler---

And that little twist that you get served up at the end? It is just terrible because Venom Snake is fully aware of the fact he is a body double for the real Big Boss, even Miller and Ocelot both know he is a fake.

Hideo deliberately withholds this information from the player. Because it serves him better as an opening hook letting the player think he is in control of the real Big Boss. It seems clever, but is nothing more than smoke and mirrors, because his opening act is his strongest hand before everything falls into chaos.

Also, how ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing stupid do you expect us to be? Big Boss looked like ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing Big Boss in MGS 4. And don‚Äôt try and act like Hideo was being clever by making the opening credits on EVERY ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING MISSION as Venom Snake a subtle wink at that there was something amiss. Because was it ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing required in the narrative? hell, ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing, nope.

---/Spoiler---

You know what, after finishing this review, it‚Äôs not a diamond underneath its unpolished surface... it‚Äôs a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing lie wrapped in ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•... 80 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing bucks... could have had myself a steak dinner for that at least I expect that to turn into ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• when I am done with it and that process only takes 48 hours.

reviewText:
Metal Gear Solid has always been known for its complex narrative. I have always enjoyed its story and it has been a very strong part of the series. MGS V is by far the weakest entry in that regard. This may worry you, if not for the fact that MGS V has the best gameplay in the series BY FAR.

This has been the most enjoyable stealth game I have ever played. The best way I can describe this game is like playing a Bond movie. The way the location text types onto the screen when you infiltrate a new area, the amazing weather and daynight cycle, and outstanding sound effects really drive this point home. The game also has a strong soundtrack featuring many songs from the 80's (my personal favorite music era). Everything plays into one another and makes the experience feel very natural cementing the game as the series best gameplay.

If you are a Metal Gear Solid fan, stealth or action genre fan, then this is a no-brainer and you need to pick this game up. If you are on the fence, then please take my word and give this game a try! I have already played through two times myself, and I am sure that number will grow over the years!

Perfect swan song for Hideo Kojima's time with MGS and Konami.

reviewText:
TL;DR Addicting stealth gameplay, beautiful PC optimization, with tons of in game content to discover. But be warned, the story and boss fights in this game is by far the worst of the series.
[ + ] Gameplay Is the bread and butter of this game. You can tell from start to end that this was the main focus of Kojima Productions. Sneaking is now easy to learn, hard to master in an open world full of enemies, animals, vegetation, and buildings. You can run, walk, crouch, and crawl to get through enemy bases / outposts, and if that‚Äôs not enough you also get countless weapons, items, and vehicles to help make your mission easier. Add all that up, and you‚Äôll realize you have hundreds of options / ways to complete a mission, making each person‚Äôs play through unique based on their playstyle.

[ + ] Graphics are beautiful, and can be seen as another big focus in production besides gameplay. The whole game was developed on the newly made Fox Engine that easily allows for gorgeous lighting, shading, physics, and animations. I would even go as far to say that the facial animations are the best out there right now, something Kojima personally said to have wanted in the game. And the best part is that the game looks great even on lower settings, showing how well the game was optimized.

[ + ] Companions are really fun to have along on missions, and work well within the game. You get up to 4 companions, each one very different in how they can assist you. The dog can track enemies and animals, the horse gives you a quick, easy means of transport, and Quiet can snipe / mark enemies from afar while you sit back and enjoy the carnage. I‚Äôll leave the last companion a secret, but like the rest, it‚Äôs very fun to have along and offers unique ways to help you.

[ + ] AI works very well, and you‚Äôll find that enemies adapt to the way you play. In a game like this, it‚Äôs crucial to have smart AI, and they really did well because soldiers will react accordingly to what you do to them, or their friends. They think the see something? Most time they‚Äôll walk over to check it out. They come under fire? They‚Äôll call in backup and try to flank you. You start shooting them in the head? Soldiers later on will start to wear helmets. Each post will remember what happened before, making you play different each time.

[ - ] Plot is terrible. The prologue starts off so amazingly, that you‚Äôll find yourself drawn in by everything that‚Äôs happening. But after that, it gets continually worse until the games end. The story isn‚Äôt told through cut scenes like older entries, rather by NPC‚Äôs and cassette tapes as you play in game. There are still cut scenes, and some cool ones at that, but not enough. And the worst thing about the story is‚Ä¶it goes nowhere. Out of the 50 missions, excluding maybe 7 or 8, all you do is collect someone or something, then leave. You go onto the next mission, get data, and find yourself one step closer to the main villain, without ever really feeling like you‚Äôve accomplished anything. And by the time you get to the games ending you‚Äôll feel like something is missing. And there is, because the games 3rd chapter was cut, leaving the game unfinished. If you bought the game expecting a good story or at least a finished one, then you bought the wrong game.

[ - ] Bosses are disappointing. The MGS series have always had the best boss fights, and while Phantom Pain does have a couple cool ones, the rest can‚Äôt really be considered a boss fight. The old MGS games had you fight a boss that had his own unique strength, weakness, weapon, and dialogue that made for a real challenge and sort of personal fight. In Phantom Pain you don‚Äôt even need skill, or perception to fight bosses. Just shoot them until they die. There‚Äôs no build up or dialogue, and don‚Äôt have anything special going on, so they come off feeling like a tougher regular enemy.


-----------------------------------------------------------------

I truly believe the MGS V we got is different from the one Kojima had originally envisioned. But including the making of the Fox Engine, the game took 5 years of development. After a while I‚Äôd say Konami had enough, cut funding, and threw the game out to make money rather than give Kojima more time to make a truly masterful game. Which is why we have cut story content and other features that felt less than completed. With all the news out now its clear Konami has fallen low, and that they are first and foremost a shady business tactician, rather than an inspiring game developer.

reviewText:
This game's story is incomplete and doesn't make much sense. But when did the story in a Metal Gear game ever make sense?

If you're a fan of previous Metal Gear games and prefer their longform tone-deaf cinematics to actual gameplay, you'll think this is the worst game in the series. You probably also hate ice cream, fast cars, sex with hot ladies, and fun things in general.

If you're like me and you just want to have your helicopter drop you off with Take On Me blasting out of the speakers so you can abduct the entire population of a Russian firebase along with all their resources, military hardware, and whatever's playing on their boombox, then you'll recognize this game for the (flawed) masterpiece that it is.

Kaz, I'm already a fiddle.

Actual Review:

So after I spent way too much time in this game I guess its time to write a review.
So where should I start?

First off: I was starting to upgrade my computer long ago just for mgsv only to find out that the fox engine is a masterpiece of programming. The game runs so smooth on maxed out settings (I have a gtx 960 g1, however due to my 2gb of vram I just have to set like 2 options from ultra to high. Otherwise everything is maxed out and its constant 60fps). The gameplay is just amazing. They put so much work into these small little details and the seriously thought of everything. Compared to all the other metal gear games the gameplay and control of mgsv is overwhelming. And the fob system is actually not as bad as most people think. You actually win more by just playing it a little bit than you would ever lose. I was VERY sceptical at the beginning but even if you lose staff, resources etc. you still gain more than you lose. Simple reason is because when you succeed and you steal stuff, you get bonus rewards too (which is like 10 times more than what you can steal). So even if you invade someone and steal things and he takes revenge and steals them back, both of only profit because of the bonus rewards (and the bonus reward is just given to you by the game, its not stolen from the enemy). And it also adds a lot of extra time to the game.

So gameplay and everything is amazing and pretty much everyone agrees on that. So whats the thing why some people are dissapointed about the game?

Metal Gear Solid V is not really like the other metal gear games. It heavily focuses on the gameplay and not that much on the story. Long cutscenes are mostly replaced by cassete tapes. Ocelot is not the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• anymore he used to be.

voteText: 40 of 72 people (56%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is disjointed and unfinished, considering the history of the Metal Gear games it lacks the excellent music score which is very unlike of the Metal Gear franchise, I sorely missed Harry Gregson Williams. The quality of the new characters is very low, thematically they seem worlds apart from each other and have next to no cutscenes showing you who they are and how they relate to other characters, they are simply tacked on for plot convenience.
The new bosses are uninteresting and suffer from not being fleshed out enough, especially the parasite unit looking like soldiers from enemy territory quake wars, the powers they have seem so over the top, why make metal gears and clone the legendary soldier big boss when you can infect hundreds of people and make them into teleporting, super strength and invisble cloaking special forces that would literally wipe out entire units (as you are told about how they beat soldiers without anyone knowing what is going on.)
The characters we do know are incredibly underplayed, especially Ocelot who seems to be dull and very serious compared to the over dramatic, sadistic and charasmatic Ocelot we have come to know. Venom snake rarely says anything too, Miller and Huey seem like the only expressive characters and have a great story arch, the game has occasional hidden gem missions and some strong emotive moments but falls flat with all the filler and fluff around it, this game is the fulton extraction simulator, where the game rewards you for simply just chain tranq everyone and extract them, speaking of rewards, the game ranks each mission with S being the best rank, which is obtainable by just beating the level very fast, there is youtube videos of people literally avoiding fighting and stealth and running to the objectives.
A lot of the features of the game are missing, such as using battle gear and the illusive chapter 3. The mother base is a ghost town, huge with nothing in it, without target practise there is no reason for you to be on the base at all, considering its size its a joke that it exists, there was so much potential and it was wasted.
The game holds the strongest game play mechanics and the best stealth gameplay compared to the other games of the series, but falls short in all other aspects, with bad design choices, such as  mandatory helicopter scenes/deployment, huge amounts of filler, grinding and constant menus with the idroid taking huge portions of time to navigate and deploy things, overuse of Fulton extraction,  repeating objectives and mission types, short cut scenes with very little emotive facial expressions considering how much facial recognition technology was used.
I found it strange that credits were played during the beginning of every main mission telling you who is starring in that level and constant reminder of who had helped direct the game, Hideo Kojima, like I would forget?
I just feel disappointed by the obvious missing content and boring repetitive nature of the game, its hastily put together and lacks the quality that all the other metal gear games delivered, a huge shame for a brilliant series of games.

reviewText:
First, let's address the elephant in the room: teh controversy.

Yes, Konami absolutely ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed up Kojima pretty badly.

Yes, this game lacks a 3rd act. Yes, Quiet's excuse for her gratuitious skin show is stupid. Yes, Konami wants to cram in as many microtransactions as humanly possible. Yes, it's annoying that Venom Snake is almost a silent protagonist. Yes, the cutscenes are extremely short and there aren't as many as in previous games. Yes, this game is open world and it might feel like it's padded. Yes, most people may not like the tapes as a replacement for long Codec conversations.

But you know what?, for all it's faults, it's my personal GOTY 2015 runner up (slightly behind The Witcher 3), because I haven't had this much fun with a videogame in a long, long time, it's easily the absolute best action/stealth game I've ever played in my entire life and I'd still whole heartedly recommend it, just keep in check your expectations and everything will go smoothly.

Get it, it's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing awesome :)

A little 2016 update.

This game now officially has a multiplayer mode called Metal Gear Online. It's a nice distraction from the main game and it can get pretty fun at times, but don't buy this just for the multiplayer alone, heck, don't even buy ANY of the microtransactions it brings with it.

I still recommend this game without hesitation, but just don't get it for the multiplayer alone.

reviewText:
A fantastic sequel to the Metal Gear franchise. While it is rather unique and open world unlike the other MGS games, it still has kept most of the mechanics from previous games and adds a LOT more to the table. Building up your own Mother Base takes time and requires a huge amount of resources and money, but will allow you to upgrade your gear and research new equipment for you on your missions. Use Fulton Balloons to extract targets, kidnap enemy troops or steal equipment and vehicles from the enemy, or just to cause chaos.

Game runs smooth on my 970 on the max settings at 60ish FPS so seems quite optimized. Haven't come across any lag or lag spikes yet.

Pro
- Fulton balloons! Send trucks, bears and unsuspecting russians into the air.
- Freedom. Very few restrictions other than a few mission area" walls. You can do basicly anything.
- Graphics. Looks fantastic and runs smooth. Seems to be quite well optimized.

Con
- Glitches. Seen plenty of enemies shoot through walls or see you through a rock or other obstacles.
- Long construction times for buildings."

reviewText:
Pros:
- One of the best stealth games out there.
- Replaying missions is most of the times a different experience. If the games is boring or repetitive is because you don't use all the tools you have.
- Environments looks great. The weather system and day / night cycles changes the way you approach a base. The terrain has good use of vertical design. The FOX Engine works great on all next-gen platforms. I played the PS4 and this PC versions. Between both versions more than 200 hs. Still playing both for whiiiiiiiiiiiiilee!
- The main advantage of this PC version is the lighting. Some shaders respond better to specular maps. The texture work between PS4 and PC at least looks kind of the same range. There're some critical closeups to textures like some Diamond Dogs logos and Quiet sniper riffle that looks awful on both. But aside that the game looks outstanding and runs great even on Borderless Fullscreen" mode ;) It had some stuttering issues and problems with alpha maps of particles during day one but they are solved.
- The game adapts to your gameplay style. It changes the experience every time you replay a mission.
- Master Miller rules!
- If you liked MGS Peace Walker this is a great evolution.
- The buddies of course! D.D. Is Love! <3 Sometimes you'll think a buddy is OP but they have a few weakness for different play styles. For instance Quiet needs to be upgraded to have better "penetration" on soldiers armor. And as I mentioned above
date:
the AI changes because of your play-style and the buddy you choose.
- This last one is for the nostalgic ones....did you play Commandos series? or even Syphon Filter 2 / 3? Well you'll find some good missions here ;) (not to mention Splinter Cell fans and Far Cry lovers who also are OK with third person games)...Many mechanics are from those games.

Cons:
- Without spoilers....The game is flawless....but I will say...don't play it for the story

- In previous MGS we had the Codec or the Radio on MGS3 SE. Now those conversations occurs mainly on the Cassette Tapes. They embrace those tapes a lot. reviewText:
(NOTE: I will talk a lot about gameplay features and presentation. There will be talk about the story but there won't be any actual story/plot spoilers)



Is this the best stealth action game of all time? Is such a thing possible? Yes it is!


-BUDDY SYSTEM- This was my favorite part of the game so I will talk about it first. You can take animals, robots or an overly attached sniper along for the ride with you. The entire feature is probably the best AI buddy thing any game has ever done. I can't even think of a linear game that does what MGSV does when it comes to having a friendly npc with you let alone an open world game. The entire experience was kind of surreal and mind blowing. The game is so ahead of its time.

-AUDIO PRODUCTION- Amazing just like every MGS game in the past. The music, sounds and effects are all sublime. The intro song to the game is very good too. The dialouge is very engaging and well written just like all MGS games in the past. Lots of humor. Lots of nonsense.

-GAMEPLAY- Have you ever wanted to play a game whose developers are a bunch of talented overachievers? Yea this game is for you. Being able to infiltrate enemy outposts from any direction in an open world is an amazing thing. An open world where you roll on the ground while interrogating enemies and use dozens of fun gadgets to help you clear out enemies. There is nothing like it. The running, animations and controls are so well refined its rare to see so much depth in a video game. All of this paired with the buddy system created so much fun. The real great thing about this game is your helicopter. The entire game was designed around it. You will actually be rescuing people.  You actually have to call extraction and carry your objective to the chopper. All of this happens under stealth world rules. Its really unique and methodical. Unlike most games out there that trigger a cutscene. This game will actually make you play out all the scenarios. Now of course you don't have to play stealthy if you don't want but it really is rewarding if you do. There are many options and so many different combinations for infiltration.

-MOTHERBASE- Some people probably didn't like this but I thought it was an excellent minigame within the bigger game itself. Managing motherbase and gathering high ranked soldiers was actually a very fun simulator. There was a lot of micromanagement and maintenance but its great. Its like metal gear manager :D

- FOB - This is a very controversial feature in the game but I felt it was a very innovative feature. You build a base and have to defend it from other people who might invade it. You can also invade other peoples bases and steal their resources, soldiers etc. This is very divisive among the community because you can be invaded while you are offline. As a result many people are terrified but at the end of the day its not a big deal because its not that hard to obtain money and resources in the game. Its actually very easy. Anways if you are into risky multiplayer feature you will like this. I spent a good 100 hours invading and actively defending. I had a blast and many close calls. The stealth gameplay and all your singleplayer tools are very well implemented into the feature. This section of the game is like VR Missions + Steroids + Dark Souls PVP + Kojima + lots of fun. You can easily lose hundreds of hours doing FOB stuff. This feature also introduces optional microtransactions but its not necessary in any way. The microtransactions don't really do much other than speed up the development time of items. But it doesn't matter because you will still be grinding resources to start the development. Whether you spend money on microtransactions or not you will grind a lot in this game. A lot.

- FOX ENGINE- The game is really well optimized and the gameplay is perfectly refined. The industry can learn a lot from this game. This is what happens when you leave a project in the oven for so long. It plays so well and you can tell Kojima productions poured their soul into this. Its really special. I played for over 100 hours and never had any crashes. The framerate was always smooth with the exception of like one cutscene. No bugs at all tho some reported a save bug which was quickly patched by the dev team.

BOSS FIGHTS - There were very few fights in this game compared to other MGS. The few fights that are here are very good tho. Its a completely different experience this time around so its really hard to judge. The game is open world and you don't have a life bar in the top corner telling you how much health you have. You don't have some magical rations to equip and use. The health is regenerating as a result you can die wthin seconds of taking damage. Some things like explosions will kill you in one shot. Overall I would say MGS3 and MGS1 had the best boss fights. MGSV is definitely better than MGS2 and MGS4 tho.

-STORY- Kojima probably got real tired of people making fun of MGS4 for having like 10 hours of cutscenes and only 5 hours of gameplay. This time around its very different. You are looking at a stealth action game with over 100 hours of gameplay and only like 5 hours of cutscenes. Its so different compared to all the previous games it kind of split the community. The presentation and pacing is very different this time around. You don't really see a bunch of silly over the top anime characters like you did in MGS4. Instead the story is much darker and you won't find as much cringe in it. The long pointless briefing cutscenes from MGS4 are not in this. Instead you get a lot of tapes briefing you with lots of information. You can listen to these tapes whenever you want. Some tapes are very good and contain a lot of important information. Some I wished Kojima made cutscenes but for what ever reason he didn't. Either way its absolutely critical for you to listen to these tapes. Not listenting to tapes in this game is equivalent to skippin cutscenes in previous MGS games.  Some tapes are kind of long so make yourself some food and eat while listenting.

The only real flaw with the story and this game is that the ending was rushed. The ending itself was great but everything leading up to it was just not there. Its missing like a good 5-6 missions. The ending also raises a lot of questions about this long near 30 year story but unfortunately Kojima has left Konami and sadly we will never get any of those answers. Previous MGS games always had future titles to continue elaborating on the story but this time around we probably won't get that type of treatment. It is what it is.



CONCLUSION-  Kojima pushed the stealth genre like 15 years into the future with this game. Its a must play and best game of the year without doubt. Take every stealth game released in recent years and all of them combined aren't even 1% of what MGSV is. That is the cold truth.

28 years of excellence from Hideo Kojima. Thank you for all the fun memories.

Introduction to my Metal Gear Solid V's first 'true' secondary mission (With 'chicken' hat, and reflex mode off).

-Goes to the ennmy camp situed 800 meters away with my horse.
-Leave horse at 200 meters before camp.
-Sucessfully get to the camp without getting spot.
-Manage to get it without getting spotted and start grabbing ressource.
-Get the idea to grab a guard to interrogate him.
-Miss click while behind him.
-Try to go away, Makes sound, Guard notices it.
-Guard turns around. Sees a panicked Snake trying to run while crouched.
-Yell that an invader has been spotted.
-I panick hard and shoot him with my tranquilizer gun in his face.
-He falls asleep. I forgot alert was set, I run.
-10 minutes later, No more ammo, silencer used, whole base is sleeping, being face-tranquilized.
-I leave feeling like an American Hero.
-Goes back to Mother Base to punch 4 of my new recruits.
-They thanks me.

10/10 alerted guard, would get spotted again.

Let's be clear, This game is HUGE. And by huge. I mean REALLY HUGE.
First of all, the map. It's big, go wherever you want, everything is open.
Scout enemies' campn gather their ressource for your base to make stuff, Better weapons, tools, or even make your base grow.

Enemies evolve, they learn from you.
Did alot of headshot ? They will start wearing helmets.
Shot alot in their torso ? They will wear kevlar vest.
Play at night time ? They will get flashlight.

Then comes the graphics, this game is beautiful, it is greatly optimised, doesn't eats your whole computer's memory or CPU. No 'big' bugs met for the moment, Few bugs of movements when on edge of rocks or such, which makes you slide and get spot by an enemy but except that, It's pretty well finished already.

LIfetime.. what can I say about it ? I cannot find words to describe it. At this time I am writing this review, I am at 48 hours of playing, non stop, swtching from Primary missions and secondary missions, and sometimes free roaming to gather ressources. And guess what ? 23% exactly are done, only.

I didn't get such addicted to a game since a really long, long time,
I once had a social life, Then I bought MGS V.

Wait no more, buy it already and stop reading reviews.

reviewText:
GET IT!
TL;DR = Easily a contender for Game Of The Year 2015. Hideo Kojima has done it again, marred only by questionable corporate decisions by Konami. If you have room for one game for the next year (or two), get this!

+ Shockingly well optimized, and will likely be the benchmark for performance in games to come. 1080p/60FPS, buttery smooth, and when it isnt, its so well done that smart use of adaptive motion blur as well as dynamic focus scaling makes it so that the action's not interrupted even in the most heated of moments. And even on the most ancient of potatos, it'll either just straight-up not run (at this point, you have got to be on some silly Pentium 4 or similar, older than my nephew) for obvious reasons, or it'll tone things down to where it tries to maintain a constant FPS at the start. Options for a 30FPS lock as well.

+ A masterpiece of Kojima storytelling, even for non-fans of Metal Gear. Even if this is your first MGS game, you wont feel lost, nor will you ever feel left out. MGS fans will appreciate this as much as newcomers, and maybe even convert them over.

+ A perfectly blended mix of 3P shooting action mechanics, tactical sneaking that the series is known for, open-world freedom and exploration (and resource exploitation), taking care of your own base with its little Pokemon-like gotta-catch-em-all soldier capturing mechanic. You can even go ahead of a planned mission to do recon, plan routes, and even infiltrate and take out vital base resources like the power generator, comms, and air radar and they'll remain down when you have a mission in the same area! (Spoiler: You get a storyline mission that you can IMMEDIATELY complete even before you land if certain events in the mission zone are already handled...)

+ Already EASILY 40 hours worth of content IN CHAPTER 1 ALONE! And that's just rushing things! This game may be a 70-100hr monster, and you wont want to rush it, thats for sure!

~~~~~

- 60FPS top lock (seen as Auto in settings). Arguements can be said that there are technical, design, and performance reasons for such a lock, but it is there, and can be seen by some noticeable pop-in in larger areas.

- Kojima storytelling, complete with lengthy cutscenes that have a bit too much fat on them and go for a bit too long. If you disliked MGS because of how long such cutscenes are, apologies, but this game carries that same banner.

- As much as the mechanics are all very well blended together, they are still a blend of mechanics that have issues when brought together into on game without proper UI support. Chief among which is the control problems when handling large menus and lists in your iDroid (easily seen when managing Mother Base staff). This is exacerbated by the lack of mouse support in menus at all. Another problem is the required precision of one's fingers no matter the control method when handling something like CQC. You can end up grabbing your opponent when you intended to disarm and hold up instead, or end up throwing a 5-hit combo when you wanted to throw. Also there is a lack of feedback when bases and outposts you have gone through have restocked"

reviewText:
I've finally beaten the game and I've given myself many days to think about it. Finally I've decided that although I've gotten many hours of mostly enjoyment, I can't call this a good game. The prologue level is amazing the first time you play it, but the game overall just goes downhill from there. The gameplay mechanics are widely considered the best in the series (although certain things are taken out like being able to shoot enemies' handheld radios), and I agree. But considering the length of this game we need more than just stellar gameplay mechanics. Sadly that is not to be.

I liked that this is an open worlds game, but that's also a big problem; there are no indoor levels (except a small to medium sized cave if you count that). Every single area in the game you must approach from the outside and every single area is arranged outside. There aren't really any buildings you have to navigate through with multiple stories. Basically there's no real variety. At least they were smart and had the guard placements randomized. You'll be visiting the same areas over and over, a lot more so if you do the side-ops. The repetiveness in this game is gigantic.

To help stem the repetiveness you do have weapons development to work on throughout the whole game. To develop weapons and other items and to use them it requires GMP (essentially money) and resources. They also threw in a waiting time for weapons to develop to further slow your progress. You get GMP for all sorts of things, and resources you mainly get by finding them in the world and deployment missions. This was fun at first but it didn't take long before it became a chore to grind out the necessary supplies.

The biggest flaw of the game is easily the story and characters, or lack there of. You, Big Boss, rarely talk in the game and when you do it's only a short sentence or two. The rest of the time it's just the other characters simply being exposition and info dumps. There's very little personality development for any of them. But the biggest slap in the face are the godawful cassette tapes. Instead of giving us proper cutscenes they have these audio only cassettes where it's basically just the person (not Big Boss) talking to themself about whatever the subject is. It's incredibly boring and lame. Gone are the traditional codec conversations you can have with the various people you're with. Instead you point your binoculars at certain places on a map and can get brief messages about it, but that's it. I think Kojima took the complaints of MGS4's excessive cutscenes too far by giving us very little cutscenes in this game. I would talk about the disappointment of the characters themselves, such as the wasted potential of the villain Skullface, but I don't want to give spoilers. I will say I'm not happy about the explanation for why Quiet doesn't wear clothes because it just boils down to shameless fan service. Also, the game doesn't explain why she doesnt write/type messages to communicate, which is a bit of a plot hole, considering what she could have (and it's fairly clear wanted) to tell them. Finally, the game doesn't give an ending, just reveals the twist that the game not so subtetly hinted at in the very beginning.

Another complaint is all the filler missions. Having the repetitive side-ops is one thing, but it's another to add in the pointless missions from some client". It's only there to artificially inflate the length. The locations of the main story missions take place at boxed off areas of the map
date: a map you have access to in free roam as well. The problem is when you do the story missions these areas are rarely much different than if you decided to visit them in free roam. reviewText:
This game is terrible, point form on why.

-Cons
- Side Ops are exactly the same as regular missions.
- Gameplay is extremely repetitive and you don't need to play any other way to beat mission.
- Missions in chapter two are literally replaying old missions that you have already completed adding nothing.
- Gathering resources and upgrading your base (which only works in game time) feels like a chore.
- Online multiplayer has no VAC or anti-cheat system so you can cheat and win PVP.
- Micro transactions, selling the prologue to this game for forty dollars on release, cutting the ending to Phantom Pain.
- Story is terrible because the prologue is cut out and the ending is cut out only get middle of story.

-Pros
- Game is fun for a few hours at most before becoming repetitive.
- Some gameplay elements such as guards adapting, weather system and stealth feel good.
- PC Port, wants you to use controller in settings etc but still runs very well on PC.

This is just my observations and feelings on this particular title, If you played Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeros for more than two hours then you will probably like this game as well. If you are a new comer to the series I would steer clear.

reviewText:
One of the, if not the best game ever made... Slightly ruined by Konami.


Too much game!

The complexity depth and scope of this game is hard to sum up or indeed fathom.
Built on the foundations of earlier games and incorporating mechanics and ideas from those titles as well as some brand new ones, all of this placed in TWO massive free roaming combat arenas.
Its almost too much game! Not in the way that there are too many ‚Äúcollectables‚Äù or stuff like that to pick up but in a way that makes you feel like you are just one man trying to defeat a massive army.


Konami are EVIL!

I am a fan of these games and played them back when they came out. But when this game came out I was not a fan!
Like many people I was on the Konami sucks train and was shocked and appalled by the way the game locked away the stuff you earn and offered it to other players to steal! Then they announced that you would be able to ‚Äúinsure‚Äù your stuff by paying them! Konami were essentially using Mafia style strong arm extortion racketeering on it faithful players!!

That said I never had any problems unless it couldn't sign in to the servers and on my second play through its a lot less shocking. I know the stuff I don't just sell immediately might get ‚Äúlocked‚Äù and I will have to wait (like a FB p2p game) to unlock that stuff again or just get new stuff. Also I like making my base super deadly and watching people fail to take it down, then being like ‚Äúwow good job‚Äù when someone actually does!


What Story?!

I know allot has been said about the story, but I think after all the other games its not so bad to keep the story minimal. The fact that it is in between games with strong stories and is trying to tie them together, means it finds itself restricted in what it can do. I mean they're not going to kill Snake or Ocelot are they? The fact that this is a ‚Äúfiller‚Äù game trying to fit in is evident in the two regions you visit. I love the Africa area and its crazy to think that the pixilated top down original game and this are basically the same thing in the same place!

Plus points:
Great gameplay.
Good Graphics.
Stable FPS.
Large world.
Many weapons / items to choose from.
Lots of vehicles drive / get dropped in.
The whole supply drop / bombardment system.
The Fulton system.
Different characters to play as.
The buddy(s).
Kooky weirdness and hiding in boxes.

Minus Points:
Konami
Badly implemented pay to play system that nobody needs or wants and was just an attempt at extortion by Konami.
Have to connect to bad servers or your stuff is stolen by Konami.
Bad (unrealistic) physics (its not a simulator).
Some buggy gameplay (Its fine when you're used to it).
Some annoying gameplay (being exposed / attacked in a cut scene), only in story missions.
Occasionally unrealistic AI responses.
Long traversals to / in between destinations.
Quiet.

9/10
When someone on PC hacks the game and locks Konami out of it, I'll give it 10/10!

reviewText:
This is a lovely engine married to a joyless, hollow game and I am so, so sad that there *probably* isn't an Obsidian of weird goofy homoerotic stealth murdergames waiting in the wings to make The Phantom Pain: New Vegas.

There are some good *moments* in the story, but the narrative is mostly disjointed and flat. There's zero levity aside from the idolmas posters that everyone pointedly ignores and DD. Skull Face doesn't get a scrap of interesting motivation or character depth until 70+ hours in and then you're like *god*, why couldn't Kojima have spent less time on the generic themed boss unit and torturing Huey and hamhandedly trying to tie stuff from previous games into the new one, part a billion and more time on making his characters seem like fully realized human beings? Kiefer Snaketherland barely talks. Huey exists to be tortured until he drops the next plot point (but it's okay bc he's secretly a monster!!!). The Serious Backstory Reason for why Quiet runs around afghanistan in ripped tights and a bikini is ridiculous and kind of insulting? Like, she's kind of cool otherwise but the whole OH I HAVE TO BE ALMOST NAKED OR ELSE I'LL DIE WEEOOWEEOO (which doesn't even work because if clothing basically asphyxiates her /why is she wearing tights/ are the rips for her thigh gills or something ) thing kind of ruins it.

Ocelot is underused. Kaz is surly and shouty and dull. Instead of codecs or cutscenes, a lot of the background information and exposition is in tapes, and if you try to listen to the tapes while you're *doing* anything more often than not you'll trigger a voiceover from Kaz or Ocelot and have to start over after they're done telling you about wormwood or w/e. I mean, I get *why* they probably did this - some people don't want to sit through half an hour per go of somebody talking over stock footage and want to get right to the shooting mans or feeding on treefrogs or w/e, but it kinda hurts more than helps.

On its own, the gameplay is fun, but it wears thin because the Phantom Pain is pretty much Grindy Timesink: the Game. You need a ton of GMP both to pay for loadouts and to develop weapons, which means you need to do side missions in a bunch of far-flung parts of the map that take forever to get to (it's not as bad once you get to Africa, but it's miserableeeee in Afghanistan) because you don't get the ability to fulton vehicles until several hours in and D-Horse is sadly not a bionic racehorse or anything. On top of that, items take 18/36/72/144 minutes in real-time to develop (and you can't close the game and and come back later to find them done, like with DA: Inquisition or something). Grade 7+ weapons and items *can* be developed while you're offline, but they take *literal days* to develop, so...it's kind of a mixed bag.

The side missions themselves get real old real quick - the travel time could be forgiven if they were varied or had neat little gimmicks, but it's the same few mission types all the way down (with like...what, a literal handful of exceptions?). Extract someone or pick up something, kill a group/blow up vehicles, clear mines, repeat 157 times. These were fun, at first! But doing over a hundred of the same side ops makes them wear really, *really* thin.

Some of the main missions are fun, but a lot of them feel kind of random and disconnected from the narrative. The boss encounters are some of the most tedious, unfun things I've found in the entire MG series. (i was gonna make a Snake's Revenge joke but nothing's coming so long story short i uh hope you like fruitlessly trying to dodge zombie 100m hurdle champions with perfect aim and bottomless magazines, among other things) The bosses themselves don't really have...*anything* in the way of unique backstory or character, to the point that they make the Tarted-up Trauma Brigade from MGS4 look deep and well-rounded by comparison.

The bosses that got recycled from previous games don't count, and they're not used to much interesting effect in TPP anyways. Deal with it, nerds.

The online is amazing, because they managed to take the worst parts of Dark Souls-style MP and make them /worse/. You can't opt out of the online. If you want to develop Grade 6/7+ gear, you pretty much have to do the online, because it's either rob someone's base or run around picking up stacks of 10 Golden Crescent/Haoma/Digitalis until you reach 1000 or whatever. Like soulsgames MP, there's some PVP - if somebody's playing while you invade their base, they get a notification and can defend, and (like soulsgames!) more often than not the PVP's full of cheap fun-ruining s--t and hackers. Unlike soulsgames MP, you can't opt out of the online, which means people can invade you and steal your FOB soldiers *even when you're not running the game*.

The personnel requirements for upgrading your base defense items past like...first/second tier pretty much force you to spend the ten bucks in wacky Konami Buttcoins and buy a second FOB. The *resource* requirements for upgrading force you to invade a bunch of FOBs (unless you like a lot more tedium), which means you run into the other problem. There's no real diversity in FOBs' *layout*, only their level of defense, and *that* tends to stick to a pretty strict binary -- either they're 1/2 platform FOBs with minimal defenses and modest rewards and really boring, or they're 3/4 platform FOBs where the platforms are saturated with lasers and cameras and UAVs and soldiers with grade 6/7 Battle Dress and you're dead two seconds after you get spotted regardless of running or dodging because unless DD digs up an Old Hunter's Bone *no one can run that fast*.

It's not exactly a ton of fun.

The incidental music is good. The Official 80s Music(tm) is kind of lacking. Less She Blinded Me with Science (ughhhhhh), more punk and Cocteau Twins.

3/10 would drag myself to the near-end out of spite and what might be stockholm syndrome and spend way too much GMP to give Quiet some actual people clothes again.

reviewText:
This game was massively overhyped and under delivered.  Maybe I'm the only guy with what will probably be an unpopular point of view with this, but this game could have been amazing.   It starts off pretty well, hits all the right notes, and Act 1 of the game, which is massive turns out to be half decent.

The second half of the game going into Act 2, while having a few memorable moments, is otherwise a complete disaster.  Over half of the missions in the second half of the game consist of you replaying missions from the first half of the game, but with gimmicks to make them harder.  They completely have nothing to do with the story at all, and some of them are stupidly conceived that it feels like a chore to keep playing.  Every so often they will throw you a little piece of story, then back to the replaying of the old crap.  This goes all the way to the end of the game, literally.   The final mission and the ending are such a massive disappointment in every way, that I'm baffled how any reviewer worth his salt could have found the conclusion to this game to be anything other than a flop.

I'm frankly not interested in hearing the tale of how the end of the game was forced to be cut down, you are charging a premium price for a game like this, it should deliver a premium experience.  Compared to the narratives of the previous MGS games, this is a compete dud.

In terms of the gameplay elements, there's a lot to like here, but a dose of really poorly desgined annoyances.   The open-world" isn't really that open at all in terms of one of the games maps is just a series of hallways with mountains and cliffs keeping you on the rails.
