reviewText:
Obvious spoilers ahead in this review, be warned.

MGSV, gameplay-wise, is definitely one of the best games of the year. It provides players with a lot of options of how to tackle obstacles. It gives you all the tools you need to do whatever you want to do to the point most of the game becomes absurdly easy. The graphics and optimization are all fantastic as well, but these things have all been covered elsewhere. If you don't care about story, you'll love MGSV and you should pick it up.

That said, the gameplay is flawed in quite a few ways. The latter stages of the game are just repeats of missions you've already done with the difficulty amped up, there's very little motivation to play them other than a slow grind so you can get through with the few remaining story missions. This is worsened by the Side-Ops which quickly just turn into generic slaughterfests where you repeat the same thing over and over just to progress the game.

The game clearly doesn't feel finished. It's obvious that whatever was happening at Konami left Kojima with an unfinished product he had to rush out the door, and it shows. Aside from the repetitiveness in the missions (as well as how few main story missions there are), the multiplayer was also neglected. FOBs were initially promised to be customizeable bases players could personalize alongside a Dark Souls-like co-op feature, but neither of these are the case. Each FOB is an exact clone of Mother Base, you're essentially just playing the same map over and over with different guards and defenses. It also becomes practically impossible to win as an attacker against any decent players - the amount of guards the enemy has combined with their ridiculously short respawn timer of 25 seconds means on most maps the defender can simply rush you down and win through attrition no matter how many times they die.

These things are mostly excuseable. The main issue here is the story. Kojima introduces an interesting plot in Ground Zeroes with Big Boss being put in a coma and Skullface being introduced as a reprehensible villain with shadowy motives.  Players pick up the Phantom Pain expecting a story of revenge as Boss goes on a rampage to take down Skullface and by extension, Cipher, but ultimately players are left disappointed.

Spoilers ahead
Heavy story spoilers from here on in;

Skullface's motives ultimately make no sense. Players are never made aware of who exactly he is or why he's doing what he's doing. His plans are ultimately contradictory and rely on psuedoscience to the point that the writers had to literally rewrite human evolution and biology to accomodate it. It's incredibly jarring and ultimately you're forced to just go along with it because the nonsensical plotline is built entirely around it. In Ground Zeroes players are built up to expect one of the darkest antagonists Metal Gear has had, yet ultimately all he does is raise more questions that his inclusion fails to answer because of his utter irrelevance as a character.

The weakness of Skullface as a character could be excused if we were introduced to more antagonists to support him, as is common in most Metal Gear games. In MGS1 we had Foxhound, in MGS2 we had Dead Cell, in MGS3 we had the Cobra Unit and in MGS4 we had the Beauty and the Beast Unit. Each of these groups contained a number of interesting antagonists who each had specific powers which provided the player with challenges throughout the game - characters like Vulcan Raven, Psycho Mantis and Revolver Ocelot are probably much more memorable to people than Liquid Snake, for instance. There is no such counterpart in MGSV - Skullface's only supporting cast are the Third Child and the Man on Fire, both of whom are excellent characters but ultimately they serve as the only real boss enemies in the game. There's also the Skulls, who are essentially completely mute zombies with no personality or sentience that don't really serve as interesting villains.

The side-characters unfortunately suffer a lot of the same issues. Miller is a perpeptually whiny manchild who borders on treason more or less entirely throughout the game, leading players to wonder why he was ever considered Boss' right-hand man. Quiet is a fairly interesting character, but her relevance to the storyline is ultimately minimal outside of certain missions. She was clearly written with the fact that some players would choose not to bring her back to Mother Base in mind.

And then we get to the ending. I won't spoil the ending directly, but needless to say it completely destroys any enjoyment the player may have taken from the story. We're led to believe that the player is witnessing Big Boss' descent into an anti-hero, yet for the most part all we see is a typical good guy. The few moments of badassery displayed (that is, the ones that aren't ruined by Huey acting like a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•wit) are completely wiped away as Kojima asspulls a twist that makes absolutely no sense and renders the events of the game completely irrelevant. It's as though Kojima was trying to recreate the same mind‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ery he came up with in MGS2 but it completely falls flat on its face. It's completely disappointing for the player, it ruins any emotional investment they may have had in the game or its characters and it unfortunately has negative repercussions for the consistency and lore of the other games in the series. With MGSV being the last Metal Gear planned to work on, I'd been hoping for closure to any remaining plotholes and more insight into one of the series' central characters. Instead Kojima fails to to so adequately and instead raises even more questions with a bizarre M. Night Shyamalan-esque twist.

Spoilers end
In short, MGSV is a fun game, but it's an awful Metal Gear game. MGS4 was highly criticized for its total fanservice, but it at least looked at the characters of Metal Gear and tried to give them closure. MGSV does the opposite - it's only tangentially about Metal Gear, instead it's more like a reinvention of the entire series for a new audience. And even if the awful storyline and characters are disregarded, the game itself is artificially inflated through dozens of repetitive side mission, needless timesinks and the latter half of the game literally just making the player repeat missions they've already finished.

You'll enjoy the first half and get sucked into the story, but by the end you'll feel disappointed by a game that's clearly unfinished and tries to make up for it with ridiculously stupid twists that'd make even the Colonel in MGS2 blush.

reviewText:
This is a review for MGO, not for TPP.
Alright, so. No this is not a review for the Phantom Pain. This is a review for Metal Gear Online. I'm not here to discuss the singleplayer aspect of the game, I'm here to discuss the multiplayer aspect of the game.

First off, Metal Gear Solid V has an excellent singeplayer, albeit the lack of content and the feeling of it being rushed, it's a very good experience.

The multiplayer aspect of the game, however, isn't. Yes I know, it's a beta. But we all know that the beta is only there for server stress testing.

UPDATE: The game's out of beta after two days, no patch notes anywhere, still no text chat and still no option for push to talk, dedicated servers, etc. This review still stands as is!

Server performance and connection
The game's performance is great, but the server performance isn't. There's a P2P connection between players just like with the console version, which also has terrible networking.

For those who don't know, a P2P (short for peer to peer) connection. Is a connection between computers and a main server that stores all your exp, coins and points. But, instead of the server being physically there to host your game, your game data is streamed between all the players in the game, thus creating a 'virtual' server. This virtual server is hosted by one player in the game, which has supossedly the best connection out of all players.

The reason I put in the word supposedly is because this player can have a dial-up connection and still be the host. The game solely looks at ping and not at up and down speeds. This creates big frustrations like getting killed around corners, kill delays and my personal favorite: kill trading!

Another great thing about this is that CQC, which is a core gameplay mechanic of Metal Gear Solid V, isn't going to work. Why? Because people will start teleporting all over the place, dodging CQC is next to impossible and people can grab you from meters away.

Also there is no in-game text chat and no push to talk, all mics are open by default and you can't type anything besides pre-made in-game phrases.

Spawn points
Another controversial thing, the spawn points in MGO are in one word; terrible. The game has this one hangar map where the spawn points of both teams are literally on the other side of the building. This building is around 5 x 20 meters. Which isn't big, at all. You can just rush in as an Enforcer and shoot everybody in the face. Spawn protection is about two seconds and that's not enough to shoot somebody else that's shooting you.

This is only a problem in the two game modes that aren't clock and dagger, I'll get to that in a bit.


Game modes, or lack thereof
The game supports a total of three game modes which aren't really utilizing the entire stealth mechanic of Metal Gear Solid V.

Bounty Hunter: Basically the EXP grind mode / TDM mode. Players start off with a set amount of tickets. Every kill results into the opposite team losing a ticket. If the amount of tickets reaches zero, you win. However, you can earn tickets by fulton extracting enemy teammates. With every kill you earn a bounty point, the more points you have, the more point the enemy team will gain when they fulton extract you.

Cloak and Dagger: Probably the most fun mode. The game is 6 v 6 where the player either has to defende a data disk or extract a data disk. The ones that defend the disk are equiped with lethal weaponry, whilst the attackers are equiped with non lethal guns. The key here is stealth and teamwork.

Comm Control: Basically Call of Duty's domination gamemode, kinda the same as Bounty Hunter.

Overall the modes are very basic and they lack depth. They don't utilize the game's singleplayer mechanics as well. Specifically stealth mechanics aren't used properly in all the modes. The modes aren't really fun, either. It's just rushing because of the short five minute timer. More modes would mean the game would get some more depth, which I would seriously support!

Balancing
The game tries it's best at balancing but to be honest, it's not really possible to do so with all the current weaponry and perks.

For instance, within the Cloak and Dagger gamemode, it's possible for the non-lethal attacking team to take out the entire enemy team with snipers. Players are cloaked permanently until they get spotted, which is rather hard in dark maps. If the entire team chooses to take non-lethal snipers, they can snipe the enemy team from a distance and win the game.

In Bounty Hunter, which is basically TDM, you can be an Enforcer and shoot four RPGs per life. That's... quite a lot since they can kill about two to three players with one well-placed shot.

Customization and classes
The game has three classes, each supporting their pros and cons.

Enforcer: Basically your go-to character if you want to run and gun. The enforcer supports high damage weaponry, explosives and more health than any other classes. He has the firepower, but lacks the finesse.

Scout: Your sniper character, great for long-distance battles. But lacks in short range as he's easily flankable if you're careful enough.

Infiltrator: My personal favorite. The Infiltrator is a class mainly focused on stealth. He's fast, he's low on health but has a couple of fun abilities like the ability to use cloak.

Customization is... well, limited. Weaponry and some perks are locked to your class. Most paint jobs for your gun cost actual money and some customization to your character also costs money, which is a big shame.

Rounding up
The multiplayer is basically lacking in depth, its got its pros, its got its cons. It's fun if you're with friends, but playing with random people that don't play the objective isn't a fun experience.

If the game gets more balanced, the networking gets fixed up and if they implement text chat I'll update the review. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
As a fan on the series for 15 years I was upset at the cut content and sacking of Kojima.
But the game is fantastic. I have over 60 hours played and i'm at 39% complete. There is mountains of content in this game,  many different types of main missions and side ops that you can approach when you want, how you want. I love the chopper insert and exfill system, I love flying into africa with long tall sally by little Richard blearing out of my chopper :D

The AI adapt to you and how you approach bases and outposts, equipping themselves with Night vision, helmets, gas masks and more accordingly. They will also conduct search parties for you and cover entry/exit points. They really do search for you too, the AI is brilliant in that regard.

All this and the game runs and looks like a dream. I have been running high/ultra settings at a constant 60fps on a R9270 2gb and an FX6300, frames havent dropped once.

A Hideo Kojima game. 10/10

reviewText:
Don't really know what to write.  The gameplay trailers they did for this game are an accurate depiction of what you can do.  Great game.  Its story missions are split up like a TV show series.  That kind of threw me off but I understand why they did that.  It breaks the game up into manageable slices.  You can play for 30 mins to 1 hour, complete a mission, and have a satisfying conclusion.  The story is actually interesting as well.  MGS 2 turned me off to the series due to its overuse of melodrama.  Kojima definitely turned it way down for this.  There is more of a serious vibe to this game, and its better for it in my opinion.

Plus theres a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• load of content.  18 hours in and it says I am at 9% completion.

reviewText:
I've played 5 hours of this game so far and I'm loving it!

The intro was spectacular and really made me feel something, which few games have. It was surprisingly long (took me about an hour), but totally worth it.

I've completed only the first few batches of missions and collected D-Dog (he's still a pup), and a side-op. The amount of research you can perform makes me excited as well.

Approaching different objectives from any way I desire is incredibly refreshing. I try to go pure stealth, but my mistakes cause me to end up with a shootout. I didn't expect the third person shooter style to play well, but it feels just as effective as being stealth.

Controls are weighty, but feel realistic and smooth. My only complaint thus far is some of the times I have difficulty controlling D-Horse, but that might get better with time.

I can't wait to get home and play it again! All in all, one of the best games I've ever played.

reviewText:
Should you buy this game as a newcomer to the series? Ehhh, idk up to you. I personally wouldn't

Should you buy this game as a huge MGS fan? No.

Why not?
Well, simply because you can feel how rushed the game was. It was released prematurely, no doubt about it. There is literally only 3 maps in the game (Afghanistan, Africa, and Mother Base). ALL of them feel barren and like they're all missing something.

Sure you can do side quests, but who wants to do the same ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• over and over again?
Sure you can farm mats to upgrade your weapons, but is that what the MGS series is about?

The story is okay, and just does not impact you at all like previous games had. Some stuff in the story just falls flat, and the stuff that could have lead to something AWESOME just turns to ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

It also doesn't help I obsessed over this game for years since the Moby ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• trailer.
I had hyped myself to oblivion, only to be massively disappointed.

Also, the MGO in this installment is just... An insult to the fans who have been waiting for a new MGO. No where NEAR as much content as MGO 2. Just a little handful of maps, 3 game modes (No TDM or DM? Seriously?!)
I'm all for change, but the change in MGO 3 was barely there. Truly saddening.

The answer to all this is Kojima simply just got ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed royally by Konami, and he wasn't able to deliver what he wanted.

All that being said, this game is actually a very beautiful game, it runs perfect with little to no dips in FPS, the controls are ridiculously smooth, there are some pretty good wtf moments, and the MGS charm is still there even though it is the darkest installment in the series.

8/10

Just wait for it to go on sale, or a version with all the DLC comes out.
Oh, and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• YOU KONAMI

reviewText:
Here's how much I like this game.

I wrote a 17 page review HERE. Steam will only take three pages. Spoilers are hidden, and the formating is better on GDocs anyway.


So here's the TL;DR version from it's intro and whatever else I could fit in here:

Preemptive TL;DR ReviewThe game is incredibly fun.
At least 60 hours minimum in gameplay for Chapter 1.
More ‚Äúreplay value‚Äù than what Ground Zeros had.
Multiple ways to play; no one way is the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù way (but stealth earns more points).
You can drive around the African plains, driving off cliffs, with unconscious guards in the back, all while ‚ÄúTake On Me‚Äù plays on your walkman.
8.5/10

GameplayI could sit here for paragraphs and talk about the new open-world style. Yes, it‚Äôs extremely fun and gives you hours of replayability. Don‚Äôt feel like sneaking today? How about ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up in a tank. Want to do missions with (almost) no starting equipment? Go for it. The world is your play thing.

But you probably already knew that.

Rather than blab on about all the open-world mechanics, I want to focus on the one mechanic that really resonated with me; The Response System. In a nutshell, the response system is how the enemy forces react to you. No, a nutshell is too small. Let‚Äôs compare it to a frig‚Äôen acme-grade boulder. It‚Äôs e-uge.
The response system was Kojima Production‚Äôs way of tailoring the difficulty of Phantom Pain to every individual player. Is your strategy based around vehicular combat? Now enemies have guided missiles. Are you one of those people who just run-and-gun like mindless ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•wats? Have fun with those pinpoint-accurate riot suit guys. Or are you a traditional Metal Gear player, choosing stealth above all? Then watch where you step; there are mines everywhere. Every single strategy has a response specifically designed against it, in a system designed to be your own personal challenge.
The response system is broken down into eight separate ‚Äúresponse‚Äù categories (six visible and two invisible). I want to go as in-depth as possible with this, so here‚Äôs a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• load of some charts. A quick breakdown:
Combat response: Triggered by setting off alerts and doing frontal assaults. Enemies are equipped with better weapons and armour, reinforcements increase, and every enemy is hopped up on Diazepam.
Sniper Response: Triggered by hitting enemies from long distances. Snipers are deployed around the map, just waiting to ruin your day.
Vehicle Response: Triggered by getting kills with vehicles. Enemies are deployed with rockets; just two are powerful enough to stop your paper-thin tanks.
Gas Response:Triggered by using gas and smoke grenades on guards, or when they smell the stink of someone who hasn‚Äôt showered in 20 missions. Enemies finally figure out the science behind gas masks, making them immune to your gasses.
Headshot Response: Triggered by getting headshots. Enemies start wearing helmets, which you‚Äôll respond to by shooting them in their still unprotected face.
Nighttime Response: Triggered when you start doing more night-time vigilante work. Enemies trade in their glowsticks for flashlights, and have a chance to come equipped with night vision goggles so bright they put sam fisher to shame.
Fulton Response: Triggered when you fulton a guard and his buddy happens to catch you in the act. Enemies respond by learning how to shoot a big-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• balloon.
Covert Actions Response: Triggered by neutralizing guards without setting off alerts. Enemies respond by putting up plastic dummies so fake they make lawn flamingos look real.This system is the backbone of the entire open-world machine that is Phantom Pain. Without it, this game would be nothing.
That being said, the system isn‚Äôt perfect. While it‚Äôs designed to be hard for the way you play, it‚Äôs never hard enough. Drones and anti-theft devices are never used by the AI. And for someone who had a 1(high) response level in their Covert Actions Response, I only saw one camera throughout the entire game. ONE. The hardest part of the entire game were vehicle battles, which boiled down to how many rockets you could fire off before you got sniped by a tank half a mile away.
This stems from the fact that the system is too diverse; difficulty doesn't exactly increase with progress anymore. Completing a few missions using a different tactic, be it intentional or unintentional, automatically lowers responses that were not triggered. Frequently completing missions with varying tactics would often keep the response system at stupid easy levels. The end-game of Phantom Pain for me was almost identical to the beginning missions, as I had somehow created a permanent half-combat, half-Covert Action response level. While it was nice to see such an in-depth difficulty system in use, they should have also incorporated elements of the standard ‚Äúenemies get tougher as the game progresses‚Äù model. That would have created a perfect balance between personal-difficulty and progress-difficulty.

Scoring System
Now this next part probably won‚Äôt make any sense to people who haven‚Äôt played Peace Walker. Stick with me here, this is the main reason why I think Phantom Pain is better than it‚Äôs predecessor Peace Walker, and why it makes Phantom Pain one of the more unique entries in the series to date.
First, let‚Äôs talk about the scoring/rank system that was in Peace Walker, as it is what the current system is based off of. The scoring system in Peace Walker graded you on a basic criteria at the end of each mission: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=600341225
Given that system, you were very limited in how you could play. Sure, you could run through with the CAW (fully automatic shotgun that held 7 shots) and the Patriot (The Boss‚Äô weapon, has unlimited ammo) and wreak everyone, but doing so would get you a low rank. To achieve an S rank, you'd have to sprint towards the objective, headshotting every guard along the way with your tranq pistol. This was almost a requirement, as getting a high rank (S rank) was required to get better (cool as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•) gear. We‚Äôre talking about stuff like the Railgun, Stealth Camo, EM Net, Vulcan Minigun, The End‚Äôs suit (from MGS3), The Boss‚Äô weapon ‚ÄúPatriot‚Äù, and The Banana (yes, you can use a banana as a weapon). So long story short, stealth was practically the only/best way to play.
And this was Peace Walker‚Äôs biggest downfall. Here‚Äôs a game where you can develop an absolute ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• load of weapons. Peace Walker had around 98 weapons: 63.5 of said weapons were lethal weapons (which you could only use on AI boss fights), 25 weapons were gimmick weapons (magazines, smoke grenades, LR and PR guns, etc.), and only 9.5 weapons were non-lethal. 9.5. I have all these crazy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• guns and I'm stuck using the same 9.5 almost every mission. I want to use the minigun, I want to use the CAW. But I can‚Äôt. This severely restricted your playstyles and how you could play the game. I hated it.
Then Phantom Pain happened. While Phantom Pain‚Äôs grading system was still similar to Peace Walker‚Äôs, it improved it in about every area that Peace Walker failed:Time is still the largest factor in your rank.
Alerts don‚Äôt pen

reviewText:
Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain.... What is there to say. I've waited years for this game. I've waited longer for an actual PC release of any Metal Gear Solid game. Ground Zeroes came out awhile ago and it was like a tease. We all witnessed what the fox engine could do. That the team behind the PC version was comminted to making a good port. We just had to wait.


I started my Metal Gear Solid journey when I was a kid. For my 12th birthday my Dad bought me a Playstation. He didn't understand that you had to also buy games for it. So all I had that summer was a demo disk that came with the system. On this disk was a bunch of games you could play for a few minutes at a time and then they would end. I played all the games that looked fun to me a hundred times. Tony Hawk 1 was on this disk. I played that first level Hanger" 2 minutes at a time probably a thousand times that summer. After awhile I got bored. I looked at the games I didn't play on the disk and stumbled upon "Metal Gear Solid." At first glance it didn't look like something I would care for. Being bored enough I decided to give it a shot. The demo was of the very first part of the game where your goal is to make it to the elevator without being seen. After many failed attempts I got the hang of it. As the elevator started ascending
date: the cutscene started. Man was that awesome. I knew that if there was any game I wanted to play this was the one. Years go by
recommended: and Metal Gear Solid is my favorite series. I played each game multiple times (besides Peace Walker). Now that I'm a PC gamer
hoursPlayed:
when I heard (over a year ago) that MGSV was coming to the PC I couldn't believe it. I was so excited.

The Day finally comes and I played it maybe 12 hours that first day. It was nothing like I imagined. The first real open world in a Metal Gear Solid game sounds amazing to me. As I went from outpost to outpost collecting materials and kidnapping soliders to work for me I felt something was missing. This is far from the games I played growing up. Not in a bad way. I joked with friends that this game plays more like Far Cry 3 then like the Metal Gear Solid I knew.

Gone are the 20 minute cutscenes that a lot of people didn't like (I loved them btw.) Call it what you want
voteText: Metal Gear Solid was story first for me. Don't get me wrong I love the updated gameplay for todays standards. I feel that a open world is something that Metal Gear Solid always needed. I just feel like it's lacking on the story front. Most of the story takes place between main missions and what use to be cutscenes has been turned into Cassette Tapes. The Cassette Tapes are great. I guess I'm being a bit nostalgic. I just loved the face to face interaction characters had in the previous games.\n\nThe story is focused. More tight then previous games. reviewText:
A Hideo Kojima Game.






What, that isn't enough for you? Clearly you've never played Metal Gear.
Try a super-versatile, extremely polished, open world stealth action sandbox with LOADS of upgrade progression, myriad weapons, (both lethal and non-lethal), shiny gadgets that would've made James Bond green with envy, and more. Build your own army of hand-picked soldiers from the ranks of the enemy, expand your ocean base to city-sized proportions, and sneak around in a cardboard box. Throw in fluid, tactical movement, weapons with realistic ballistics and handling, and a complex, rewarding system of close-quarters combat - Now you're getting the picture. A strong contender against The Witcher 3 for Game of the Year 2015, and a title that is certain to be remembered on its own as Hideo Kojima's Magnum Opus - And one of the best video games ever made.

reviewText:
Here's how much I like this game.

I wrote a 17 page review HERE. Steam will only take three pages. Spoilers are hidden, and the formating is better on GDocs anyway.


So here's the TL;DR version from it's intro and whatever else I could fit in here:

Preemptive TL;DR ReviewThe game is incredibly fun.
At least 60 hours minimum in gameplay for Chapter 1.
More ‚Äúreplay value‚Äù than what Ground Zeros had.
Multiple ways to play; no one way is the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù way (but stealth earns more points).
You can drive around the African plains, driving off cliffs, with unconscious guards in the back, all while ‚ÄúTake On Me‚Äù plays on your walkman.
8.5/10

GameplayI could sit here for paragraphs and talk about the new open-world style. Yes, it‚Äôs extremely fun and gives you hours of replayability. Don‚Äôt feel like sneaking today? How about ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up in a tank. Want to do missions with (almost) no starting equipment? Go for it. The world is your play thing.

But you probably already knew that.

Rather than blab on about all the open-world mechanics, I want to focus on the one mechanic that really resonated with me; The Response System. In a nutshell, the response system is how the enemy forces react to you. No, a nutshell is too small. Let‚Äôs compare it to a frig‚Äôen acme-grade boulder. It‚Äôs e-uge.
The response system was Kojima Production‚Äôs way of tailoring the difficulty of Phantom Pain to every individual player. Is your strategy based around vehicular combat? Now enemies have guided missiles. Are you one of those people who just run-and-gun like mindless ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•wats? Have fun with those pinpoint-accurate riot suit guys. Or are you a traditional Metal Gear player, choosing stealth above all? Then watch where you step; there are mines everywhere. Every single strategy has a response specifically designed against it, in a system designed to be your own personal challenge.
The response system is broken down into eight separate ‚Äúresponse‚Äù categories (six visible and two invisible). I want to go as in-depth as possible with this, so here‚Äôs a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• load of some charts. A quick breakdown:
Combat response: Triggered by setting off alerts and doing frontal assaults. Enemies are equipped with better weapons and armour, reinforcements increase, and every enemy is hopped up on Diazepam.
Sniper Response: Triggered by hitting enemies from long distances. Snipers are deployed around the map, just waiting to ruin your day.
Vehicle Response: Triggered by getting kills with vehicles. Enemies are deployed with rockets; just two are powerful enough to stop your paper-thin tanks.
Gas Response:Triggered by using gas and smoke grenades on guards, or when they smell the stink of someone who hasn‚Äôt showered in 20 missions. Enemies finally figure out the science behind gas masks, making them immune to your gasses.
Headshot Response: Triggered by getting headshots. Enemies start wearing helmets, which you‚Äôll respond to by shooting them in their still unprotected face.
Nighttime Response: Triggered when you start doing more night-time vigilante work. Enemies trade in their glowsticks for flashlights, and have a chance to come equipped with night vision goggles so bright they put sam fisher to shame.
Fulton Response: Triggered when you fulton a guard and his buddy happens to catch you in the act. Enemies respond by learning how to shoot a big-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• balloon.
Covert Actions Response: Triggered by neutralizing guards without setting off alerts. Enemies respond by putting up plastic dummies so fake they make lawn flamingos look real.This system is the backbone of the entire open-world machine that is Phantom Pain. Without it, this game would be nothing.
That being said, the system isn‚Äôt perfect. While it‚Äôs designed to be hard for the way you play, it‚Äôs never hard enough. Drones and anti-theft devices are never used by the AI. And for someone who had a 1(high) response level in their Covert Actions Response, I only saw one camera throughout the entire game. ONE. The hardest part of the entire game were vehicle battles, which boiled down to how many rockets you could fire off before you got sniped by a tank half a mile away.
This stems from the fact that the system is too diverse; difficulty doesn't exactly increase with progress anymore. Completing a few missions using a different tactic, be it intentional or unintentional, automatically lowers responses that were not triggered. Frequently completing missions with varying tactics would often keep the response system at stupid easy levels. The end-game of Phantom Pain for me was almost identical to the beginning missions, as I had somehow created a permanent half-combat, half-Covert Action response level. While it was nice to see such an in-depth difficulty system in use, they should have also incorporated elements of the standard ‚Äúenemies get tougher as the game progresses‚Äù model. That would have created a perfect balance between personal-difficulty and progress-difficulty.

Scoring System
Now this next part probably won‚Äôt make any sense to people who haven‚Äôt played Peace Walker. Stick with me here, this is the main reason why I think Phantom Pain is better than it‚Äôs predecessor Peace Walker, and why it makes Phantom Pain one of the more unique entries in the series to date.
First, let‚Äôs talk about the scoring/rank system that was in Peace Walker, as it is what the current system is based off of. The scoring system in Peace Walker graded you on a basic criteria at the end of each mission: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=600341225
Given that system, you were very limited in how you could play. Sure, you could run through with the CAW (fully automatic shotgun that held 7 shots) and the Patriot (The Boss‚Äô weapon, has unlimited ammo) and wreak everyone, but doing so would get you a low rank. To achieve an S rank, you'd have to sprint towards the objective, headshotting every guard along the way with your tranq pistol. This was almost a requirement, as getting a high rank (S rank) was required to get better (cool as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•) gear. We‚Äôre talking about stuff like the Railgun, Stealth Camo, EM Net, Vulcan Minigun, The End‚Äôs suit (from MGS3), The Boss‚Äô weapon ‚ÄúPatriot‚Äù, and The Banana (yes, you can use a banana as a weapon). So long story short, stealth was practically the only/best way to play.
And this was Peace Walker‚Äôs biggest downfall. Here‚Äôs a game where you can develop an absolute ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• load of weapons. Peace Walker had around 98 weapons: 63.5 of said weapons were lethal weapons (which you could only use on AI boss fights), 25 weapons were gimmick weapons (magazines, smoke grenades, LR and PR guns, etc.), and only 9.5 weapons were non-lethal. 9.5. I have all these crazy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• guns and I'm stuck using the same 9.5 almost every mission. I want to use the minigun, I want to use the CAW. But I can‚Äôt. This severely restricted your playstyles and how you could play the game. I hated it.
Then Phantom Pain happened. While Phantom Pain‚Äôs grading system was still similar to Peace Walker‚Äôs, it improved it in about every area that Peace Walker failed:Time is still the largest factor in your rank.
Alerts don‚Äôt pen
Out of space. Continued in Google Doc

reviewText:
Metal Gear Solid games are typically plot-heavy games, so I will break this down in an attempt to avoid spoilers: a list of pros and cons followed by a full review that avoids spoilers as much as possible.

MGS5 has plenty of good things going for it:
+ Expansive outdoor environments with dozens of military facilities to explore...
+ A diverse soundtrack from a new composer that combines and builds off of the best tracks in the series...
+ The best and most complex controls for Snake out of any MGS game, allowing real freedom of movement...
+ Hundreds of weapons to choose from, including options to edit them and make your own versions...
+ A long main campaign over a combined 35+ missions (including story side ops)...

However, these elements are all dragged down by glaring issues:
- ... That are often just the same 4-man outpost cookie-cutter stamped across both maps.
- ... Which is not only missing the series's main theme but feels out of place, using modern synths in a 1984 game.
- ... Which seems to have input issues regardless of your control scheme, with Snake sometimes moving randomly (sometimes to his death or a mission failure). Even when the controls do work properly they feel loose and inaccurate.
- ... That are clearly bad or strictly worse than a select few weapons. Many weapon upgrades are simply bigger numbers with occasional add-on slots.
- ... Which is chock-full of a disgusting amount of padding. The majority of the missions and side ops are simple extraction missions where you sneak in, attach a magic balloon to a prisoner, and then run to a chopper.

Full review (with light spoilers):

For a game that was supposed to bridge the gap between the original Metal Gear games and the MGS series's later titles, there is very little storytelling or character development here. The only character with real growth is Huey, who is a piece of trash that you (and everyone in the game) grows to hate. Sure, Huey might be the best written character in the series, but it doesn't excuse how everyone else is fueled by revenge and has their arc concluded with revenge. There are also few cutscenes, with most of the meat of the story being told through Codec calls- *ahem* -I mean, cassette tapes. The game also takes a sharp turn from GZ's tone, with Skull Face going from being a creepy, mysterious horror one step ahead of you to being a caricature of a bond villian (who exposes his whole scheme to you during an awkwardly long caravan ride to his real" base). The worst part is a lot of the story is repeated; you seem to be expected to listen to all of the cassette tapes to get the full story (imagine how bad previous games would've been if you were expected to pay attention to every non-critical Codec call!) and yet the conversations on them are often repeated or paraphrased during the main game! The game also fails to conclude all of its threads appropriately; most notoriously

reviewText:
This game is worth full price, and is a steal on sale.

The missions are based mostly on time to get an S rank, and I really like that because it gives you a challenge to complete the missions as fast as you can in either a stealthy way or a loud and crazy rambo style, lethal or nonlethal, and keep in mind that as long as you complete your main objective you can do so with whatever you please, and there are a lot of cool things to upgrade and unlock with blueprints and base upgrades.

The game is open world, so you can go through side op missions out on the field without going back to base and really get into a survival kind of mindset, you can also call for supply drops to keep you going. The night and day cycles are very nice. I mean it really depends on how much you want to immerse yourself into the game. You do have to go back to base for main missions thought becasue cutscenes.

I could go on and tell you about all of the cool ways i've completed missions, and those would be the way's that I've done them, but really you should go and explore and be creative in your own way, keep and open mind with this game and just have fun with it, dont be reserved in unlocking and upgrading things, use as much as you want, kill as much as you want for the first playthrough of the story, then go back and be perfect with S rank runs, be more nonlethal to get S rank soldies to volunteer.

One thing that I did to have a lot of fun with the game is I didn't hit restart checkpoint the first runthrough in story when I got caught out, I just went with whatever happened. Was just a very awesome experience.

There are a lot of hidden things about this game, I wont list them really as you can find youtube videos on that. But I will tell you that the AI will adapt to how you play, there is no difficulty setting, it goes by your playstyle. So, if you get a lot of headshots, they will start to wear helmets, if you use a lot of lethal weapons they will begin to wear body armor and get upgraded weapons themselves, and if you play at night a lot they will have nightvision goggles, if you use sleep grenades, youll see gas masks, cleymore mines if you go the same route a lot, snipers if you snipe a lot, and if you get spotted a lot, they'll put up more security cameras, plus a few other things they do.

Oh, and look for cracks in walls, they lead to alternate paths.

You get a dog that can pull out a stun stick to go and shock the Sh** out of someone, so you can do really cool combos with that, like if there's two guys, you can order him to stun one and time that with tranqing the other. Or you can equipt him with a knife if you have lethals.

Do not try to find out about the story, and do not let your friends spoil anything for you as your mind will be more blown if you find out things for yourself. However, DO go and find out secrets of the game with no spoilers on youtube.

One of my favorite things is if you find a sexy babe poster you can put it on your cardboard box that you can hide in, and when you stand up with it a soldier if hes spotted you will run up and just drop his gun and drool at it so you can easily take him out.

Umm, is there antying else?? Most definitly, but I think I've said enough about this game for a recommendation. To me this is a brilliantly designed game. You can rush through the story, but I believe this game deserves to be taken slow. I didnt pass mission 22 until well after 300 hours, and I'm still having fun with the game. There's 50 main missions, a few are repeats but you wont get the actual end scene and credits until mission 46.

reviewText:
It's like they started building a great monument, like the Taj Mahal or the Great Pyramids and then just sort of stopped, and left it unfinished. What is left is still an absolute marvel, but one can't help but feel disappointed when looking at the empty space where a complete monument should be.

Metal Gear Solid V (it should probably be pronounced 'vee') is both a massive success and an enormous catastrophe. The gameplay is simply sublime (as long as you turn off reflex and auto-aim and never use the chicken hat, you scrubs). It's everything you ever would have wanted a Metal Gear game to be since the first game in the series was released in 1987. When infiltrating a base (pretty much the only thing you really do in this game) everything must be considered, from the lighting, gear, to the camo you're wearing, the whether, everything. The lighting and shadowing in this game looks amazing, and the shadows in particular make for a fun mechanic, as the generated shodows act as cover for the player to sneak through unnoticed. The game is completely immersive when performing missions and I had many moments that felt completely real. Most of the weapons in the game feel tight and well balanced, however the combat is completely ridiculous. The use of stealth can be quickly made redundant by simply running at an enemy and holding the action button, which at first is quite fun as you clothsline and dive at enemies; but after it gets old, the over powered combat is a major game breaker, and could have had a lot more thought put into it.

There is no ending to this game. It wasn't finished. There is a huge portion of the game missing and no plans to work on it. The story is terrible, and most of it takes place in cutscenes situated at Mother Base where characters argue and fight, eventually to be broken up by snake. The mojority of the games cutscenes feel unfinished and unpolished, and some are so awkward they even belong in a cringe video, for instance the truck scene with Snake and Skull. I could even swear that many of the significant events that take place (of which there aren't many) are had in locations and between characters that weren't originally intended to be used, and that there was not enough time to create the context that the events were supposed to occur in, leaving even some of the more polished cutscenes feeling awkward. This is bad on top of the fact that the story and premise is just a repeat of MGS:PW. it's not unusual for Hideo and team to repeat set pieces as an inside joke, but in this case it really just leaves me feeling like I'm playing the same game again. I would have liked a new experience. From this it can be seen the as much as Konami have been a hinderence to this game, Hideo and team have clearly made some terrible decisions from the word go. (Spoilers) Making you play as NOT Big Boss at NOT Mother Base along aside characters who resemble, but are NOT future members of Foxhound and making it blatently obvious from the first half hour of the game that this is how things are going to be is DEFINITELY one of them. This extreme subversion of expectations could have been haunting and surreal had it taken place within a finished story, with proper character development and pacing, and there are moments where it is evident that they were trying to achieve just that, but in the context of unfinished game it just makes for an even more embarrassing failure.

Don't expect a good Metal Gear game, and get it when it's cheap, and you'll have a good time.

The content I've lost... the hours I've lost... won't stop hurting... It's like they're all still there. You feel it, too, don't you? I'm gonna make them give back our game!

reviewText:
Life isn't just about passing on your genes.
We can leave behind much more than just DNA.
Through speech, music, literature and movies...
what we've seen, heard, felt
...anger, joy and sorrow...
these are the things I will pass on.
That's what I live for.
We need to pass the torch,
and let our children read our messy and sad history by its light.
We have all the magic of the digital age to do that with.
The human race will probably come to an end some time,
and new species may rule over this planet.
Earth may not be forever,
but we still have the responsibility to leave what traces of life we can.
Building the future and keeping the past alive are one and the same thing.

reviewText:
my initial review. I'll update this when I reach the 30h mark in the game.
I wanted to buy this game since it's 1st trailor, I'm a big fan of metal gear series and played the 1st and 2nd to completion multiple times. I've also played the 3rd on ps3 but not to completion. now after this brief introduction I'm gonna write what the game is all about in details below.

- Gameplay:-

so even though I havn‚Äôt played metal gear for a long time, I can without a doubt tell you that the gamplay is just plain marvelous this game is semi open world. A mix between deux ex, assassin creed, witcher while throwing metal gear taste in it, so u can expect how good the atmosphere is, I usually switch between mouse/keyboard and xbox 360 controller while gaming and I don‚Äôt see any problem switching what so ever. The stealth system is sophisticated and AIs are smart. There are plenty of way you can execute your mission and a lot of stuff you can requisition for your motherbase.

- Motherbase and the game mechanics:-

what makes this metal gear special is that snake has grown up and is now the boss, now this move from the devs strikes at heart especially for veterans who have played the series since they were 12 years old. it give you the feeling on how snake and miller has been at this for too long and their now old, matured and met their full potential. Your unit name is diamond dogs and u are running at, and u‚Äôll be adding stuff to it, you have the support team and R&D you can recruit enemy personal and important personal, soldiers etc by knocking them cold and attaching a ballon beacon to where they are transported, you also get assigned missions, side missions from contracters, in asense you work for the government but are now mature enough to be freelancing on your own in order to win cipher and become strong enough to defeat them, u get briefing from your subordinates and u get to pick the mission that u want. And of course u get to rescue, sabotage, spy and gather intel. I feel this game is tailored toward veterans rather than new comers and so I love it.
-Graphics:-
the game looks astonishingly great, it‚Äôs very realistic and detailed and suprisinly very well optimized, I 1st thought I won‚Äôt be able to play it on my gtx 680 sli but I ended up only fully utilizing on of them. I really love the engine, it kinda look like GTA V but way more realistic and refined and way more optimized. And even on medium to low settings it still look really good. So rest assured if your PC is not in the master PC race you can still play and enjoy this game at 60fps.

-Storyline ( some spoilers ):-

it‚Äôs classic metal gear campaign and story, with you belonging to the FOX organization that is fighing the ever expanding cipher organization which I suspect is in bed in the soviets. The story takes place in 80s and has a mix of technological beauty and retro cassettes and themes. That astounishgly protraits how the militaries had a lot of advanced prototypes even for todays standards.

-Is it worth a buy?:-

well to be honest I wanted to buy this game regardless but then a month ago I got into a giveaway contest and won it!! So I got that working out for me, but I would say it worth it‚Äôs price. This game is within the league of fallout 4, GTA V( more worth it) and borderlands series combined. This is a work of art and a game that YOU MUST PLAY even if ur a new comer to the series. For new people this will change you life, our lives have already been changed by the 1st and 2nd metal gear 12 years ago and you life will be changed by this one. When I played this game for a brief period I remember why no game will ever and never come on par with metal gear the original series in this genre of games and all genres..

reviewText:
6th of October update edit: Paid 'insurance' as to not lose your materials and staff from forced online FOB. Konami, you're pretty good kid, at being a dirty money grabber.

Pretty cool game overall, but just too many bad aspects to really recommend.
Character slides down tiny slopes all the times, 3 steps to the right and you can walk up something steeper just fine.
Ending didn't feel like an ending, as if at least a whole chapter is missing from the game. Might be The Phantom Chapter.
The 'Gear' boss fight was really bland and boring for what should have been an epic boss fight, on that note proper proper boss fights were lacking all together in my opinion.  Skulls feels forced and are easy to cheese, Quiet was okay but felt like a desert End
Base building all comes down to one (1) resource, which you'll always be lacking. As soon as the parasites were introduced the whole campaign turned generic and got quite predictable

On the positive side I like being able to bring your style to the field, though killing everything severly impedes your base development.
FOBs are quite easy to invade, doing it full stealth is pretty hard on well developped bases though (unless cowardly Reflex mode). Start by trying to stealth. If you get caught:
Sprint to objective
Lay down and hide behind some cover
NPCs give up the search
Win

reviewText:
It's like they started building a great monument, like the Taj Mahal or the Great Pyramids and then just sort of stopped, and left it unfinished. What is left is still an absolute marvel, but one can't help but feel disappointed when looking at the empty space where a complete monument should be.

Metal Gear Solid V (it should probably be pronounced 'vee') is both a massive success and an enormous catastrophe. The gameplay is simply sublime (as long as you turn off reflex and auto-aim and never use the chicken hat, you scrubs). It's everything you ever would have wanted a Metal Gear game to be since the first game in the series was released in 1987. When infiltrating a base (pretty much the only thing you really do in this game) everything must be considered, from the lighting, gear, to the camo you're wearing, the whether, everything. The lighting and shadowing in this game looks amazing, and the shadows in particular make for a fun mechanic, as the generated shodows act as cover for the player to sneak through unnoticed. The game is completely immersive when performing missions and I had many moments that felt completely real. Most of the weapons in the game feel tight and well balanced, however the combat is completely ridiculous. The use of stealth can be quickly made redundant by simply running at an enemy and holding the action button, which at first is quite fun as you clothsline and dive at enemies; but after it gets old, the over powered combat is a major game breaker, and could have had a lot more thought put into it.

There is no ending to this game. It wasn't finished. There is a huge portion of the game missing and no plans to work on it. The story is terrible, and most of it takes place in cutscenes situated at Mother Base where characters argue and fight, eventually to be broken up by snake. The mojority of the games cutscenes feel unfinished and unpolished, and some are so awkward they even belong in a cringe video, for instance the truck scene with Snake and Skull. I could even swear that many of the significant events that take place (of which there aren't many) are had in locations and between characters that weren't originally intended to be used, and that there was not enough time to create the context that the events were supposed to occur in, leaving even some of the more polished cutscenes feeling awkward. This is bad on top of the fact that the story and premise is just a repeat of MGS:PW. it's not unusual for Hideo and team to repeat set pieces as an inside joke, but in this case it really just leaves me feeling like I'm playing the same game again. I would have liked a new experience. From this it can be seen the as much as Konami have been a hinderence to this game, Hideo and team have clearly made some terrible decisions from the word go. (Spoilers) Making you play as NOT Big Boss at NOT Mother Base along aside characters who resemble, but are NOT future members of Foxhound and making it blatently obvious from the first half hour of the game that this is how things are going to be is DEFINITELY one of them. This extreme subversion of expectations could have been haunting and surreal had it taken place within a finished story, with proper character development and pacing, and there are moments where it is evident that they were trying to achieve just that, but in the context of unfinished game it just makes for an even more embarrassing failure.

Don't expect a good Metal Gear game, and get it when it's cheap, and you'll have a good time.

The content I've lost... the hours I've lost... won't stop hurting... It's like they're all still there. You feel it, too, don't you? I'm gonna make them give back our game!

Overall, it's a great game and I highly recommend it.

reviewText: This is the one time where I truly wish Steam had a neutral review option. I choose negative only because I am forced to pick one or the other, so I flipped a coin.\n\nThis is the best terrible game I have ever played. Beautiful, masturfully directed and voice acted cutscenes interruped by pointless, arbitrary supernatural junk which contributes nothing to the advancement of the plot. Tight, amazingly realistic stealth infiltration mechanics punctuated by unnecessary, unexpected forced-combat missions where you blow up giant robots and fight super soldiers who summon rock missiles. Cutting edge, believable, cooperative enemy AI which, late game, ramps up into godlike awareness. A final act where actual story missions become locked behind repeating harder, cheaper versions of older story missions where you fail instantly at the slightest provocation, and where the game's idea of a checkpoint is the moment you stepped off the helicopter

And yet most of the time I stop playing because I have become disgusted with how grindy/cheap/frustrating something has become. I am grateful that I am not a professional reviewer because I would be horribly torn on what score to give this game. It is simultaneously the best game of 2015

Spoiler freeI'm going to be clear and honest in this review and I will not spoil anything about the story, perhaps talk about it from an objective perspective and more so about the gameplay.

This title brings a really cool experience. You have powerfull cutscenes from the beginning of the game that might leave you with many questions... and by leaving I mean unanswered untill you progress far into the story, this might cause you to feel like the story falls short if you focus on doing many side ops. This might also cause you to feel like the objectives in the game start to feel slightly repetitive.

Let me be critical.Optimization 10/10
I have never encoutered game braking bugs, lags, etc. The game functions smoothly.

Gameplay 9.8/10
The gameplay is so well done you will feel immersed in the missions.
Your intelligence will be tested. If you are the kind of player that wants to go with the classic stealth approach you will have to put all your attention into what you are doing, the loadout you are using, and learn the mission to understand how to do it the fastest way and get an S rank. The combat will also feel fun in any other approach you feel like using but you wont feel a full experience unless you try them all or at least go for the stealth one, you will sometimes feel forced to sneak around.

Story 8.1/10

The story is indeed where this game excells and at the same time falls short, why? simple the game is not finished. Kojima is indeed an artist and I'm going to quote da Vinci to deliver my point here: Art is never finished

reviewText:
Gameplay 9/10

Story and Mission Content 4/10

If you like the controls and stealth gameplay offered, buy the game. It's great in that aspect. If you actually know the MGS story and are looking forward to the 'missing link' or next game in the MGS saga, don't bother.

The game starts off with a bang that really feels like a MGS game, and once you finish the first chapter everything feels 10/10. Unfotunately it all drops downhill rapidly as you start the second chapter, which you even get a crazy and exciting trailer for at the end of the first chapter.

Unfortunately, the second chapter feels incredibly rushed as about 70% of the missions are recycled versions of missions in chapter 1 (I mean it's literally the exact same mission, but with increased difficulty, the debriefings are even the same and thus don't make sense). Only about 5 missions here are actually original and only 3 added to the story. The ending pops up out of nowhere (provided you've done enough of the recycled missions) and then you're pretty much finished.

I feel like this game earned it's title of 'The Phantom Pain' for the empty feeling you get after it's done, thinking Wait what? Was that it? What happened with/to [various plotlines]? (hint: Chapter 3 was cut out of the game so a variety of plotlines are left open unless you watch a 20min video on youtube)"

In summary
date: The Phantom Pain offers the best gameplay in the MGS saga
recommended: but possibly one of the worst stories. A game with plenty of potential ruined by unfinished and rushed content."

Graphics

boring repetative missions

This is just sad. I am a huge MGS fan. I havent played a MGS since Sons of Liberty on the PS2, but I fondly remember spending hundreds of hours in MGS1 (PS1) and MGS2(PS2).

I heard the reviews for MGS5 and the hype took over, I was super excited for this game. Im only 20 hours into it, but am sorely disappointed. So far every misison is just capture this guy or destroy this item. MGS5 tries too hard to jump on the open world bandwagon, instead of sticking to its tried and true roots of an epic stealthy-story-heavy game. The story in this game is told almost exclusively through tape cassettes, since it is mid 1980s after all. The parts that arnt told through the story are amazing. The first 30 or so minutes of the game really raised my expectations.

As for the good. The stealth mechanics are well done. In some cases, too well done, as it can get frustrating and stressful to play. This is one of the only games I've ever played where I can only do 1-2 missions per sitting due to just not giving a crap anymore as a result of constant failing over and over. The engine plays great. I have not noticed a single hint of slowdown on my GTX 980. The world, while pretty, is bland and full of desert. I havent encountered any sort of environments like other metal gears. Nor have I encountered any boss fights. The game seems like a shallow attempt to reinvent the series into the newest fad, open world games. For me it just doesnt work.

I keep hoping I will reach a mission and Kojima-san will pull another glorious Snake/Raiden switch and MGS5 will be like: Here is the actual game!" Alas

reviewText:
Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Story

Let me start by talking about what was good.  The gameplay was fantastically fun, with lots of great ways to complete objectives.  Mechanically it is also stellar how well this game was put together.

Unfortunately that is where the good ends.  This is was not the metal gear experience.  It was a hobbled together frankenstein of a time wasting micromanaging open world war monger simulator. The story ends faster than it started leaving you with phantom motivation to even play the game.  None of the characters with the exception of DD, and Quiet had any personality.  The fact that Big Boss ‚ÄúSnake‚Äù the hero just seemed to shrug and give no input for everything giving including torture was quite appalling. Yes he just stands there watching, this is the guy who is a hero because he is the master of non-lethal infiltration. The rest of the cast do not even matter, they are just a bunch of weak bullies hungry for power.

The Metal Gear experience I know is being thrust into an unwinnable situation with nothing but your gadgets and your codec calls for information alone. Not constantly being forced to go back to your main base via loading screens and long helicopter rides and a maddening rate. Fast travel is only available at the main base and not in the combat zones as to make the game take artificially longer, Fallowed by endless repeat fetch quests, and more required base building. Awful‚Ä¶  just awful.

I don‚Äôt know if Kojima was forced to make the game like this or not, but it is not Metal Gear worthy.  I wonder if the choices for the music tapes from the game were what he was listening to when he was working on this‚Ä¶ thing.

If you have never played or no nothing about Metal Gear there is a slim chance you may like this game.

If you love Metal Gear and have played the previous titles STEAR CLEAR.

If you must know what the game is about, just watch the cut scenes, but even then it is a hallow experience.

I will miss this franchise.

Final verdict 4/10

You know how you like something initially, and then it gets rended to crap by a publisher? This game is that.

I enjoyed the 100+ hours I spent on it, but I also did all of it offline before the changes.

Not to mention the game isn't actually complete to begin with, but oh well.

STORY / ATMOSPHERE
Okay first of all i explain how much they give you story in the game. I myself am pretty confused how much the game developers decided give players the story at one time sometimes you dont get absolutely no story at all for really really long time and sometimes you get so much of it you feel like you want to skip them and want to start playing(Note: this happends only at prologue when the game starts). Ofcourse i understand its part of MGS series and im big fan of the series becouse of its good story line and long cinematics but in this game they give it to you SO HUGE AND SO RARE amounts the problem is THE RARITY of the story telling. So basicly if you are only after the story and like fast or even medium- forwarding paste story you get really frustrated in this game.

When the game starts in prologue chapter its cinematic blasting and every single action is cinematic style and you have no gameplay for an about 1hour of the game it almost feels like Heavy rain title game where you can eat popcorn and watch cinematics without the options to chance the story ofcourse which i would be just fine with that but its not the problem. The real problem is after the prologue there isint much of story telling its quite rare and the game starts to lose atmosphere at some points.

But after Prologue the real game starts THE SANDBOX experience and it feels like really SLOW and BAD if you are after THE story which you should its metal gear game atleast. You start spending alot time on Main missions how you progress in the game which doesnt absolutely give you any of the main story only for really long time and gives mostly just some random events, random people appear which arent very intresting and you dont get back to them after the mission is done which all seem to be quite irrevelevant on your MAIN story. Sometimes you actually get the feeling like your doing side missions in other sandbox game like GTA title but your actually doing main story mission which is sad when it comes to story and this feeling can keep up on hours and its NOT GOOD.

You can go on to 2-4 hours depending on your progress without any story then you get small-medium chunk of main story and you always have thirst for more but the game just doesnt give it to you, and you find your self frustrating and grinding boring main missions over and over again AND They are repeating themself ALOT you are getting again into same places just do different stuff you start to get bored and the game feels so grindy when you realize you are going to the same place for a third time then you realize something is off. THE GAME ITSELF IS UNFINNISHED i have seen alot posts about this on internet also on this part atleast.

So basicly the game forces you to do same content over and over again AND OVER AGAIN. its really bad. When you finnish chapter 1 IT GETS NIGHTMARE when it comes to replay and losing atmospehere the game changes from good to absolute horrible when it comes to story.

IN CHAPTER 2 you do same missions over again and sometimes you get new mission but rarely you spend 90% of your time doing replay missions on ridilous difficulity example do mission 1 without any gear and hard enemies its like playing MGS2 on newgame + on EXTREME difficulity exepct the story is still unfinnished you havent seen all of it. So its like a carrot to a rabbit to keep players in badly designed game THE GAME IS REALLY UNFINNISHED from that part. AND THE GAME HAS only 2 chapters and you only mostly replay old chapter 1 missions in last chapter 2. WHICH IS ABSOLUTELY HORRIBLE DESIGN CALL.

the problem of this type is really bad when it comes to enjoyable story. I myself actually sometimes forgot what even had happened in the story becouse of the long breaks from it and boring repeating main missions without no story or soul in them. Even the story itself is kinda open and most of the times you are kinda confused at start of the games and some mid game cinematics you dont get much of it and some things you just dont GET which is really weird. and havent explained some things that happen propely this has happen to alot of people not just me.

GAMEPLAY:
Gameplay itself is quite good atleast in combat mode Snake moves nicely and responses good on movement shooting is good responses nicely.

Sneaking on the other hand is quite hard and frustrating they made it that way that if even 1 enemy sees you for 1second the hole Base or surrounding enemies who wouldnt even see you at the moment are also magically seeing you instantly what makes no sense whatsover and starting to instantly shoot you and you cant do much prevent the ALERT mode
Unlike in older MGS games like MGS2 enemies would actually call reinforcments before alert and you could stop them before that and it actually makes more sense i think its kinda bad design call once again from game devs. But in this game the alert goes instantly off and makes sneaking quite annoying and frustrating biggest design problems in my opinions are the large area's and maps older MGS had small maps and good gameplay on when it comes to sneaking around. In this game maps are absolutely huge and sneaking is quite bad in large MAPS and you get spotted easily and alert is hideous in this game it takes so so long time to lose the alert mode so most of the time you just hit Menu last checkpoint and save alot of time that way. It kinda ruins sneaking experience if you are pressing checkpoint 10-20 times for each missions just becouse of annoying game mechanics kinda ruins the mood.

Also there is alot of useless stuff in the game like minigames Staff you can control at your motherbase and way too often you dont even get the hang of the old minigames / mechanics and the game already introduces you to another useless mechanic and that kinda makes you frustrated too. The introduction's to these mechanics are flawled sometimes the game dont even tell you all you need to do. But you have to figure out how to press menu things etc on this minigame type of scenarions. There is other crappy stuff too example when you start new mission snake has to look view from his helicopter it might get annoying to look that same view like 60 times in game since they last around 1-2min each also ranking system on missions is bad you can get S the best rank with sneaking mission for just only shooting rocket launcher and playing it like Duke Nukem makes no sense this game would suppose to support sneaking..

Game is pretty much of grinding there is million new weapons you can get of and new items and tools and equipent and partners and vehicles and it gives you alot of game hours like 50+ if you want to do all of this kinda stuff this game provides you might actually like this game. But overall you get frustrated if you are after good Story or atmospehere. The game loses its atmospere quickly and if you are finding experience like OLD MGS this will be disapointment to you as it were for me.

reviewText:
A Fan's Review


An Introduction-I don‚Äôt normally write reviews, and I know that this is going to be a big surprise to some people, but I feel like I would be doing an injustice to myself if I didn‚Äôt try and share my opinion on this game. I realize that I may be among a small amount of people that feel this way, or maybe I am wrong‚Ä¶ Regardless of that, I think that this review is coming from an enormous fan of the series since the NES days and I hope that people reading will respect that. That being said, I will try to organize this well, and make this an objective review.

I down-thumbed this game for a MULTITUDE of COLLECTIVE reasons, I will discuss them in a random and not really specific order, but I hope to cover everything I can without going too crazy long. I will compare this game to its prequels at times, I believe it is fair in some ways and not so in others, although I am aware that this game is very different.  Here we go, boys and girls, it‚Äôs a long one.

GAMEPLAY-This game, if you familiar or not, is part of a relatively old series that originated in 1987 (NES release date). Of course the gameplay dramatically changed since then, but this game in particular is, as you may know, a far-cry from the other installments. Open world, Tactical Espionage Action. This is what the game does exceedingly well. MGS always pioneered great gameplay and Mr. Kojima is known to make whatever sacrifices needed to insure this. This game is in no way a BAD game to play, it may very well be the best game to date that allows the player to wander as they wish, doing as they please in a militaristic setting, but I feel it may be the worst Metal Gear.

STEALTH-It creeps closer to realism in this game, Guard shift changes, weather impacts, flashlights, supply routes, communications, and many more make this game a revolution in the stealth field. Over the course of the game enemies will adapt to YOUR playstyle, giving themselves helmets if you score headshots, flashlights and night vision if you attack more at night. It is very hard to say negatives about this area of the game without splitting hairs, this was the focus of the series and Metal Gear always did this well. Just for difficulties sake, turn off reaction time.

COMBAT-This is where the game misses a small step. I was hoping for more of an array of customization to Snake‚Äôs load out. It is has become the Metal Gear way to have two pistols, one tranquilizer and is .45, especially Big Boss, however this is impossible. The types of weapons you can carry into battle are rather set in stone. That aside, most other things are very well organized and going loud is a very viable option for fun in this game alongside sneaking, making them wish they never spotted you.

CUSTOMIZATION-This is, in my opinion, the best quality of the game. You have complete control to customize almost every aspect of the game to your liking. Change the color of almost everything you can use, and develop your own emblem to be shown on flags and shoulders. And the game features my favorite weapon customization type, akin to Army of Two, you can mix and match barrels and stocks of all your guns and create entirely new ones in the process. Making the assortment of weapons in the game essentially multiply.

The F.O.B.-The online Forward Operating Base was a great idea on paper before release, but it is a rather large disappointment for many in the game, a lot of people just choose to ignore it. Once you do infiltrate once, you almost already have done it all. It almost makes you a nanny, taking you out of intense missions to make you defend your base against someone like me, who invades just to take all your resources, pummels you with explosives and waltzes to the command room.  This aspect of online I‚Äôm sure will be shadowed by the coming Metal Gear Online which I hope is grand.

Storyline-It is with this that I may be the most unsatisfied. Simply put, it does not live up to the quality of Metal Gear. The fans looked forward for the first steps of Big Boss‚Äô plunge into villainy, they wanted to see the beginnings of The Terrible Children, and they wanted to see hatred and revenge‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt see any of those things delivered. The trailers for the game were almost a lie, manipulating scenes in almost all the cut scenes to make you think something completely different about them. It‚Äôs not something I feel that I can approve of. We are given areas of the game for choices to be made that impact nothing, only lead to the exact same ends defeating the purpose of their existence.

For what seems no reason ‚ÄúToo be continued‚Äù is put in the middle of cut scenes, breaking the immersion to bring you back to the mission selection screen for you to press next mission and continue anyway immediately. Movies and shows do this break not because they want to, but because they have to for time slots, and in an industry that is trying way too hard to become another, instead of forging its own path, this game is the definition of attempts at that. Do not mistake me for saying that movies and games shouldn‚Äôt mix and ‚ÄúMetal Gear shouldn‚Äôt be like a movie,‚Äù I am saying that it shouldn‚Äôt have to bring over the bad qualities of them to do so. The sad truth is the one damned place we should have gotten the ‚ÄúToo be continued‚Äù was at the end of the game because it ends so abruptly, I was barely aware it ended. The game has a plethora of gutted content that haunt the fans. It‚Äôs what happens when a game as big as Metal Gear comes out in days where this is becoming more and more okay for developers to give us unfinished games.

METAPHORS AND THEIR EFFECTS ON GAMEPLAY-Kojima had a lot of messages to deliver with this game. I think that it might be the first ever example of a game that features such heavy metaphors that it encumbers the gameplay, removing the fun from it. If you kill, snake will be covered in blood, but if you kill too much he will be covered permanently too look like a demon. The player is now punished to play with low resolution red blotches covering their body as they extract helpless animals out of their habitat to the middle of the ocean to get ‚ÄúNice‚Äù point. If I wanted to play Fable, I would play Fable.

It is the metaphors that lead to the most questioned aspect of the game. I will try to continue without spoiling anything. At the shortened finale of the game, we lose a beloved asset to the gameplay. A favorited aspect of the game is removed for the sole purpose of being beaten over the head by a metaphor, into submission. It is the prime example of the will for powerful metaphors hindering fun, and for a game designer I misunderstand how this is a good choice. Petitions are already in place for the changing of this, and a mod is most likely right around the corner. There already is one, but it is a little complicated and isn‚Äôt a solid answer yet.

TL;DR


So in conclusion, I am merely saying what most others are saying online, the game is a disappointment to the fans of the series, but the gameplay is truly rock solid. It is still a great game to be played, but it is barely a Metal Gear. In my personal, biased, eyes the series should have ended and did end at Guns of the Patriots. This game was a move to copy the gameplay of Peace Walker with more action and deliver it on a massive AAAA scale. But the sad truth is, not many fans enjoyed Peace Walker, and in such, not many are approving of this game. I know I am making blanket statements, and you may have enjoyed Peace Walker and this game too, however take a trip online and see the big picture. I‚Äôm not going to be your big brother and point you to answers online, but don‚Äôt do so unless you beat the game, spoilers are everywhere. As a fan, I dislike this SEQUEL.


Thanks for reading, share your thoughts!
