reviewText:
Want to manage your own outfit? Sorry wrong phrasing there, what I meant to say was your own tactical OU. The chance to deploy troops on regional operations, manage tech/RD, recruit POW's, infilitrate enemy encampments on solo ops, infiltrate FOB's, charge into FOB's/enemy encampments, travel to regional locations with varying degrees of flexibility in your approach to an objective and well, everything operating your own tactical OU entails pretty much. There are far more things to be done and to do. Being 'Boss' ain't easy and requires a lot of input, but you have an entire MB to support you in that regard. A growing MB at that.

So if you ever dreamed of managing your own tactical OU with the guise of being this legendary Warrior (the greatest Warrior of the 21st Century mind you) and operating all this from your laptop then hell, this game is for you soldier. Think Jagged Alliance 2 but a little more involved I'd say....Bet you'd never see that comparison coming.

Now get your laptop online and connect to your TCO and prepare to engage and infiltrate FOB's of opposing PMC's. Oh and let's not forget to help out Big Boss eh? Afterall we are the guys that provide Mother Base, Big Boss and all his tactical units full coverage and support via our laptops/PC's. Feel's good to be an NCO (Senior NCO at that) and work alongside Big Boss himself even though we do not deploy to the field personally, we ensure operations are controlled to the smallest detail (quite literally I'm sure you would all agree).

So how would I rate managing my own tactical OU? Well I don't. I only do what is needed to be done and carry out order's as is expected of a soldier and I expect you all to do the same.

(I thought Witcher 3 was a generational MasterPiece. It seems there is yet anouther game that must be added to the list of Generational Masterpieces. Hell Big Boss may be the greatest Warrior of the 21st Century, but Kojima's game is defintely one of the greatest game's of this Generation. Period).

reviewText:
Enjoyable gameplay but lacking in every other department, to fans of the series it feels like a slap in the face.

MGS5 is sadly never a 10/10 the story feels like fan fiction that Kojima wrote one lazy weekend, it's so mediocre. The gameplay is decent and it's the only redeeming factor although such repetitive missions/side missions can't be excused, there isn't much variety at all in the 150 side missions they are basically a rinse and repeat scenario, only 15 of the 50 'main' missions actually move the plot forward. At least Keifer Sutherland pulls through he really does nail those 8 lines he had to speak.

Im scratching my head wondering how this took over 6 years to develop,it's enjoyable but laughably overhyped there was clearly development issues in that time perhaps Konami and Kojima should have spent less time marketing it and instead producing a better game. I loved this series but i can't reccommend a game that was falsely marketed, has cut content and literally slaps you in the face with the horrible second chapter and recycled missions. Mgs5 is completely incomplete, should have called it The Phantom Story.

- The pacing.
- The plot.
- Mute Snake.
- The ending.
- The cut content.
- The repetitive missions.
- Worst bosses in the series.
- The time to get from MB -> ACC -> Mission.
- The spoiler credits at the beginning of each mission.
- Pointless side-ops.
- Quiet is terribly written, but what part isnt.

All of these and more make for an average game, the first in the series i won't replay.
Final score: 6/10

reviewText:
First Impressions:

Firstly, great game so far and I would recommend it.  Don't buy it on steam thought, ¬£46 is far to expensive when you can get it on other well known sites for a fraction of the cost and activate it via steam.

So the game?

This is definately a game that focuses on story and cinematics. There's about 30 mins to an hour of cutscenes and mundane gameplay before you get into the free roaming missions part of the game.  That's not bad, the opening intros set the scene and are very gripping, but having just played through the METAL GEAR SOLID V: GROUND ZEROES, I was itching to get into the action and did find the intro a little too long for my taste.  I was also slightly confuded. You're made to change your character's appearance which you do via a 'mirror'. Then later you're shown your face again and it's snake, and you continue to play with Snakes face so I've no idea what that was all about..... #confused.

Once past that though, the action / stealth is great fun. It's nothing that's not been done before mind you with splinter cell coming to mind, but tied up with the beautiful graphics, its well worth playing.

Unfortunately for me, I'd forgotten that the previous MGS's were heavily 'super natrual' themed and coming from Ground Zero, I was expecting a traditional military sneak em up like Splinter Cell. All these wierd things like flaming man, floating straightjacket woman and the zombie like soldiers kinda broke the immersion for me, but I accept that's my fault for not reading the synopsis before buying.

That said, it's a minor gripe, one I can get over quck enough by just going wit the flow.

Finally I should mention the controls.  I've read a lot of the negative reviews and many are focusing on the controls.  Keyboard controls are fine. Sure they take a little getting used to but if you're a PC gamer at heart, you should have no problems adapting.  Yes, it is a 'head shake' moment when you pull up the key map and find it shows you controller diagram, but oh well!

So in short, the game has some minor issues (what game doesn't?) but nothing that should stop you buying this.

Enjoy!

reviewText:
After all the terrible PC launches of big titles, it's wonderful to find out that The Phantom Pain is extremely well optimized and looks stunningly good. That right there is enough for me to give a positive review.

As for the game itself, I find the gameplay to be a bit lackluster so far. The controls and mechanics are not very intuitive. A jump button and some simple climbing mechanics would have made the navigation far less awkward than it is now.

The real star of this game are the cutscenes, as they are simply the best in-engine cutscenes I have ever seen. The voice acting, audio, camera work, writing and overall direction are all splendid.

reviewText:
Cons:
- online is funky (not unexpected in the first week)
- bug with steam overlay
- some control related issues

Pros:
- support for the game is constant and always working on something
- Graphics in gameplay and cutscenes look great
- controls for snake make you extra deadly
- music is love, that womans vocals draw you into the story
- choose your own adventure (figure out how to do things yourself and do it)


The bugs were small and didn't effect graphics or gameplay really, I was able to fix the overlay and controller one simply by reloading so I assume it had more to do with the fact the game is still getting polished for online first week jidders with updates. Other than that though the customer service is responsive in my experience and they seem to be constantly working on the online experience and maintenence is I think three times a week which is decent. The way snake manipulates the environment around him is wonderful and it completely immerses you in the story. The autosave feature saves headaches if you mess up and the camera control is polished and easy to manipulate if you want to shoot off the left or right shoulders, duck and peek over cover, slide down slowly while looking behind you, etc.. The story is definitely a solid point in the series and it doesn't disappoint here either; I was on the edge of my office chair the entire time during the prologue and I already have to many questions than answers meaning I will be 100% marathon gaming this whenever I have game time. Once they throw you into your sandbox you can do whatever and see what happensl they don't really tell you what to do so its all up to you how you take down a base. The combat is open and free and you can do whatever you want given your tools and environment. The reflex from MGS GZ is back and it still works wonders if your spotted. Great experience so far.

reviewText:
With a HUGE backlog of history, an unsettling amount of depth, and a crazy amount of thought out into this game. It isn't for the light hearted. Those unfamiliar it is not a held guide along a beautiful path, but a mouintain path frought with peril above some of the most treachourous of lands.

BUT

it is a road worth walking, for both the unseen & the veterans.

WHY?
the history and depth alone should merit this, but alone it does not. Alone it is but a fragment of what could be the understatment of the year. The rich depth behind every character goes a long way, the smaller references invite multiple fascitudes of story and enlighten worldy players of their backstory. Inevitably each moment is both profound for old and enlightening for new.

It provides multiple types of gameplay, using open world mechanics, inside a mission driven structure, using strong Ai & consistent character development to make each play a strong willed push into the unknown. Each mission is thought out as to approach it anyway YOU choose. Are you the sniper that likes to hit and leave? would you prefer to CQC yourself some enemies and get some new recruits? or just going for that masterfullly stealthy assassin play and get in and out unseen...or go in guns blazing. Ultimatetly the decision is yours. This is why it makes a massterful game.

HOW?
The game gives sense of purpose to every slight connetation it has. From subtle story elements to overly dramatic crazy gunfights with enemies that look as though they've been forged by a love of anime and giger alike. Ultimately the purpose behind each story element and every mechanic has weight. Nothing feels like a poor attempt, nothing feel's floaty,  nothing belittels itself after 10 hours or more. Each mechanic in game, from hold up's to the careful use of stealth to infiltrate has had minor tweaks from other games, further development & weight added.

This feels more like a culmination of the series, gathering all the quirks and problems and eviscerating them entirely. Giving HUGE plot point's and dialog pieces enough space to breathe, but enough screen time as not to bore those who just want some action.

THAT GOOD?
In a word YES
In many YES but, we have a game here that achieves so much it would be silly to belittle the smaller pieces of game that bare no weight or have trivialites, these have been put in becasue of the fan's love for the series, hideo kojima's masterpiece is here. His being in game's has spiralled to this point. Whether we see more from him in this light is uncertain, but what is certain is that this is his pinnacle currently.

It would be a shame for anyone to miss out.

reviewText:
Game: Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain
Score: 9/10
Recommended? Yes
Worth a buy at full price? Yes

Overall a great game for old and new mgs fans alike, but don't expect the same story telling and the same long, artful cutscenes that you've been accustomed to: this game is more focused on gameplay, and the story is quite gimped compared to the other games in the series.

Pros:
+Great introduction
+Great TPS gameplay
+Vehicles
+Many customizations
+Great deal of ways to approach any given mission
+Buddies to bring into battle
+Many hours of content
+Open world
+Difficult (if you avoid killing and reflex mode)
+Great graphics
+Awesome optimization (all high+extra high on GTX660 1080p@60fps)

Cons:
-Gimped story when compared to other MGS titles
-Reflex mode makes the game a joke for stealth
-Forced multiplayer
-Microtransactions
-Slow, timed development of in-game items (similar to upgrading structures in clash of clans)
-Bare, empty world
-Weak boss fights
-Some missions are repeated exactly with only a few extra challenges added to them

Conclusion:
If you don't care for story and don't come from an MGS background, and like great graphics and gameplay, then this game is worth your money and time, and will be fun for you to play. If you were hoping for a great finale to the MGS series, you may be a little disappointed. All in all, a good buy, but definitely not 10/10" as IGN seems to put it. I'd say its more like an 9/10 for gameplay

reviewText:
It's pretty great. Runs well and looks nice. Gameplay is excellent and the story has its moments. People are complaining about the Chapter 2 feeling rushed and honestly, it kinda is. However, if you are going for 1‚Ç¨ per 1 hour of entertainment value, you are pretty likely to fill that quota in chapter 1 alone, so yeah.

People also complain about the online FOBs. Other people can infiltrate your motherbase and steal your staff and resources even when you are offline. But does it really matter? I have now played the game for quite a few hours and I have been invaded quite a few times and... I have never lost anything meaningful. Biggest loss has probably been an A++ staff member. So what? You can get 10 new ones in 5 minutes. It literally doesn't matter, if you play the game. You can even lock-up your staff members (I can lock-up >100 members, the amount seems to increase when you develop your base), so they can't be stolen or killed by your rivals. I have pretty much all my >S rank staff locked-up. I have nothing to lose in FOB.

And if you do happen to be online, it's payday baby. The attacker really has no way to win against you and when you succesfully defend your base you get pretty nice rewards from it. When you are offline, people from your friend-list can go defend your base. And they often do for the rewards. Overall, it's not a bad system. It actually sparks up the end-game quite nicely.

reviewText:
Tactical Espionage Action at it's finest. The choice of a stealth or loud approach to missions is entirely up to you, the guards have random patrol patterns to keep you guessing where they will be and the fulton recovery system never gets old :D. Excellent storyline so far, but I still need to complete it fully. It has a cast of rather believeable characters even though some of them are a genetic milestone away from reality. And just as a side note, Quiet is my new Pinup Girl!

The Fox Engine really helps you to immerse yourself into the game with the excellent graphics, and the time shifting from day to night back again combined with the change in weather conditions also present extra challenges to be methodical around.

reviewText:
Writing a review after 200+ hours of continuous gameplay:

First part of this game the prologue gets me into the depth of the storyline behind the Big Boss's lost motherbase nine years ago, this part which I really like because it's so exciting to look at in my opinion, some of you may not like the prologue like saying its so boring or it takes so long to get on the gameplay controls.

After finishing the prologue: the meeting with Revolver ocelot at afghanistan the dialogue between him and Big Boss is great for listening to it, it makes me feel like I'm in some sort of rockstar games (red dead redemption)

The story missions overall is good but short and has some of replays of the same missions but on different difficulty levels to prevent you from speed running the whole storyline.

The controls: you can properly control your player in a very responsible way but if you want to dodge you're welcome!

In-game Photography: the graphics are excellent and correctly optimized for both of Nvidia and Amd video cards.
The smoke particles are heavy especially when getting close at them they impact perfromance by half and some times more than half, LOL.
The textures are very good but I think they need more higher resolution and HD remake.

Things I dislike about this game:

1. The number of Vehicles and the freedom of customizations both need to be extended and improved in any somehow.

2. Kinds of soldiers depending on the suit they wear are just few but facially looking different from each others, there are 2 kinds of soldiers you can extract, Africans, Russians. They speak different languages and some of them the same, for example: African: speaks English, kikongo (the epidemic disease lol), Wears the same as other African soldiers. Needs more weapon classified soldiers!

3. Entrances: Well, I can't find any huge enemy building base to sneak into like in mgs 2. Everything's like small rooms and buildings without even doors.

Bonus: I wish hideo kojima could remake the metal gear solid 1, 2, 3 series all into one for PC and put them up for sale like what CAPCOM did with resident evil series.

reviewText:
The Man Who Sold The World
An incomplete masterpiece.

The game has a godlike optimization, an intuitive and smooth gameplay. Its history, the way it narrate, the plot twists, the events, the missions design, the rawness of his images (of extreme violence, sometimes very extreme)... a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing masterpiece, at least during the first chapter... after that, everything is down hill from here.
The advertising images,trailers, news, sold much more than what it is. The story could have been a lot more. A lot. The game, in the second half, has a serious lack of script, well, there's not script at all, and much filling and repetitive stuff. We already know that the game cut content, very important content for some reason without sense. It is not the end we were promised, there's not the answer we're looking for.  Many of you can considering this as a spoiler.  The end, if you can call it an end... is a decaffeinated one, is the ultimate meeh, It is a bad ending. The last stretch, to unlock the final missions... the worst I've ever seen, anticlimactic, meaningless, exasperating...
A crying shame, the game will transcends, no doubt, it is incredible. But for some reason it has a number of totally erroneous and senseless decisions.

like its end and the story they try to sell us with that cassette from the man who sold the world and the Operation Intrude N313, they sold us the world with this game, promising much more, than it really is.

reviewText:
I'll preface this by stating that this review is coming from a lifelong fan of the Metal Gear Solid series (though I'm not quite old enough for the original Metal Gear games) and have played every entry in it thus far.

Positive:
The most well-optimized PC game I have ever played. This runs on maximum settings at a steady, high frame rate, and in my near 200 hours of playing it, never once has it stuttered, dropped in frame rate (at least not noticeably), or had a single screen tear. Also, one of the best looking games I've ever laid my eyes on. Transitions from gameplay to cutscenes are seamless.

Clean, intuitive interface and controls. Whether you're on foot, horseback, or riding in a mech, everything is fluid and precise. I don't think I've ever accidentally done something I didn't mean to in terms of character control. The stealth gameplay is very well executed and the enemy AI is generally good despite a hiccup here and there.

Variety is the name of the game. You can approach any given scenario pretty much however you want. Charging in guns blazing will almost always get you killed until you reach a certain level and unlock more powerful weapons, but that's an option. Want to steal a tank and ride it into battle? That's an option. Command your horse to defecate (‚ÄúDo it!‚Äù) on the road to cause enemy vehicles to swerve out of control? That's an option. If you have, say, enemy communication satellites to destroy, you can go tactical by sneaking in at night in a stealth suit with a silenced tranquilizer pistol and planting C4 to detonate from a distance, remaining undetected. You can also choose to destroy the satellites with a rocket or grenade launcher or ride in on a mech and use its customizable on-board weapons or never even leave your helicopter, simply fly above the site and mow down enemies and the satellites using its mounted minigun. Veterans of the series will be happy to know that the cardboard box also makes a return, and now you can distract enemies by taping posters of female models on the side of it or use it to slide down hilly areas for up to hundreds of feet. The game's world is a big playground, and simply wandering around in it aimlessly can be surprisingly satisfying.

There is a section in which you ‚Äúdevelop‚Äù new weapons and gadgets by using the game's fictional currency. You will need to raise certain sections of your army to specific levels to unlock some weapons (more on the army aspect later) as well as go hunting for soldiers and resources in the field. This gives you a more customizable experience, as you choose what weapons to unlock and when. You'll want a decent weapon in each category, but if you're more of a close quarters gunman, you can concentrate on upgrading the shotguns or SMGs first; likewise, if you prefer fighting at a distance, there are sniper & assault rifles and launchers aplenty.

You find cassette tapes littered all over the place, many of them pop songs from the '80s (including David Bowie, The Cure, and Joy Division), which gives the game even more of a sense of period and setting. Plus it's just amazing to hear A-Ha's ‚ÄúTake On Me‚Äù while interrogating an enemy, pushing a knife through his chest, then opening fire on a squad of child labor profiteers.
Negative:
Repetition. There are over 150 side ops, but they're almost entirely comprised of groups of missions in which you do the exact same thing (extract a hostage, destroy an artillery unit or communications outpost, clear a minefield), only in different places. Some main missions, though longer and more complex, are guilty of this too, and there are too few that truly progress the plot.

There are only two maps ‚Äì Soviet-occupied Afghanistan (all desert) and civil war-torn central Africa (mostly marshlands and some forests). Neither contain enough interior settings (which is where Metal Gear Solid thrives, I feel), and while they are large, a lot of it looks the same and it won't take very long before you've explored both maps in their entirety. Mother Base repeats so many textures and designs that it isn't worth exploring beyond looking at your animal conservatory (featuring animals you've trapped in the field) or gathering various collectibles hidden around. This combined with the redundant nature of the missions adds to the sense of repetition in MGSV.

Hideo Kojima. To me, he's like the George Lucas of videogames ‚Äì Metal Gear Solid is one of the best games ever made and MGS3 is arguably the best game in the series, but story-wise, everything else is eccentric & wacky at best and randomly silly & stupid at worst, and there's nobody to tell him no, save Konami (and only after he cost them too much money). MGSV is rife with plot holes, including a gaping one due to budget cuts that prevented Kojima's team from finishing the final mission which would've brought closure to all the storylines left hanging open and properly tied the game into the chronology of the series, leading into Metal Gear 1. Also, at the beginning and end of every mission, Kojima reminds us that this is his game in the form of cinematic credits which accentuate his company and status. He even makes a cameo in the game as himself *again* (he did this in the exact same context in Ground Zeroes). The game may as well be called Hideo Kojima's Metal Gear Solid V.
Neutral:
The story and particularly the ending which naturally polarized players. I thought this game had some great moments but that they were too far and few in between. It has noticeably shorter and fewer cutscenes than previous MGS games, which, depending on the player, can be good or bad.

The RPG-esque micromanagement that comes in the form of leveling up Mother Base (‚ÄúOuter Heaven‚Äù from Metal Gear 1 & 2 and your home when you're not gallivanting around Afghanistan and Africa). As you extract more soldiers and resources from the field, you'll start to build more platforms and an army to train and house on them, each soldier having a specialty, rating, and, in some cases, a temperament label (some soldiers lie about their true skill or are a negative influence on the squad while others have various positive combat skills). Some may find this fun and a nice distraction from the action while others may find it unnecessary or excessive. You can choose to ignore it to a certain extent, but you will need to level up specific squads in order to unlock some important upgrades.

The difficulty in some missions can be downright brutal, and it doesn't help that the checkpoint system is unforgiving. Boss fights (of which there are much fewer than in previous MGS titles) will start you over entirely if you die, and you can lose a lot of time in missions if you get very far but are spotted and killed. There's no manual save, quicksave, or auto-save of any kind when you're in a mission. You need to be smart, tactical, and patient and not treat this like a typical shooter or 3rd person action game if you're going to survive, especially early on.

This has very little in common with previous games in the series, including the demo/preview game, MGSV: Ground Zeroes. 95% of it is spent outdoors, it's much lighter overall on plot and dialogue, and the nature of its stealth gameplay has changed dramatically by setting it almost entirely outdoors as opposed to the corridor-style settings native to the series.
Verdict:

Though its problems are glaring, they don't detract from the overall experience, which is practically distilled fun. I would recommend this to both fans of the series and those new to it as well. It's one of the best action/adventure games of this generation, though not the best game in the series (in my opinion, that would be MGS3: Snake Eater). It's also unique as stealth games go because of how the those aspects operate in an open world setting.

reviewText:
What an absolute pleasure it is to play this game. Even with my specs, which includes an i7 860 at 2.6GHZ, 6GB of RAM and a GTX 960, the game runs with no issues what so ever and is buttery smooth. It runs at a steady 60FPS with all options on high despite the size of the maps and regardless of what is happening on screen.

As far as gameplay goes, well, Metal Gear has never been better. Sure, there are some slight problems with the AI every now and then such as not being able to spot me for a few seconds out in the open. But other than that (which has occured very sparsely thus far), the AI is deadly and will hunt you down if you slip up. In true stealth fashion, there is plenty reward to be found in observing the enemy and planning your next move, however, a more hands on approach is not punished as harshly as it once was. It is a truly wonderful and tense experience.

Truly a Hideo Kojima Game!

reviewText:
MGSV is the greatest stealth/action game ever made. The game has an enthralling rhythm of choosing objectives, creative planning, and chaotic execution. These three pillars are perfectly balanced, giving you just enough help and direction while retaining an immense degree of player freedom and choice.

What makes MGSV so special is the simplicity of the design coupled with the depth of customization. You can play with the starting gear and do fine, but there‚Äôs always the option to dive in and fully embrace your own playstyle. It is also one of the most technically advanced, graphically realistic, and visually stunning games on the market.

Then there‚Äôs the quintessential Metal Gear story. Many have misunderstood MGSV‚Äôs story, labeling it sparse, lackluster, or even unfinished. Lies! The story is a perfect Kojima tale, giving us something truly unexpected, subverting expectations.

It has been said that the end of any saga should go beyond words and make us feel very deeply. All three (three!) endings of MGSV are heartfelt and moving. And the way the game ultimately ties in with the original Metal Gear is the perfect conclusion to this epic 25 year saga.

In conclusion, MGSV is captivating, brilliant, gorgeous, and bold. It is an artistic masterpiece and a masterclass in game design. Go play it right now!

One of the best stealth (action-adventure) games out there and the best Metal Gear Solid game gameplay-wise with near impeccable presentation.

It's surprising how the weakest aspect of this title is its story. Almost every Metal Gear Solid game has been an example of how not to handle exposition, however, they make up for it with interesting story/plot/characters/bosses/themes. Metal Gear Solid V The Phantom Pain fails to deliver in almost all of those aspects to the point where sometimes it doesn't feel like a Metal Gear Solid title. It‚Äôs hard to say if most of it, if not all, is a consequence of the controversy surrounding the game‚Äôs development and release or of Hideo Kojima‚Äôs shift in priorities, regardless, this is what we got.

It might be a ‚Äúdisappointment‚Äù for some long time fans of the series and to explain how and why would mean serious spoilers, not just for this game but for the entire series, but suffice to say that despite all of that it remains a solid title with fun and engrossing gameplay that rewards experimentation and it packs serious amounts of content.

Metal Gear Solid has never played this good.
